questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. On physical examination, you note mild ascites and hepatomegaly. The serum alpha-fetoprotein level is elevated. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Triple phase CT

Explanation:

  • In a patient with known risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), such as chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis, and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein levels, the investigation of choice is Triple phase CT.
  • The preferred method for definitive diagnosis of HCC is a Triple Phase CT scan, which highlights arterial hypervascularization and venous washout.
  • A triple-phase CT scan has the following phases:
    • Arterial Phase - HCC shows hyperenhancement due to its arterial blood supply.
    • Portal Venous Phase - HCC may appear isodense or hypodense as it becomes less conspicuous compared to the surrounding liver tissue.
    • Delayed Phase - HCC exhibits washout, a characteristic feature - appearing hypodense relative to the liver parenchyma.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the components of the given apparatus except:

choices.text: It contains 1 black cup and 6 white cups.
The 6 white cups are of 200ml capacity each
The indicator used in this is starch iodide.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It has 1 glass stirring rod.

Explanation:

The image given is that of Horrocks apparatus.

It is an apparatus used to estimate the chlorine demand of water (or the dose of

Bleaching powder that is required for disinfecting water).

Contents of the apparatus

  • 1 black cup
  • 6 white white cups (200 ml capacity each)
  • 2 metal spoons
  • 7 glass stirring rods
  • 1 special pipette
  • Starch-iodide solution
  • 2 droppers

Procedure:

  • A stock solution is made by mixing 2g (1 spoonful) of bleaching powder with water in the black cup and filling up to the brim.
  • The 6 white cups are to be filled with water to be disinfected up to about a cm below the brim.
  • With a special pipette provided, 1 drop of stock solution is added to the 1st cup, 2 drops to the 2nd, 3 drops to the 3rd cup, and so on.
  • Water is stirred in each cup using a SEPARATE glass rod.
  • After 30 minutes, 3 drops of the indicator are added to each white cup and stirred again.

Interpretation: The first cup that shows a blue colour will tell us how much bleaching powder is required. (n*2) where n = first cup which shows the blue colour change.
n× 2 is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water.

Hence 7 separate glass rods are necessary for performing this method correctly, not 1.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a history of untreated pulmonary tuberculosis presents with symptoms of dysuria, hematuria, and flank pain, and noticed a gradual worsening of his symptoms. His laboratory tests are consistent with renal impairment. Which of the following features are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

  • GUTB (Genitourinary TB) typically originates from the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from the lungs or thoracic lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria lodge in the kidneys, triggering an inflammatory response causing tissue destruction, caseous necrosis, dystrophic calcification granuloma formation, and scarring and strictures in the ureter.

 

  • The putty kidney is a sequela of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) characterized by "extensive dystrophic calcification involving all or most of the kidney, seen as calcified non-functioning renal tissue."
  • It is the end stage of renal tuberculosis making the kidney non-functioning.

  • Hematogenous spread and granuloma formation: GUTB typically originates from hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from the lungs or thoracic lymph nodes. The bacteria lodge in the kidneys, triggering an inflammatory response that leads to the formation of granulomas.
  • Caseous necrosis and tissue destruction: If the infection progresses, it can lead to caseous necrosis, a form of cell death characterized by a cheese-like appearance. This process destroys renal tissue, impairing kidney function.
  • Ureteric strictures and obstruction: GUTB can also cause scarring and strictures in the ureters. These strictures obstruct the flow of urine, leading to hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine buildup) and further damage to the kidney.
  • Dystrophic calcification: Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in damaged or necrotic tissue. In the context of GUTB, the extensive tissue destruction caused by infection, inflammation, and obstruction creates an environment conducive to calcium deposition.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining biopsy samples from different parts of the small intestine. Which of the following histological features would most likely indicate that the sample is from the ileum?

choices.text: Abundant Brunner's glands in the submucosa
Thick circular folds in the lumen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Numerous large Peyer's patches

Explanation:
Numerous large Peyer's patches are a characteristic feature of the ileum.

 

The table below discusses various histological features of small intestine:

Feature

Duodenum

Jejunum

Ileum

Lumen and Wall

Wider lumen, thicker wall

Wider lumen, thicker wall

Narrow lumen, thinner wall

Circular Folds

Large, thick circular folds

Large, thick circular folds

Small, few circular folds

Villi

Numerous broad villi with goblet cells

Numerous tall villi with goblet cells

Few, short and slender villi with goblet cells

Brunner's Glands

Present in submucosa

Absent

Absent

Peyer's Patches

Absent

Very few, only in distal part

Numerous, extending into mucosa

Histology image

Presence of numerous tall villi (Option A): This is more characteristic of the jejunum, not the ileum. The ileum has fewer, shorter, and more slender villi.

Brunner's glands (Option B) are absent in both the jejunum and ileum.

Large, thick circular folds (Option D) are more prominent in the duodenum and jejunum. The ileum has smaller and fewer circular folds.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations, dizziness, and chest discomfort. His vital signs are blood pressure 75/50 mmHg, heart rate 190 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. He appears pale and diaphoretic. ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Administer IV amiodarone 150 mg over 10 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perform immediate synchronized cardioversion

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and ECG suggesting a monomorphic wide-complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm is consistent with a diagnosis of an unstable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • The first line of treatment for unstable VT with a pulse is synchronized cardioversion.

 

Wide QRS Tachycardia (QRS ≥0.12 second):

  • Ventricular in origin
  • It includes ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, pre-excited tachycardias (Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome), and ventricular-paced rhythms.
  • Ventricular tachycardia is classified as monomorphic or polymorphic
  • Treatment is based on the type of ventricular tachycardia

 

Monomorphic VT:

  • Regular, stable with a pulse- DOC is Adenosine 6mg IV push followed by 12mg IV push if needed
  • Unstable patient with pulse-synchronized cardioversion
  • No pulse- Unsynchronized shock

Polymorphic VT:

  • With pulse- Amiodarone or procainamide
  • Without pulse/unstable- Unsynchronized shock

 

Ventricular fibrillation:

Note: Almost always presents as unstable, without a pulse- Unsynchronized shock

 

Administer IV amiodarone 150 mg over 10 minutes (Option A):

  • It is not the first-line treatment in a patient with hemodynamic instability and shock.
  • Immediate cardioversion is preferred in unstable patients.

 

Perform immediate unsynchronized defibrillation (Option B):

  • Defibrillation is indicated for pulseless VT or ventricular fibrillation (VF).
  • This patient has a wide-complex tachycardia with a pulse, making synchronized cardioversion the appropriate approach.

 

Administer intravenous adenosine 6 mg (Option D):

  • Adenosine is used to treat stable, regular, monomorphic wide complex tachycardia with a pulse.
  • This patient is unstable with pulse making synchronized cardioversion the appropriate approach.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of poor vision during nighttime and dryness of the eyes. On physical examination, you observe Bitot's spots on the conjunctiva. There is concern about vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate WHO grading of vitamin A deficiency and treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: X1B ; 300,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D7
X3B ; 100,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D21
X1B ; 200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D28
X3B ; 400,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D14

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X1B ; 200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D28

Explanation:

  • The presence of Bitot's spots corresponds to the WHO grading X1B for vitamin A deficiency.
  • For a child over 1 year old, the recommended treatment is 200,000 IU of vitamin A once daily on D1, D2, and D28 (4 weeks later).

Bitot’s Spot

WHO Grading of eye signs of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in children

Grade

Eye Sign

XN

Night blindness

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis

X1B

Bitot's spots

X2

Corneal xerosis

X3A

Corneal ulcer covering less than 1/3 of the cornea

X3B

Corneal ulcer covering at least 1/3 of the cornea

XS

Corneal scarring


 

Age Group

Treatment

Under 6 months

50,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

6 to 12 months

100,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

Over 1 year

200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later 

 

Use in preterm infants:

  • Vitamin A supplementation improves respiratory function and reduces the risk of chronic lung disease.
  • It reduces death or oxygen requirement, with no impact on neurodevelopmental outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Colposuspension surgery

Explanation:

In this scenario, all the conservative and less invasive measures have failed. Hence, the next best step in management is colposuspension surgery.

Treatment of urinary incontinence:

Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)
  
  • Note: Mirabegron contraindicated in severe uncontrolled hypertension systolic blood pressure ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≤ 110 mm Hg, or both
  • Mirabegron is better tolerated than antimuscarinics in older patients and can be considered as an alternative to antimuscarinics for elderly patients.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the ER with complaints of chest pain radiating to his left arm for the last 30 minutes. He has a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia and hypertension. ECG showed features of stable angina. Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate was administered, which provided pain relief. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: It donates nitric oxide, which activates guanylyl cyclase, thus increasing cytosolic cGMP.
It hyperphosphorylates Myosin light chain kinase.
It blocks the L-type voltage-gated calcium channel in the vascular smooth muscle.
It inhibits the degradation of cytosolic cGMP.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It donates nitric oxide, which activates guanylyl cyclase, thus increasing cytosolic cGMP.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Glyceryl trinitrate is a potent nitric oxide donor, which in turn activates soluble guanylyl cyclase thus increasing production of cGMP .
  • This results in the activation of cGMP-dependent protein kinase (PKG), which dephosphorylates myosin light chain kinase (Option B), thus interfering with actin-myosin binding, resulting in vascular smooth muscle relaxation.
  • This vasodilating action provides rapid angina relief by reducing the afterload and increasing blood flow to the ischemic myocardium.

(it blocks K+ channels in the beta cells of the pancreas, thus reducing insulin secretion)

(Enzyme dependent)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is found dead in his apartment under suspicious circumstances. Upon initial external examination, petechial hemorrhages are noted around the eyes. The scene suggests a possible asphyxial death, as there are no overt signs of trauma. During the autopsy by the police surgeon, which among the following has to be opened first to identify definitive signs of asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cranial cavity

 

Explanation:

  • In cases of suspected asphyxial death, the cranial cavity is typically opened first.
  • The order of opening is the cranium, Thorax (Option A), abdomen, and neck. (To get a clear field of study for neck structures after draining of blood from neck vessels via the head and trunk)
  • Asphyxial deaths frequently involve abnormalities in the lungs and airway, such as congestion, petechiae, froth in the airways, or other indicators of respiratory failure.
  • This helps confirm if the cause of death is indeed related to impaired oxygen exchange or suffocation.
  • Examining the heart may also reveal signs of right-sided heart failure due to hypoxia.
  • Abdomen is first to be opened in stillbirth


 

Order of Opening Cavities

Head Injury Cases, Asphyxial Deaths

The skull opened before the thorax and abdomen.

Pneumothorax, Venous air embolism

The Thorax opened first, then the skull.

 

Abdominal cavity (Option B): While the abdominal cavity could be opened to assess for trauma or distension, these findings are less likely to provide direct clues in cases of asphyxia unless abdominal trauma is suspected, which is not indicated here. Thus, it is typically examined after the thoracic cavity.

Pelvic cavity (Option D): Trauma to the pelvic organs or fractures is more relevant in cases involving physical injury or sexual assault. These findings are not directly associated with asphyxial deaths, so this cavity is not examined first.

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife presents with itchy and burning lesions over her hands. She reports using a new detergent solution at home and lesions developed within few hours of usage. She has not had similar complaints in the past. Which of the following statements is correct regarding her diagnosis?

choices.text: Occurs due to type IV hypersensitivity
Lesions may spread beyond the site of contact
Depends on intensity, duration and concentration of substance

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Depends on intensity, duration and concentration of substance

 

Explanation:

 

This patient presents with:

  • Acute onset of itchy and burning lesions

  • Confined to the area of contact (hands)

  • After exposure to a new detergent

  • No prior sensitisation history

These features are most consistent with Irritant Contact Dermatitis (ICD).

ICD depends on:

  • Intensity of the irritant (e.g., detergent chemicals)

  • Duration of contact

  • Concentration of the substance used

 

 

Irritant contact dermatitis

Allergic contact dermatitis

Onset

Within minutes to hours of exposure

Sensitization with first exposure, lesions with subsequent exposure - may be days/ weeks later

Pathogenesis

Direct disruption of the epidermal barrier, inflammation, and cellular immunity activation.

Type IV hypersensitivity

Predisposition

No genetic predisposition

Genetic/ family predisposition present

Distribution

Site of contact

May extend beyond the site of contact

Causes

Detergents, Alkalis, cement, Acids, Cutting oils, Organic solvents

Nickel (watches), PPD - paraphenyl diamine(hair dye), topical neomycin, Parthenium plants

 

Occurs due to type IV hypersensitivity (Option A): This is true for allergic contact dermatitis, not irritant type.

 

Lesions may spread beyond the site of contact (Option B): Again, a feature of allergic contact dermatitis, not ICD.

 

Diagnosed by a patch test (Option C): Patch testing is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis, not ICD.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male diagnosed with testicular torsion is scheduled for emergency surgery. During the pre-anesthesia assessment, the type of anaesthesia was decided. Which of the following about the needle (in the image below) used for administering the necessary anaesthesia is incorrect?

choices.text: Less chances of Post dural puncture headache

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is a dura-cutting needle

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image depicts a Whitacre needle, a dura-separating needle (not a dura-cutting needle) commonly used in spinal anaesthesia. (Option C ruled out)
  • It has a conical, pencil-point tip with a small orifice, which is useful in reducing the incidence of Post dural puncture headache (PDPH)

 

Types of needles used in Spinal anaesthesia:

Dura Separating Needle

Dura Cutting needle

Sprotte’s needle and Whitacre's needle

Quincke’s needle

The pencil point tip creates a smaller puncture. (Option A ruled out)

A sharp tip makes a larger puncture

Reduced chances of PDPH (Option B ruled out)

Highly prone to PDPH due to CSF leak

25, 26 or 27 G are regularly used

Rarely used these days

questions.text: A 6 year old with severe earache and fever following an upper respiratory infection presents with a bulging, red tympanic membrane and a yellowish spot. What stage of ASOM is this?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Stage of Suppuration

 

Explanation:

 

Stages of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)

Stages

Feature & Symptoms

Signs

Stage of Tubal Occlusion (Option A ruled out)
  • The Eustachian tube becomes blocked due to inflammation and increased blood flow, particularly at the nasopharyngeal end.
  • Mild hearing loss and earache. Usually, no fever is present.
  • Eardrum retraction, the handle of the malleus becomes horizontal, prominent lateral process of the malleus, and reduced light reflex.

Stage of Exudation (Presuppuration) (Option B ruled out)
  • If the Eustachian tube blockage continues, pyogenic bacteria invade the middle ear, leading to inflammation and fluid accumulation.
  • Symptoms worsen, with significant earache that may disrupt sleep. Hearing loss and tinnitus may occur.
  • Redness initially on the pars tensa, followed by visible blood vessels along the malleus handle and the eardrum's periphery creating a "cartwheel" appearance.

Stage of Suppuration (Option C)
  • Pus forms in the middle ear causing the eardrum to bulge outward due to the pressure.
  • Excruciating earache, increased hearing loss, high fever (up to 102°F-103°F), vomiting, and possible convulsions.
  • A red, bulging eardrum with obscured landmarks, a hidden malleus handle, and a yellow spot indicating potential eardrum rupture.

Stage of Resolution (Option D ruled out)
  • The eardrum ruptures spontaneously, releasing pus and alleviating pressure.
  • Relief from earache and fever as the inflammatory process subsides. Symptoms improve with pus drainage.
  • Blood-tinged discharge initially, becoming mucopurulent.
  • A small perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant of the pars tensa is usually visible.
  • The eardrum's redness decreases and its landmarks become visible.

Stage of Complications
  • In severe cases, the infection may spread beyond the middle ear, leading to serious complications.
  • Potential complications include acute mastoiditis, subperiosteal abscess, facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, petrositis, extradural abscess, meningitis, brain abscess, and lateral sinus thrombophlebitis.

They later have a child who presents with symptoms of anaemia and requires regular blood transfusions. Further investigation reveals that the child has beta-thalassemia, a genetic disorder prevalent in the region. Which of the following symbols can be anticipated in this couple, which is a risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:  B

 

EXPLANATION:

Consanguineous marriages (marriages between relatives) increase the risk of their children developing genetic (autosomal recessive) disorders. This symbol represents this risk in the pedigree chart.

 

 

 

The symbols used in the pedigree chart:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a 40-year history of heavy smoking presents with progressive shortness of breath and a chronic cough. On examination, he has a barrel-shaped chest and decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.55 and a significantly decreased DLCO. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the decreased DLCO in this patient?

choices.text: Increased thickness of the alveolar-capillary membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of alveolar surface area.

 

Explanation: In emphysema, the destruction of alveolar walls leads to a significant reduction in the surface area available for gas exchange. This is the primary reason for the decreased DLCO in patients with emphysema, as the reduced alveolar surface area limits the ability of gases, such as carbon monoxide, to diffuse across the alveolar-capillary membrane.

 

DLCO (Diffusing Capacity of the Lungs for Carbon Monoxide)

  • It measures carbon monoxide (CO) transfer from the alveolar gas to the pulmonary capillary blood.
  • Carbon monoxide is used because it has a high affinity for hemoglobin, and its uptake is limited primarily by the rate of diffusion rather than by perfusion.

 

Procedure
  • Inhale gas mixture (CO and helium)
  • Hold breath for ~10 seconds
  • Exhale and measure CO concentration

Factors Affecting DLCO
  • Lung Volume: Lower volumes decrease DLCO (e.g., restrictive lung diseases)
  • Hemoglobin Level: Anemia lowers DLCO; polycythemia increases DLCO
  • Carboxyhemoglobin Levels: Elevated in smokers, reducing DLCO
  • Alveolar Surface Area: Reduced in emphysema, decreasing DLCO
  • Pulmonary Blood Flow: Reduced flow (e.g., pulmonary hypertension) decreases DLCO

Clinical Interpretation
  • Reduced DLCO: Interstitial lung disease, emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary vascular disease, anemia
  • Increased DLCO: Polycythemia, asthma, left-to-right cardiac shunts

Significance in Clinical Practice
  • Differentiate obstructive vs restrictive lung diseases
  • Assess disease extent in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, sarcoidosis

 

Increased thickness of the alveolar-capillary membrane can decrease DLCO, it is more characteristic of interstitial lung diseases such as pulmonary fibrosis, where fibrosis thickens the membrane. (Option B)

 

Decreased pulmonary blood flow can contribute to a reduced DLCO, it is not the main mechanism in emphysema. In emphysema, the primary issue is the loss of alveolar structures. (Option C)

 

Hyperinflation of the lungs is a common feature of emphysema, it does not directly cause a decreased DLCO. Hyperinflation results from the loss of elastic recoil and air trapping, contributing to airflow obstruction but not directly to the decrease in diffusing capacity. (Option D)

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman at 16 weeks gestation has a history of three prior pregnancies and her last delivery was 18 months ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate Td vaccination schedule for this patient?

choices.text: 2 doses of Td vaccine, one month apart, starting immediately.
1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.
No Td vaccine is needed for this pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

  • This patient is considered a multigravida because she has a history of three prior pregnancies.
  • Her last delivery was less than 3 years ago (18 months).
  • The use of Td is recommended during pregnancy to protect against maternal and neonatal tetanus & diphtheria during prenatal care.

 

Primi-gravida or multigravida with last delivery >3 years ago

2 doses of Td vaccine:

  • Td1 - Early in pregnancy, 0.5ml IM
  • Td2 - 4 weeks after Td1, 0.5ml IM

Multigravida with last delivery <3 years
(If received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 yrs)

Td-Booster around the 7th month of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Barberio test

Explanation: 

The given image shows the Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.

 

Test Name

Substance Detected

Result

Reagent Used

Barberio Test

(Option B)

Spermine

Yellow needle-shaped crystals of Spermine Picrate

Picric acid
