questions.text: Which condition is characterized by recurrent catalase positive bacterial, and fungal infections, defective nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test results, and deficient reactive oxygen species production by phagocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation, with recurrent catalase-positive bacterial and fungal infections, negative nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test results, and deficient reactive oxygen species production by phagocytes, is due to defective NADPH Oxidase, suggesting Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

  • It can be X-linked recessive (75% cases) or autosomal recessive (25% cases).
  • diagnosis: 
    • Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) is a screening test commonly used to assess the respiratory burst activity of phagocytes. In CGD, phagocytes fail to reduce NBT to its insoluble form, resulting in a negative NBT test.
    • Dihydrorhodamine test (DHR) is the confirmatory test for CGD done by flow cytometry.


Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (Option A): Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in leukocyte adhesion or migration, leading to impaired immune responses. It is of 3 types: 

  • LAD I: Defect in β2 integrin
  • LAD II: Deficiency of sialyl-Lewis X
  • LAD III: Mutation in the FERMT3 gene

Hyper-IgM Syndrome (Option B) is a group of primary immunodeficiency disorders marked by elevated IgM levels and decreased levels of other immunoglobulin isotypes, resulting from defects in either the CD40 ligand and the CD40 receptor.

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (Option C), also known as Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia or Bruton's disease, is caused by mutations in the BTK gene and primarily affecting boys, is characterized by a lack of mature B cells and impaired immunoglobulin production, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections​​​​​​.

questions.text: A patient who is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus has been prescribed a drug which is a PPAR-gamma receptor agonist. All of the following are incorrect with respect to this group of drugs except?

choices.text: These drugs act by sensitizing skeletal muscles to insulin
These drugs reduce the production of adiponectin
The dose should be increased when combined with gemfibrozil
Play a supportive role in post-menopausal osteoporosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) These drugs act by sensitizing skeletal muscles to insulin

Explanation:

PPAR-gamma agonists/thiazolidinediones act on the PPAR (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor) gamma in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, sensitizing them to insulin and reducing blood glucose levels (primary action).

 

Activated PPAR-gamma receptors enhance the expression of insulin-dependent glucose transporter GLUT-4 in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle.

 

Secondary actions:

  • Suppressing hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  • Reduces fatty acid release.
  • Promotes lipogenesis.

 

Drugs:

  • Pioglitazone (available in India).
    • Metabolised by CYP2C8 and CYP3A4.
    • Given only in type 2 diabetes mellitus.
    • Side effects: Plasma volume expansion, oedema, weight gain, headache, myalgia, mild anaemia, and increased risk of fractures (especially in elderly women).
    • C/I: Liver disease and CHF.
  • Troglitazone (banned due to hepatotoxicity).
  • Rosiglitazone (banned due to increased risk of MI/heart failure).


 

Adiponectin (Option B) is released by the adipose tissue, enhancing insulin sensitivity.

Gemfibrozil (Option C) impairs the metabolism of these drugs, leading to potential toxicity; hence dose of the latter should be reduced almost to half. Rifampicin does the opposite by inducing the metabolism of these drugs.

Activating PPAR-gamma receptors in bones will lead to osteoclastic activation, resulting in bone resorption. Thus, these drugs can cause fractures, especially in those with osteoporosis (Option D).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of mild anterior epistaxis, mainly from the nasal septum. Upon examination, the source of the bleeding is traced to a venous structure near the anterior septum. Which of the following veins is most likely responsible for the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Retrocolumellar vein

Explanation:

The Retrocolumellar vein is located in the anterior septum of the nasal cavity, specifically in the region just behind the columella. It is part of the venous drainage system of the anterior nasal septum, an area prone to anterior epistaxis in young people.

 

 

Veinous drainage of Nasal cavity

The greater palatine vein (Option A) and sphenopalatine vein (Option B) are associated with posterior parts of the nasal cavity and palate and are less likely to be involved in anterior epistaxis.

The superior ophthalmic vein (Option D) is located in the orbit and drains structures of the eye, not typically involved in nasal bleeding.

questions.text: If the development of the endoderm is negatively affected and fails to normally differentiate, which of the following glands would not be affected by this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior pituitary

 

Explanation:

The pituitary gland develops from the ectoderm, and hence, an improper differentiation of the endoderm would not affect it.

 

Glands developed from ectoderm and endoderm:

Ectoderm

Endoderm

Neural ectoderm:

  • Posterior pituitary
  • Connective tissue of thymus
  • Connective tissue of thyroid and parathyroids
  • Adrenal medulla
  • Connective tissue of lacrimal, nasal, labial, palatine, oral, and salivary glands
  • Thymus glands (parenchyma)
  • Parathyroid glands (parenchyma) (Option B)
  • Liver
  • Pancreas (Option D)
  • Follicular cells of thyroid (Option A)
  • C cells of thyroid
  • Prostate
  • Urethral glands

 

Surface ectoderm:

  • Rathke’s pouch gives rise to the anterior pituitary (Option C)
  • Sweat glands and sebaceous glands
  • Parotid, sublingual, submandibular salivary glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Lacrimal glands

questions.text: A 18-month-old, previously vaccinated with the Pentavalent series, is due for the 1st DPT booster. The parents are concerned about side effects. What should the healthcare provider explain about the appropriate vaccine and potential adverse effects?

choices.text: Administer DPT as the booster; local reactions like pain or redness are common.
Administer Pentavalent again to maintain immunity; severe side effects are rare.
Administer DPT and monitor for severe side effects like encephalopathy.
No further vaccines are needed after completing the Pentavalent series.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer DPT as the booster; local reactions like pain or redness are common.

 

Explanation:

 

DPT VACCINE

Protects Against

Diphtheria, Pertussis (Whole cell and Acellular), Tetanus

Dosage
  • 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks;
  • 1st Booster: 16-24 months;
  • 2nd Booster: 5-6 years

Route of Administration

Intramuscular, on the anterolateral aspect of the left thigh.

Adverse Effects
  • Local: Redness and pain at the injection site;
  • Systemic: Fever;
  • Severe: Persistent inconsolable cry (>3 hours), seizures, hypotonic hyporesponsive episodes, encephalopathy/altered sensorium, anaphylaxis.

C/I
  • Progressive neurological illness;
  • Anaphylaxis to a previous dose;
  • Encephalopathy within 7 days of the previous dose.

Precautions
  • Previous dose associated with fever >40.5°C within 48 hours;
  • Hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode <48 hours;
  • Persistent inconsolable crying for >3 hours, <48 hours;
  • Seizures <72 hours.

Storage

2-8°C; sensitive to light.

PENTAVALENT VACCINE
  • Protects a child from 5 life-threatening diseases – Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B, and H. influenzae type B.
  • Administer at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks.
  • 0.5 mL given intramuscularly in the anterolateral mid-thigh.
  • Store and transport at +2 to +8°C.

 

Administer Pentavalent again to maintain immunity; severe side effects are rare (Option B):

  • The Pentavalent vaccine is only given in the primary series at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.

 

Administer DPT and monitor for severe side effects like encephalopathy (Option C):

  • While severe side effects like encephalopathy are possible, they are extremely rare.

 

No further vaccines are needed after completing the Pentavalent series. (Option D):

  • Even though the Pentavalent series has been completed, the DPT booster is still necessary at 16-24 weeks to maintain immunity against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has had a fever of 103°F, chills, and severe headaches that have persisted for three days. A blood smear confirms the presence of Plasmodium falciparum trophozoites in erythrocytes. Which type of biological transmission does this parasite undergo within the vector?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cyclopropagative transmission

Explanation:

Plasmodium falciparum undergoes Cyclopropagative transmission within the female Anopheles mosquito.

  • Cyclopropagative transmission in a biological vector refers to the multiplication and development of the agents into their infective form within the vector.

Types of biological transmission:

Propagative transmission

The agent only multiplies in number within the vector.

E.g., Yersinia pestis in rat flea.

Cyclodevelopmental transmission

Agent develops into infective form within the vector without multiplying.

E.g.,Microfilaria in culex mosquito

Cyclopropagative transmission

Agent develops into infective form and multiplies in number within the vector.

E.g., Malarial parasite in Anopheles mosquito

questions.text: A 28 year old male presents to the STD clinic with a history of swelling in the inguinal region as shown in the image below. He has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse in the past few months and reports a painless ulcer, which healed without scarring. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection
Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy
Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of a male with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, swelling in the inguinal region (inguinal lymphadenopathy) and a painless ulcer that has healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The incorrect statement is that it presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV): 

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2). It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection.
  • The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days, and the disease presents in three stages, described in the table below:

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.
  • Diagnosis of LGV can be confirmed by the Nucelic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT). Antibody detection by real-time PCR can also be done. Treatment includes:
    • First line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 21 days.
    • Second line: Erythromycin 500mg 4 times a day x 21 days.
    • Third line: Azithromycin 1g weekly once x 21 days.

 

Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3 (Option A): This statement is true; these specific serovars are the causative agents of LGV.

Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection (Option B): This statement is true; co-infections with other STIs, including HCV, are possible in individuals with LGV.

Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease (Option D): This statement is true; esthiomene (genital elephantiasis) is a recognized chronic complication of untreated or persistent LGV infection.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and a palpable pelvic mass. She reports not having a menstrual period for the past two months. A physical examination reveals a firm, rubbery pelvic mass. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of hCG and LDH. An ultrasound reveals a 10 cm solid ovarian mass, and a laparotomy is performed. Below is the slide after the HPE examination of the biopsy.

 



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:C) Dysgerminoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings, along with the histopathological features seen in the slide (large polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm & dark stained nucleoli & back-to-back arrangement) are features of a dysgerminoma. There is also lymphocytic infiltration of fibrous septa and features are similar to seminoma.

 

Dysgerminomas are malignant germ cell tumors typically occurring in young women and are associated with elevated hCG and LDH levels.

Types of Germ Cell Tumors

Description

Teratoma

Mature cystic teratoma of the ovary

Most common germ cell tumor. They have components of all 3 germ layers

2 Types:-

  • Mature Teratoma (MC GCT Overall)- Dermoid/Cystic, Benign
  • Immature Teratoma- Malignant, monoclonal type

Dysgerminoma
  • MC malignant germ cell tumor
  • HPE- Seminoma type cells seen
  • Tumour Marker- hCG, PLAP, LDH

Yolk Sac Tumor

 

Schiller Duval bodies
  • The most malignant and worst prognosis
  • HPE- Schiller Duval bodies: Central vessels with tumor cells around a cystic space
  • Tumour Marker- AFP, Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Embryonal Cancer
  • Highly aggressive malignant tumour
  • Tumour Marker- AFP, hCG, Estrogen

Choriocarcinoma
  • 2 Types:-
  1. Gestational Choriocarcinoma
  2. Non Gestational Choriocarcinoma
  • Tumour Marker- hCG

Mixed Type
  • Presence of more than one germ cell element (Dysgerminoma + yolk sac tumor)
  • Tumour Markers- hCG, AFP

questions.text: What program is the given image a logo for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) National family welfare program

Explanation:

The image is the logo for the National Family Welfare Program

 

Themes:

  • 2 child norms: Son or daughter → two will do
  • Spacing pregnancies: The Second child should be after 3 years of the first child
  • Universal immunization
  • Community needs-based assessment approach

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of profuse watery diarrhea and multiple episodes of vomiting for the past 3 days. On examination, he appears lethargic, has poor oral acceptance, and has dry mucous membranes. Laboratory tests reveal serum potassium of 2.8 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intravenous potassium chloride at 0.5 mEq/kg/hour

Explanation:

  • Normal serum potassium level: 3.5-5.5 meq/L.
  • Hypokalemia is defined as a serum potassium level below 3.5 mEq/L.
    • Mild hypokalemia: 3 - 3.5 mEq/L
    • Moderate hypokalemia: 2.5 - 3.0 mEq/L
    • Severe hypokalemia: <2.5 mEq/L
  • In this case, the patient has moderate hypokalemia with symptoms of lethargy and dehydration.

 

Etiology:

  • Common causes of hypokalemia in children include:
    • Gastrointestinal losses (diarrhea, vomiting)
    • Renal losses (diuretics, renal tubular disorders)
    • Inadequate intake
    • Transcellular shifts (e.g., insulin administration, beta-agonists)

 

Clinical features:

  • Muscle weakness
  • Fatigue
  • Constipation
  • Cardiac arrhythmias (in severe cases)
  • Polyuria and polydipsia

 

Treatment:

  • The treatment of hypokalemia depends on its severity and the presence of symptoms.
  • In this case, with moderate hypokalemia and symptoms, intravenous replacement is appropriate.

 

Potassium Supplementation:

Indications for IV Potassium Supplementation:
  • Symptomatic patients
  • Severe hypokalemia (<2.5 mEq/L)
  • Presence of ECG abnormalities
  • Unable to tolerate oral feeds.

IV Potassium Chloride Supplementation:
  • Dosage: 0.5-1 mEq/kg per dose
  • Administration: IV infusion over 1-2 hours
  • Infusion Rate: Do not exceed 1 mEq/kg per hour
  • Potassium Concentration:
    • Maximum of 60 mEq/L for peripheral lines
    • Maximum of 80 mEq/L for central lines
  • Avoid using glucose-containing fluids to prevent insulin-mediated intracellular potassium shift.

Oral Potassium Supplementation:
  • Dosage: 2-4 mEq/kg per day, divided into 3-4 doses
  • Common Preparations:
    • Potassium chloride (10%; 20 mEq/15 mL)
    • Potassium citrate (especially for renal tubular acidosis)
  • Administration Tip: Liquid preparations can be bitter; dilute with juice or water to improve taste.

 

Additional Management Considerations:

  • Replace ongoing potassium losses
  • Ensure volume resuscitation with normal saline
  • Correct any associated hypomagnesemia
  • Treat underlying conditions (e.g., monogenic hypertension, Bartter syndrome, Gitelman syndrome)

questions.text: An 8-years-old boy presents with a 5-day history of severe sore throat, high fever, hoarseness of voice, and swollen neck. Physical examination reveals a thick greyish pseudomembrane in the throat and significant cervical lymphadenopathy. A throat swab was sent for microbiological analysis and revealed the following. Which staining technique is used to identify the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Albert stain

 

Explanation:

The above image shows Albert stain of corynebacterium diphtheriae showing metachromatic granules.

 

Albert Stain

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes (Chinese letter or cuneiform appearance), characterised by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli
  • Volutin granules are reserves of energy for C. diphtheriae, as polymetaphosphates are stored in them.
  • 4 stains can be used for staining volutin granules:
    • Ponder's stain
    • Loeffler's Methylene Blue
    • Albert stain
    • Neisser stain

 

Gram stain (Option B): It helps identify rod-shaped Corynebacterium diphtheriae, but does not help stain the metachromatic granules.

Zeil Neelsen stain (Option C): Only stains acid-fast bacilli ans is used in TB.

Gabbet stain (Option D): It is also known as Cold Zeil Neelsen stainand it only stains acid-fast bacilli.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On physical examination, she has diffuse goitre and dry skin. Histopathological examination shows lymphoid infiltration, atrophic thyroid follicles lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

 

Explanation:

The above scenario and HPE findings suggest a diagnosis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis/Lymphocytic thyroiditis..

  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.
  • In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells (hallmark feature of Hashimoto's thyroiditis).
  • It is an autoimmune condition, so on hematological testing we see autoantibodies like Anti-TSH receptor antibody, antithyroglobulin antibody, and anti-TPO antibodies.
  • Genetic cause of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR5 polymorphisms.
  • Long standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis can give rise to some cancers like:
    1. Papillary carcinoma thyroid
    2. Maltoma (a marginal zone lymphoma)

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman was found to have an abnormal NT scan. An amniocentesis revealed a chromosomal karyotype given below. This result most commonly occurs due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-disjunction in maternal meiosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX, +21 is suggestive of Down’s syndrome which occurs due to Non-disjunction in maternal meiosis.
  • Non-disjunction points to the failure of the homologous chromosome to separate during meiotic division.

Mechanism:

  • Trisomy 21 (meiotic material nondisjunction 95%)
  • obertsonian translocation (4%) - involves 2 acrocentric chromosomes ( chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22) that fuse near the centromeric region, with a subsequent loss of the short arms. (Option C)
  • Mosaic pattern (1%) (Option D)

questions.text: Following a sudden outbreak of mystery fever in a South Indian village, several individuals from the same locality developed fever, headache, altered sensorium, and seizures. Which of the following is not true regarding this likely condition?

choices.text: The disease has been linked to Pteropus species as natural reservoirs
The condition often presents as rapidly progressive viral encephalitis
Human-to-human transmission has been documented in prior outbreaks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Case fatality rate below 10%

 

Explanation:

Clinical features point to Nipah virus which is a zoonotic paramyxovirus with outbreak potential and high public health concern. It is transmitted from Pteropus bats to humans, often via contaminated fruits or intermediate hosts. It causes acute encephalitis with high neurovirulence and rapid clinical decline and CFR touching 40 to 75%.  It is present in body fluids like saliva and can be transmitted from person to person.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male is on mechanical ventilation for acute hypoxemic respiratory failure (Type 1). His latest ABG shows:
pH: 7.43, PaCO₂: 38 mmHg, PaO₂: 54 mmHg, HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L.
Which of the following changes should be made to improve his oxygenation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Increase Fio2

The patient has Type 1 respiratory failure (low PaO₂ with normal PaCO₂), indicating a pure oxygenation problem.
Increasing FiO₂ is the most direct and effective way to raise PaO₂.It is alos the lastest and simplest way to improve oxygenation. It provides immediate increase in alveolar oxygen concentration and thus raises PaO₂ quickly. Always titrate FiO₂ up to 60% (0.6) before increasing PEEP.
Increasing tidal volume (A) or minute ventilation (D) would reduce CO₂, not help oxygenation.
Decreasing RR (C) would worsen oxygenation by lowering minute ventilation and overall alveolar exposure to oxygen.

questions.text:
Mr. Sharma's family consists of four members. Mr. Sharma is a graduate working as a manager in a private company, earning a monthly income of INR 50,000. Mrs. Sharma is a high school graduate and a homemaker, and their two children are school students.

Based on the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale, what is the socio-economic status of Mr. Sharma's family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Upper Class

Explanation:

Modified Kuppuswamy scale

Purpose

To assess the socio-economic status (SES) of urban families in India.

Components

1. Education of the head of the family.

2. Occupation of the head of the family.

3. Monthly family income.

Education Score

Illiterate: 1

Primary school: 2

Middle school: 3

High school: 4

Intermediate/Post high school diploma: 5 Graduate/Postgraduate: 6

Profession or Honors: 7

Occupation Score

Unemployed: 1

Unskilled worker: 2

Semi-skilled worker: 3

Skilled worker: 4

Clerical, Shop-owner, Farmer: 5

Semi-professional: 6

Professional: 10

Income Score

The family income per month in Rs.

The income scale has been recalculated using India's average consumer price index for Industrial workers for the year 2021.

 

<100: 1

101-299: 2

300-499: 3

500-749: 4

750-999: 6

1000-1999: 10

=2000: 12

SES Classification

 

Upper Class: 26-29

Upper Middle Class: 16-25

Lower Middle Class: 11-15

Upper Lower Class: 5-10

Lower Class: <5

 

Based on Mr. Sharms’s components:

Education: 7 points

Occupation: 10 points

Monthly Family Income: 12 points

Total Score: 7 + 10 + 12 = 29 points

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent seizures and headaches. MRI reveals a mass located in the cerebral hemisphere. Histopathological examination of the mass shows cells with a "fried egg" appearance and a chicken-wire capillary pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oligodendroglioma

Explanation:

  • The given clinical presentation and histopathological features suggest Oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma:

Aspect

Description

Definition
  • Primary brain tumours arise from oligodendrocytes (glial cells supporting neurons).
  • It is often slow-growing and typically occurs in adults aged 40-50.

Clinical Features
  • Seizures
  • Headaches
  • Focal neurological deficits

Histopathological (HPE) Findings
  • "Fried-egg" appearance of tumour cells
  • Chicken-wire capillary pattern

Radiological Findings
  • MRI is preferred for diagnosis.
  • Contrast-enhancing mass in the cerebral hemispheres
  • It may show calcifications and oedema

Treatment
  • Surgery: Aim to remove as much of the tumour as possible while preserving brain tissue.
  • 5-ALA fluorescence-guided surgery: Helps visualise tumour cells for more accurate resection.
  • Chemotherapy: Temozolomide is commonly used.
  • Radiation Therapy: Recommended for high-grade tumors or when complete removal is not feasible.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal that she has a duplex collecting system, with the upper renal moiety's ureter inserting ectopically into the bladder. The lower renal moiety's ureter is positioned normally. According to Weigert-Meyer law, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: The upper renal moiety's ureter typically drains into the bladder orthotopically.
The lower renal moiety's ureter is more likely to be associated with ureterocele.
Vesicoureteral reflux is more common with the lower renal moiety's ureter.
The ectopic ureter insertion of the upper moiety is often located lateral to the lower moiety's

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vesicoureteral reflux is more common with the lower renal moiety's ureter.

 

Explanation:

The diagnosis of a duplex collecting system is supported by the recurrent UTIs and imaging findings showing separate ureters, with the upper moiety's ureter likely inserting ectopically per Weigert-Meyer law, leading to potential complications like vesicoureteral reflux. 

The normal position of the lower renal moiety's ureter, as per Weigert-Meyer's law, is associated with a higher risk of vesicoureteral reflux.

 

Cross fused Ectopic

• A rare congenital malformation where both kidneys are located on one side of the body (unilaterally), with the ureter of the crossed kidney draining into the bladder on the opposite side (contralateral).

 

• Presentations can range from incidental findings during imaging to renal impairment, depending on the function and anatomy of the affected kidneys.

 

• Often identified through ultrasound, CT, or MRI, showing the kidneys positioned on the same side and their unique drainage patterns.

Duplex collecting system

• A common congenital renal tract abnormality is characterized by incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties, leading to complete or incomplete duplication of the collecting system.

 

• Duplex collecting systems may be associated with vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction, or ureterocele, despite being considered anatomical variants.

 

• Imaging Characteristics: IVP can effectively image both collecting systems, but poorly functioning systems may not excrete contrast, resulting in a "drooping lily appearance" of the functioning lower pole moiety.

Weigert Meyer Law

• Ureteral Drainage: The upper and lower renal moieties each have separate ureters, each with its own orifice in the bladder. 

 

• Ectopic Insertion: The upper renal moiety ureter typically inserts ectopically, medial and inferior to the lower renal moiety ureter, often leading to a ureterocele. (Option D ruled out)

 

• Orthotopic Insertion: The lower renal moiety ureter inserts orthotopically, lateral and superior to the upper moiety's ureter, with a risk of vesicoureteral reflux. (Options A  & B ruled out)

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with an anorectal malformation (imperforate anus) on physical examination. Given the high association with VACTERL anomalies, the medical team decides to conduct a series of radiographic studies to assess for potential associated conditions. Which of the following is a key imaging modality in the evaluation of a neonate with imperforate anus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Invertogram

 

Explanation:

The invertogram is crucial for assessing the most distal level of the bowel in male patients with imperforate anus, particularly when meconium is present on the perineum without an apparent perineal fistula. Proper positioning is essential for accurate evaluation.

 

Invertogram

  • Used to classify anal atresia in neonates by visualizing the distance between the gas bubble in the terminal colon and the perineal skin.
  • Typically performed 24 hours after birth to allow for small fistulas to become apparent.
  • The newborn is inverted from the lower limbs, with careful positioning to avoid hip and shoulder rotation.
  • Remove any radiopaque items and ensure the X-ray is taken during full inspiration.
  • Can cause discomfort and crying, which may lead to misleading results; a prone cross-table lateral view can be a more comfortable alternative.

Invertogram image showing anal atresia

 

Plain abdominal X-ray (Option A): While useful for ruling out esophageal atresia and other anomalies, it does not provide specific information about the anatomy or level of the anorectal malformation.

 

Abdominal ultrasound (Option C): This is important for evaluating hydrocolpos and hydronephrosis in females with cloacal anomalies but does not assess the anorectal malformation itself.

 

Distal colostogram (Option D): This test can evaluate the distal bowel but is typically performed after a colostomy has been created, making it less relevant for initial assessment in a newborn with an imperforate anus.

questions.text:
An arterial biopsy of an elderly male was performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Giant cell arteritis

 

Explanation :

  • An arterial biopsy obtained from an elderly patient showing narrowed lumen, chronic inflammation (blue-coloured lymphocytes), giant cells (present in the arterial wall) and internal elastic lamina fragmentation suggests giant cell arteritis.

Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also known as Temporal Arteritis

  • Key Histopathological Features of GCA:
    • Giant cells in the arterial wall
    • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate (lymphocytes)
    • Narrowed lumen due to intimal thickening
    • Commonly affects patients >50 years old

Takayasu arteritis (Option B)
  • Can show giant cells but typically <50 years old

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option C)
  • Shows fibrinoid necrosis (pink necrotic material).

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D)
  • AKA leukocytoclastic vasculitis which shows broken white blood cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatty stools complains that her symptoms worsen after a high-fat meal. Reduced activity of pancreatic lipase is suspected. Which of the following ions is most likely to be low in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcium

Explanation:

Pancreatic lipase is an ion-activated enzyme. Its activity is enhanced by adding calcium ions, which is its cofactor.

  • A cofactor is a collective term that includes coenzymes and metal ions
  • Enzymes that require certain metal ions for their activity are called metalloenzymes

Metal-ion (cofactor)

Enzymes

Calcium (Option A)

Lecithinase, lipase

Copper (Option B)

Tyrosinase, cytochrome oxidase, superoxide dismutase

Iron (Option C)

Cytochrome oxidase, catalase, peroxidase, xanthine oxidase

Zinc (Option D)

Carbonic anhydrase, carboxypeptidase, alcohol dehydrogenase

Magnesium

Hexokinase, enolase, glucose-6-phosphatase

Manganese

Phosphoglucomutase, glycosyl transferases

Molybdenum

Xanthine oxidase

questions.text: A 30 y/o female came at 28 wks gestation with 75 gm OGTT report showing 2 hr postprandial (PP) blood glucose value of 170 mg/dl. She was started on dietary modification and exercise. She came for follow up after 2 wks, her FBS is 120 mg/dl & 2hr postprandial is 160 mg/dl.. What is the best treatment for her now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Insulin

Explanation:

Insulin is DOC in Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 75gm 2 hr PP values > 140 suggest GDM, which is uncontrollable on a diet in the given scenario.

Insulin dose:

75gm 2hr PP value (mg/dl)

Insulin dose

Time of day

120-160

4 units

30 min before breakfast

160-200

6 units

30 min before breakfast

>200

8 units

30 min before breakfast

FBS >95

Add 2 units

Before dinner

Continue dietary modification and exercise (Option A) is wrong because once dietary modification and exercise are started, the goals to be attained after 2 weeks are:

  • FBS: 70-95 mg/dL.
  • 1 hour post prandial: <140 mg/dL.
  • 2 hour post prandial: <120 mg/dL.
  • HbA1C: <6%.

This goal is not attained in the given scenario. So, insulin needs to be started.

Glibenclamide and Metformin (Option C&D) are the only oral hypoglycemic agents that can be given in gestational diabetes.

  • They do not cause any teratogenic effect.
  • But first line DOC in GDM is insulin.
  • Other oral hypoglycemic drugs are C/I in GDM.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done to assess infertility, which is given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hysterosalpingography

 

Explanation:

The above image shows hysterosalpingography with normal uterine filling and bilateral patent tubes.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.
  • Timing of HSG: 
    • postmenstrual period
    • follicular phase 
    • usually D6-D11 of mesntrual cycle to avoid it during pregnancy and ensure endomtrium is thin for better visualisation

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into the peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Saline infusion sonography (Option A) or sonosalpingography uses ultrasound to visualise the uterus & tubes while simultaneously injecting saline (not radiocontrast dye) retrograde into the uterus.

Sonoelastography (Option C) is used to assess soft tissue stiffness.

Contrast-enhanced sonography (Option D) combines intravenous contrast injection & ultrasonographic examination.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge for the past week. There is no itching. On examination, there is white discharge coating the vaginal walls. Based on the clinical and microscopic findings (below), what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial Vaginosis

Explanation:

Bacterial Vaginosis is characterised by a thin, greyish-white discharge with the presence of clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria).

Bacterial Vaginosis:

  • The most common cause of vaginal discharge in reproductive-age women. 
  • Caused by: Hemophilus (Gardnerella) vaginalis. Less common: Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides

The image below shows Normal vaginal flora and clue cells in bacterial vaginosis.

Candidiasis (Option A) typically presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and itching.

Trichomoniasis (Option B) presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and often causes itching.

Chlamydia (Option D) is often asymptomatic but can cause mucopurulent discharge and other symptoms.

questions.text: A newborn male presents with severe respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray reveals bowel loops in the left thoracic cavity. Immediate surgical intervention is planned to repair the diaphragmatic defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

Explanation:

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), accounting for about 90% of cases.
  • The clinical presentation typically includes severe respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds in the chest, as seen in this patient.
  • A chest X-ray often reveals bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, and immediate surgical repair is necessary. It is usually found on the left side (80%), but can also occur on the right (15%) or be bilateral (5%).

Morgagni hernia(Option B) is an anterior, usually right-sided defect, often containing colon, and is usually asymptomatic rather than causing neonatal distress.

Rolling hiatus hernia(Option C) occurs in adults when the stomach herniates beside the esophagus, causing reflux or chest pain, not bowel loops in the thorax.

Sliding hiatus hernia(Option D) is also an adult condition where the gastroesophageal junction and stomach slide into the chest, presenting with GERD, not neonatal respiratory distress

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the neonatal conditions described?

 


	Mastitis neonatorum typically presents with bilateral breast swelling
	Vaginal bleeding in neonates usually resolves within 10 days.
	Hymenal tags are usually symptomatic and often require medical treatment.
	Term neonates can lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first week of life.
	Physiologic phimosis usually resolves by age 3-5 and is generally asymptomatic.
	Preterm infants regain their birth weight within 7-10 days.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2, 4, 5

 

Explanation:

  • Neonatal vaginal bleeding is a normal physiological process caused by decreased maternal estrogen and typically resolves within 10 days. (Statement 2)
  • It is normal for term neonates to lose 7-10% of their birth weight in the first week due to loss of extracellular fluid. (Statement 4)
  • Physiologic phimosis is a normal condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted and generally resolves by age 3-5 without causing symptoms. (Statement 5)

 

Condition

Features

Duration

Management

Mastitis Neonatorum
  • Infection of breast tissue related to maternal hormones.
  • Symptoms include unilateral breast swelling, erythema, warmth, tenderness, and possible purulent discharge. (Statement 1)

Resolves within a few weeks

Antibiotics; usually resolve on their own

Vaginal Bleeding
  • Normal due to decreased maternal estrogen.
  • Symptoms include a small amount of blood-tinged discharge or bleeding.

Resolves within 10 days

Medical evaluation if bleeding persists or if other concerns arise

Hymenal Tags

  • Benign remnants of tissue at the vaginal opening.
  • Normal anatomical variations and typically asymptomatic.

Often resolves on its own (Statement 3)

Treatment only if causing discomfort

Physiologic Weight Loss
  • Expected weight loss in the first week of life.
  • Term neonates lose 7-10% of birth weight; preterm infants lose 10-15%.
  • They then gain about 20 to 40 grams daily.
  • This initial weight loss is primarily due to the loss of extracellular fluid, while subsequent weight gain is attributed to increased intracellular water and solids, supporting cellular growth.

Term infants regain within 7-10 days; preterm infants by 10-14 days (Statement 6)

Weight gain of 20-40 grams daily after regaining birth weight.

Physiologic Phimosis
  • A normal condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted due to preputial adhesion.
  • Generally asymptomatic.
  • This differs from pathologic phimosis which involves scarring or inflammation, which may need treatment.

The prepuce becomes retractable by 3 yr of age. Resolves by age 3-5; may take longer

Gentle retraction during bathing to aid in loosening.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the difference between Cost-Benefit Analysis and Cost-Effective Analysis in health management?

choices.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis focuses on the qualitative aspects of health services, while Cost-Effective Analysis focuses on quantitative aspects.
Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effectiveness Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.
Cost-Benefit Analysis is used for planning and budgeting, while Cost-Effective Analysis is used for project scheduling.
Cost-Benefit Analysis evaluates staff performance, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis evaluates patient outcomes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.

 

Explanation:

  • Cost-Benefit Analysis
    • It is a management technique that compares a program's monetary costs with its monetary benefits, expressed in terms of economic gain.
    • It helps determine whether the benefits outweigh the costs in monetary terms.
    • The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms.
  • Cost-Effective Analysis
    • Compares the costs of different interventions to achieve a specific health outcome that is not expressed in monetary terms.
    • It is used to determine the most efficient way to achieve a particular health goal, such as lives saved or cases treated, without converting the outcomes into monetary values.

questions.text: During an autopsy performed on a body 20 hours after death, the pathologist notices small blisters filled with gas on the lower abdomen and thighs. What is the likely cause of these blisters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decomposition due to gas formation
 

Explanation:

Postmortem gas production occurs as a result of bacterial activity, leading to gas accumulation between the epidermis and dermis, which manifests as blisters. This process typically occurs within 18 to 24 hours after death.

 

Gas production:

  • H₂S

  • Phosphorated hydrogen

  • Ammonia

  • CO2,

  • Mercaptans and methane.

 

Post-mortem blister
  • Gas formation in the blood vessels can push blood stained fluid, air, or liquid fat between the epidermis and dermis, leading to the formation of small blisters.
  • Occurs within 18 to 24 hours.
  • Blisters typically appear on the lower surfaces of the trunk and thighs, areas where hypostatic edema causes tissue fluid buildup.

Postmortem gas rigidity

  • It is also known as gas stiffening, this is when the body becomes rigid due to the accumulation of putrefactive gases.

Post mortem purge
  • Gas accumulation in the abdomen forces the diaphragm upwards compressing the lungs and heart, and the bloodstained froth exude from the mouth and nostrils.
  • This can be misinterpreted as bleeding from antemortem injury.

Ante-mortem blister vs Post-mortem blister

Features

Ante-mortem blister

Post-mortem blister

Cause

Burns (Option A)

Decomposition (Option B)

Content

Inflammatory fluid

Gas

Base

Hyperemia

Pale

Vital reaction

Present

Absent

Friction-induced blisters (Option C) arise from skin abrasion, not gas accumulation.

 

Chemical exposure (Option D) may cause blisters, but they would contain inflammatory fluid and not gas.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?




	Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it.
	It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc.
	Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature
	It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early.
	Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this clinical presentation is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Prion Disease or Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE):

  • Prions are proteinaceous infectious particles with no RNA/DNA.
  • Pathogenesis: Misfolding of normal prion protein (PrPc) to form beta-pleated configuration (PrPSc).
  • Histopathology: Spongiform vacuolisation inside the cell.
  • Associated diseases:

Types of prion disease
1. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)

  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

2. Kuru disease

  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

3. Fatal familial insomnia

4. Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on the popliteal surface of his leg that has been present for several months. The ulcer developed at the site of a burn scar he sustained 30 years ago. On examination, the ulcer is painless, slow-growing, and has irregular borders as shown in the image?



What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision followed by flap cover
Wide local excision followed by flap cover and radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wide local excision followed by flap cover

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and image suggest that the patient has Marjolin’s ulcer.
  • Management of Marjolin’s ulcer consists of wide local excision followed by flap cover.
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative endarteritis.

 

Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition
  • Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice
  • Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency department after a fall from height. He developed shortness of breath, tachypnea, and chest pain since the fall. A chest X-ray was taken shown below.



What would be the pathophysiology for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Blunt trauma to the chest

Explanation:

The diagnosis here is of tension pneumothorax as per the history and X-ray image, which is caused due to trauma (blunt or penetrating) to the chest.

  • Pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space, disrupting normal respiratory mechanics.
  • Types:
    • Primary spontaneous pneumothorax: occurs without underlying lung disease, often due to the rupture of apical pleural blebs (Option A). It is more common in males with tall and thin build and smokers, indicating potential subclinical lung pathology.
    • Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax: associated with pre-existing lung conditions (Option B), such as COPD, making it more dangerous due to reduced pulmonary reserve.
    • Traumatic pneumothorax: results from physical injury to the chest, which can be penetrating or non-penetrating. Includes iatrogenic causes (Option D) from medical procedures like transthoracic needle aspiration, thoracocentesis, and insertion of central IV catheters.
    • Tension pneumothorax: a critical condition where air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure, mediastinal shift, and compromised cardiovascular function.

Pathophysiology of pneumothorax:

  • Normally, the pleural space maintains negative pressure relative to atmospheric pressure.
  • When the chest wall expands, the lungs expand outward due to the surface tension between the parietal and visceral pleurae.
  • Lungs have a natural tendency to collapse due to elastic recoil.
  • If there is communication between the alveoli and the pleural space, air enters the pleural cavity, disrupting the negative pressure gradient.
  • Pneumothorax occurs when air fills the pleural space, leading to lung collapse until equilibrium is reached or the rupture is sealed.

Pathophysiology of tension pneumothorax:

  • Impact on lung capacity:
    • As pneumothorax progresses, lung volume decreases, affecting vital capacity and lowering oxygen partial pressure.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Symptoms can range from being asymptomatic to experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath.
    • Patients may exhibit tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia.

questions.text: What is the primary use of the instrument shown in the image given below?

choices.text: To examine the anterior segment of the eye.
To provide a wide-field view of the retina.
To capture high-resolution images of the retina.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To provide a wide-field view of the retina.

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is an Indirect Ophthalmoscope, device used to examine the retina and provide wide-field view of the retina.
  • Clinical use: Best for peripheral retinal examination, e.g., retinal detachment, tears, degenerations.

DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE

INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
  • 15x magnification
  • Virtual image, erect
  • Field of view: 2 DD
  • Monocular
  • Undilated pupil
  • Stereopsis absent
  • 2-3x magnification
  • Real image, inverted
  • Field of view: 8 DD
  • Binocular
  • Dilated pupil
  • Stereopsis present

  • Tonometer: Measures intraocular pressure (Option A)

  • Slit lamp: Examines the anterior segment of the eye (Option B)

  • Fundus camera: Captures high-resolution images of the retina (Option C), but not wide-field like indirect ophthalmoscopy

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of frothy urine, as shown below, and severe generalised oedema. On physical examination, there is marked swelling in the legs and abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal significant proteinuria (3+ on dipstick) and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following findings can be typically observed in this patient?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Red cell casts in the urine

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Hyperlipidemia

 

Explanation:

 

Feature

Nephritic Syndrome

Nephrotic Syndrome

Primary Characteristic

Inflammation of glomeruli

Increased permeability of glomerular basement membrane

Proteinuria

Mild to moderate (< 1 g/day)

Severe (> 3.5 g/day)

Hematuria

Present (visible blood in urine or microscopic hematuria)

Absent or very minimal

Edema

Mild, usually in the face and eyes

Severe, generalised (anasarca)

Blood Pressure

Elevated (Hypertension) (Option D)

Normal or slightly elevated

Serum Albumin

Slightly decreased or normal

Markedly decreased (hypoalbuminemia)

Lipid Levels

Normal or slightly elevated

Hyperlipidemia (Option B)

Renal Function

Often reduced (Azotemia) (Option A)

Usually normal or slightly impaired

Urine findings

Red cell casts (Option C), granular casts

Fatty casts, oval fat bodies & Maltese cross appearance (lipiduria)

Common Causes
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Minimal change disease
  • Membranous nephropathy
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
Symptoms

Oliguria, hematuria (cola-colour urine), hypertension, thrombotic events (Loss of AT III via urine)

Frothy urine, severe oedema

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a painless, bluish, fluctuant and translucent swelling on the lower lip that enlarges with eating or pressure, as shown in the image below. She reports a history of accidentally biting her lip frequently. What histopathological feature would be expected on biopsy of the lesion?

choices.text: Mucin-filled cavity surroundedby granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells.
Proliferation of ductal cells within fibrous connective tissue
Eosinophilic granuloma with multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucin-filled cavity surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells.

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and the image suggest Mucocele, a benign cystic lesion caused by the accumulation of saliva due to trauma or obstruction of the salivary gland duct.
Histologically, it is characterized by a mucin-filled cavity without an epithelial lining (in the extravasation type), surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells, especially macrophages (mucinophages).

  • Mucin-filled cavity incites an inflammatory response, and for the repair of this, the body will start making granulation tissue.
  • A mucocele is an extravasation cyst: Due to excessive lip biting or any trauma, accumulation of lots of saliva and mucus occurs, resulting in a cystic lesion.
  • It does not have any ductal epithelium or ductal lining. A true cyst lined by ductal epithelium.

Treatment:

  • Cryotherapy
  • Laser Treatment
  • Surgical Excision: Removal of the cyst
