questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a large adrenal mass discovered incidentally on imaging. The tumor measures 12 cm and shows irregular borders with central necrosis. She exhibits symptoms of Cushing syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis for this adrenal mass?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adrenocortical Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

Adrenocortical Carcinoma:

  • Characterized by large tumor size (typically >9 cm), irregular borders, and the presence of central necrosis, which matches the clinical scenario.
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma often presents with hormone overproduction and significant local invasion or metastases.
  • Common presentations include Cushing syndrome (M/C) and virilization.
  • Adrenocortical tumor arises from the retroperitoneum.
  • Whenever there is a retroperitoneal mass or pathology involved, the IOC is CECT.
  • CT shows a heterogeneous mass with irregular borders, central necrosis, and invasion of adjacent structures.
  • Possible metastases to lymph nodes, liver, and lungs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with her second child at 38 weeks, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit due to decreased fetal movements. A cardiotocography (CTG) is performed, revealing a baseline fetal heart rate of 130 beats per minute with decelerations. These decelerations vary in shape, timing, and duration, often occurring independently of contractions and sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes. Based on the CTG findings described, what is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution: Umbilical cord compression leads to variable decelerations, which are abrupt, irregular, and not tied to contraction peaks, sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man on long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy for acid reflux undergoes an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy for recurrent epigastric discomfort. The endoscopy reveals smooth-surfaced lesions in the gastric body and fundus. Which statement about these findings is likely correct?

choices.text: PPIs decrease gastrin secretion, reducing the risk of fundic gland polyps
Fundic gland polyps are commonly associated with H. pylori infection.
Composed of cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells.
Sporadic fundic gland polyps carry a significant risk of neoplasia.

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of smooth-surfaced lesions in the gastric body and fundus and a history of long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy suggest Fundic gland polyps.

  • Histologically, they are characterised by irregular, cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells, with minimal inflammation. (Option C)

PPIs decrease gastrin secretion, reducing the risk of fundic gland polyps (Option A): Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) inhibit acid production, leading to increased gastrin secretion, which can contribute to the growth of fundic gland polyps.

Fundic gland polyps are commonly associated with H. pylori infection (Option B): They are primarily associated with conditions such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is due to APC gene mutation.

Sporadic fundic gland polyps carry a significant risk of neoplasia(Option D): Sporadic fundic gland polyps usually have no significant neoplastic risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing evaluation for palpitations. ECG reveals a supraventricular tachycardia with HR of 190/min. An echocardiogram reveals hypertrophy of the right ventricle and enlargement of the right ventricular outflow tract. Which structure separates the inflow and outflow tracts in the right ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Supraventricular crest

Explanation:

The supraventricular crest is located within the right ventricle and separates the inflow tract, which carries blood from the right atrium through the tricuspid valve, from the outflow tract, which directs blood into the pulmonary trunk.

  • It is a thick, muscular “U” shaped structure extending from the interventricular septum to the anterolateral wall of the right ventricle.
  • The crest provides the main attachment for the anterosuperior leaflet of the tricuspid valve.
  • The septal limb of the crest is connected to the septal limbs of the septomarginal trabeculation (moderator band).

    

Crista terminalis (Option A)

  • Located in the right atrium - separates the smooth and rough parts of the atrium, not the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts.

 

The moderator band (Option C) facilitates conduction in the right ventricle and contains the right bundle branch (RBB).

  • Helps prevent overdistension of the right ventricle during systole by acting as a stabilizing structure. It does not separate the inflow and outflow regions.

 

Interventricular septum (Option D) separates the left and right ventricles but does not partition the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete presents with exercise intolerance and muscle fatigue, particularly during high-intensity training. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency in the enzyme that facilitates the transfer of electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial FADH2 in skeletal muscle. Which shuttle system is likely impaired in this athlete?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Glycerol phosphate shuttle

The glycerol phosphate shuttle, present in white muscle fibers and neurons, specifically transfers electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial FADH2

Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane. The ADP-ATP translocase in the inner mitochondrial membrane exports ATP to the cytosol and imports ADP into the mitochondria.. Atractyloside inhibits this transport process.
  • Function:
    • It plays a crucial role in oxidative phosphorylation.
    • Oxidation, which involves the loss of electrons, is central to this process and drives ATP synthesis
  • Shuttles:
    • NADH Shuttles: Glycolysis, which occurs in the cytoplasm, generates 2 NADH molecules per glucose molecule.
    • NADH cannot directly cross the mitochondrial membrane; it requires shuttles for transport.
    • There are two main shuttle systems: the malate-aspartate shuttle (Image 1) and the glycerol phosphate shuttle (Image 2), which facilitate NADH transport across the mitochondrial membrane

 

 

 

Property

Malate Shuttle (Option A ruled out)

Glycerol Phosphate Shuttle

Location

 Present in most cells except white muscle fibers and neurons.

White muscle fibers and neurons

Energy

 "No net ATP loss" → Consumes 2 ATP per glucose molecule.

Loss of 2 ATPs per glucose molecule

Electron Carrier

 Electron Carrier: Transfers electrons to mitochondrial NADH, maintaining cytosolic NAD+/NADH balance.

Transfers electrons to mitochondrial FADH2

Enzymes

 Cytoplasmic and mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.

Cytoplasmic & mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase

Citrate shuttle (Option C) transports acetyl-CoA from the mitochondria to the cytosol for fatty acid synthesis, not for transferring electrons from NADH to FADH2.

The aspartate shuttle (Option D), also known as the malate-aspartate shuttle, is involved in transferring electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial NADH.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male recently began treatment for painless lesions in his palms and soles and presented to the emergency department with fever, chills, and myalgias. These symptoms developed a few hours after receiving his first dose of benzathine penicillin G. On examination, he appears flushed (image) with tachycardia and hypotension. Based on the findings, match the most likely diagnosis and management of this condition.




	
		
			
			1. Anaphylactic reaction
			
			
			A. Continue medication and start antipyretics
			
		
		
			
			2. Serum Sickness
			
			
			B. Administer epinephrine
			
		
		
			
			3. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction
			
			
			C. Discontinue and switch to alternate medication
			
		
		
			
			4. Steven-Johnson syndrome
			
			
			D. Discontinue medication and admit to ICU
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 3 and A

Explanation:

This patient is experiencing a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, a typical response to antibiotic treatment for syphilis, characterised by fever, chills, myalgias and worsening of syphilitic rash, which usually resolves within 24 hours without discontinuing penicillin therapy. Supportive treatment includes antipyretics and corticosteroids.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:

  • Host reaction is due to the release of spirochetal proteins (hypersensitivity).
  • Common in patients treated for secondary syphilis, leptospirosis, and Lyme disease.
  • Symptoms:
    • Chills, fever, headache, and myalgias occur several hours after the first dose.
    • It is worsening of syphilitic rash (image) and lymphadenopathy.
  • Management:
    • Self-limited: resolves within 24 hours.
    • Supportive care: Antipyretics, hydration and corticosteroids.
    • Continue penicillin therapy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with progressive bowing of the legs and tenderness in the lower limbs. The child has a history of limited outdoor play and a diet low in dairy products. Which of the following limb deformities is most likely present in this child?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a child with classic signs of Rickets associated with vitamin D deficiency. This condition results in leg deformities in children with inadequate sun exposure and dietary intake of vitamin D.

Clinical manifestations of Vitamin D deficiency

Rickets (Option A)
  • Occurs in children.
  • Inadequate bone mineralization due to poor calcium absorption.
  • Bones become soft and weak, leading to deformities under pressure.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Muscle weakness
    • Delayed walking
    • Skeletal deformities - "pigeon chest" (pectus carinatum) and genu varus (bowed legs), Genu valgum, windswept deformity.
    • Rickety rosary

Osteomalacia (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs in adults.
  • Demineralization of bone, making them weak and prone to fractures.
  • Risk factors: limited sun exposure, women after multiple pregnancies.

Renal osteodystrophy

Long-standing secondary hyperparathyroidism can result in renal osteodystrophy, increasing the risk of pathological fractures.

 

Blount’s disease (Option B) (tibia vara) is an acquired genu varus deformity typically developing later in childhood, while nutritional rickets, caused by vitamin D deficiency from poor diet and limited sun exposure, is more likely in this young child.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) is unlikely because it is a genetic disorder affecting collagen synthesis, leading to brittle bones and frequent fractures from birth, rather than the progressive bowing of the legs seen in nutritional rickets.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity.



Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

choices.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification.

Explanation:

Gradual, progressive loss of vision along with improvement in near vision (referred to as “second sight”), combined with characteristic slit-lamp findings, is suggestive of Nuclear Cataract, for which phacoemulsification is the treatment of choice.

  • Management:
    • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
    • Cataract surgeries:
      • ICCE (not preferred now)
      • ECCE
      • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
      • Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
    • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months (Option A) would not address the cataract directly and would not improve the visual acuity.

Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months (Option B): The use of topical corticosteroids after cataract surgery reduces postoperative noninfectious inflammation but it is not used as the treatment for nuclear cataract.

Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses (Option D): Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses are indicated for early-stage keratoconus with astigmatism.

questions.text: A 48-year-old multiparous woman with a complete family came to the OPD with complaints of painful menstruation and lower pelvic pain for the past 6 months. Investigations led to a diagnosis of adenomyosis. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

In a multiparous woman with a complete family, the definitive treatment for adenomyosis is a Total hysterectomy.

Medical Methods

Surgical Methods
  • Combined OCPs and progestin-only regimens: Improves dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia (Option A)
  • NSAIDs: For pain and menorrhagia.
  • LNG-IUS: Reduce Menorrhagia
  • GnRH agonists: For adenomyosis-related sub-fertility or as pre-surgical relief.
  • Danazol: For menorrhagia and pain.
  • Conservative surgery: Preserves fertility for women desiring children. It includes:
    • Adenomyomectomy: Difficulty in completely removing adenomyoma ➜ Risk of recurrence. (Option C)
    • Uterine mass reduction (laparotomy or laparoscopy)
    • Uterine artery embolisation (UAE): To relieve symptoms) (Option D)
  • Definitive surgery: Total Hysterectomy (Option B)

questions.text: A 22-year-old female who is an aspiring model presents with complaints of gastrointestinal discomfort and concerns about her weight. Since beginning her modeling career, she has become increasingly anxious about her body image, feeling pressure to maintain a slim figure to secure modeling opportunities. Recently, she has also started binge eating high-calorie foods during stressful periods, followed by feelings of guilt. To counteract this, she regularly uses over-the-counter laxatives, believing they help her feel thinner. Her BMI is measured at 17 kg/m² and her heart rate is 70 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anorexia with purging

Explanation:

  • This patient is best diagnosed as anorexia (purging type).
    • She exhibits significant weight control behaviors, including binge eating followed by laxative use, while also maintaining a low BMI.
    • This aligns with the criteria for anorexia nervosa, particularly the binge-eating/purging type, where she engages in binge eating and compensatory behaviors such as purging (laxative use here) to manage her weight.

 

Type of Anorexia Nervosa

Characteristics

Binge-Eating/Purging type
  • Recurring purging behaviors (e.g., laxative, diuretic abuse, self-induced vomiting)
  • Episodes of binge eating
  • Occurs at least once a week over the last 3 months

Restricting type
  • Primary behaviors include dieting, fasting, and/or excessive exercise
  • No recurring purging behaviors or binge eating over the last 3 months

 

Anorexia with dietary restriction (Option A): While this option describes a subtype of anorexia, it specifically refers to individuals who do not engage in binge eating or purging behaviors.

Bulimia with purging (Option C): Bulimia nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors (like purging) but typically occurs in individuals with a normal or higher weight.

Binge Eating Disorder (Option D): This is defined by recurrent episodes of binge eating without compensatory behaviors. This patient does engage in binge eating, but she also uses laxatives to prevent weight gain.

questions.text: What is the quality control agent used in the shown method of disinfection?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Bacillus pumilus

 

Explanation:

Shown method (in the image) is disinfection by Ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Quality control agent used for Radiation is Bacillus pumilus.


 

Radiation:

Ionising

Features:

  • High penetration power
  • Sporicidal action +
  • Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat)
  • Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters
  • Catgut sutures - Gamma (γ) rays

Non-ionising

Features:

  • Low penetration power
  • Only bactericidal action +
  • Examples: UV rays, infrared rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters

Mechanism of action
  • DNA damage by Dimer formation

Quality control agent

  • Bacillus pumilus (Option C)

 

Other options:

Bacillus atrophaeus niger (Option A): used for Hot air oven

 

Bacillus atrophaeus globigii (Option B): used for Ethylene oxide (Gas plasma)

 

Geobacillus stearothermophilus (Option D): used for Autoclave

questions.text: A patient reports an unusual sensitivity to temperature changes, and you suspect a disorder related to thermoreceptor function. Which of the following statements accurately describes the nerve fibers involved in transmitting signals from thermoreceptors?

choices.text: Cold receptors: myelinated type C fibers
Warmth receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers
Cold receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers
Warmth receptors: myelinated type Aβ fibers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cold receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers

 

Explanation:

Cold receptors primarily use small, myelinated type Aδ fibers to transmit signals, which conduct at a speed of approximately 20 m/sec.

Types of Thermoreceptors

Type

Location

Transmission Pathway

Speed

Cold Receptors

(Option C)

Under the skin at spots

Type Aδ fibers (myelinated), some Type C fibers (unmyelinated) (Option A ruled out)

~20 m/sec (Aδ fibers)

Warmth Receptors
(Option B&D Ruled out)

Under the skin at spots

Unmyelinated Type C fibers

0.4-2 m/sec

The body has 3 - 10 times more cold spots (lips >>fingers) than warmth spots

Nocireceptors / Pain receptors are stimulated only in extreme degrees of cold or heat and are responsible along with the cold and warmth receptors for freezing cold and burning hot sensations.

Stimulation of Thermal Receptors

Type of Nerve Fiber

Temperature Range

Cold Receptors

10-40°C (peak ~24°C)

Warmth Receptors

>30°C (fade ~49°C)

Cold Pain Fibers

Very cold temperatures

Heat Pain Fibers

Start ~45°C

Thermal Signal Pathway

  • Transmitted in parallel pathways with pain signals.
  • Signals travel in the tract of Lissauer and terminate in laminae I, II, and III of dorsal horns.
  • Processed signals by cord neurons cross to the opposite anterolateral sensory tract and terminate in both brain stem's reticular areas and the thalamus's ventrobasal complex.
  • Removal of cortical postcentral gyrus reduces, but does not eliminate, temperature distinction ability.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with intense pain in his left leg along with the following lesion. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arterial ulcer

 

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis of the given ulcer is Arterial ulcer.
  • It occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium sized arteries leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.
  • They may present as painful erosions, located between the toes, dorsum of feet, on the shin and around malleoli.
  • Characteristic features of arterial ulcers:
    • Punched-out edges are seen
    • It is intensely painful
    • Distal pulses are not palpable
    • Thin, shiny skin is seen
    • Loss of hair in the area
    • Brittle nails are seen

 

 

Venous ulcer

(Option B)

Arterial ulcer

(Option C)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

(Option D)

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, distal pulses are not palpable, associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary protein responsible for binding and transporting free heme in the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemopexin

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hemopexin is a primary protein that is responsible for binding and transporting free heme in the bloodstream.
  • When RBC undergoes hemolysis, heme is released into the blood.
  • Free heme is potentially toxic due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species and cause oxidative damage.
  • Hemopexin binds to free heme with high affinity, facilitating safe transport of the liver for degradation and prevention of toxicity (option D).

 

Haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin, but not free heme (Option A)

 

Albumin maintains osmotic pressure and serves as a carrier protein for various substances, including hormones, fatty acids, and drugs, but is not a carrier of heme (Option B)

 

Transferrin is responsible for transfer of iron in the bloodstream. (Option C)

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) from diabetic nephropathy has been on hemodialysis for three years. She reports persistent back pain and changes in posture. An X-ray shows specific findings, shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Explanation:

The scenario depicts a case of Renal osteodystrophy (Secondary Hyperparathyroidism), with the X-ray showing Rugger jersey spine.

 

Radiological features of Hyperparathyroidism
  • Subperiosteal resorption usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side, leading to a concavity of bone (the earliest bone change). 

 
  • The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull). 

 
  • Brown tumor or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions resulting from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can cause bone expansion, often accompanied by hemorrhage and granulation tissue (more common in primary hyperparathyroidism).



 
  • Rugger jersey spine: Characterized by alternating black and white striations, with sclerosed white end plates and black vertebral bodies; commonly seen in renal osteodystrophy (secondary hyperparathyroidism). 

 

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A) shows sacroiliac joint erosions, bamboo spine and dagger sign.

 



 

Osteoporosis (Option C)  show osteopenia and biconcave vertebrae, often referred to as codfish or fish-mouth vertebrae. 


 

Osteoblastic metastases (Option D)  is characterised by increased density and sclerosis, commonly referred to as "ivory vertebra."

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male taking propranolol presents to a cardiologist with worsening chest pain.The cardiologist discusses the option of second-line antianginal drugs to manage his symptoms better. Which of the following statements is correct?


	Ranolazine acts on sodium channels and is primarily used to treat acute angina.
	Fasudil acts as a Rho kinase inhibitor used in chronic angina.
	Trimetazidine inhibits thiolase to shift fuel metabolism from glucose to fatty acids.
	Ivabradine reduces heart rate by selectively inhibiting the funny current in the sinoatrial node.
	Ranolazine is contraindicated in patients with existing diabetes mellitus.
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: A) 2 and 4

Explanation:

Second-line anti-anginal drugs (Mnemonic- No DRIFT):

  • Nicorandil
  • Dipyridamole
  • Ranolazine
  • Ivabradine
  • Fasudil.
  • Trimetazidine

Drugs

Ranolazine

Fasudil

Trimetazidine

Ivabradine

Target

Blocks late Na channels

Rho kinase inhibitor (Rock enzyme)

Partial fatty acid oxidation (PFOX) inhibitor

Inhibit funny current channels in the SA node.

MOA

↓ Myocardial contractility and O2 demand.

Coronary artery dilatation.

Inhibit the thiolase enzyme and shift the fuel metabolism from fatty acids to glucose.

Reduce heart rate and O2 demand.

Use

1. Chronic stable angina

2. Ventricular tachycardia

3. Improves glycemic control (lower HbA1c and increased insulin)

Chronic vasospastic angina

Second-line anti-anginal drug

1. Chronic stable angina

2. Chronic heart failure

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct?

choices.text: It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.
Results in minimal visible injuries on the neck.
Key postmortem findings include only superficial bruises and no internal injuries.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.

 

Explanation:

The given image describes Throttling (manual strangulation).

  • Throttling results in death through mechanisms like asphyxia (obstruction of the airway) and vagal inhibition (pressure on the carotid sinus leading to a drop in heart rate and blood pressure).
  • The requirement of applying pressure for a minimum of 2 minutes to cause death is consistent with the physiological effects of throttling.

 

Throttling (Manual Strangulation):

  • Definition: A method of strangulation where the assailant compresses the victim's neck with their hands.
  • Mechanisms of Death:
    • Asphyxia: Obstruction of the airway due to neck pressure.
    • Cerebral Anoxia: Restricted blood flow to the brain due to pressure on blood vessels, leading to potential brain damage.
    • Vagal Inhibition: Stimulation of the vagus nerve can cause a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure, potentially resulting in cardiac arrest.
  • Fatality Requirement: Sustained pressure for at least 2 minutes is typically required for lethality.

Postmortem Findings:

 

Examination Type

Findings

External Examination

(Option B ruled out)
  • Bruises and Abrasions: On the front and sides of the neck.
  • Signs of Asphyxia: Cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu's spots, bleeding from nose and ears.
  • Injuries on Other Body Parts: Additional signs of violence (abrasions, bruises, scratches).

Internal Examination (Option C ruled out)
  • Haemorrhages: In subcutaneous tissues under bruises.
  • Muscle Damage: Tears or lacerations in neck muscles.
  • Hyoid Bone Fracture: Significant diagnostic indicator, typically from inward compression.
  • Laryngeal and Tracheal Damage: Fractures of thyroid and potentially cricoid cartilages.
  • Haemorrhages in Mouth/Throat: Bruising and lacerations on the tongue, haemorrhages in mucous membranes.

 

Medico-legal Questions:

  • Determining Manner of Death:
    • Suicidal Throttling: Considered impossible; hands would relax upon unconsciousness. (Option D ruled out)
    • Homicidal Throttling: Presumed unless proven otherwise; common in homicides, especially involving vulnerable victims.
    • Accidental Throttling: Rare, may occur during playful or affectionate contact.

questions.text: Which part of the nephron is affected in Gordon syndrome?

choices.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Distal convoluted tubule

Explanation:

Gordon syndrome affects DCT.  It is caused by mutations that increase sodium-chloride reabsorption via the NCC (Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter) in the DCT. this leads to low alosterone levels and hence it is also called Pseudohypoaldosteronism type IIA.  It leads to:

  1. Hypertension (due to volume expansion)

  2. Hyperkalemia (due to reduced potassium excretion)

  3. Metabolic acidosis

  4. Low renin and aldosterone levels

It is the opposite phenotype of Gitelman syndrome, which also involves the DCT but causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

Inheritance

Autosomal dominant (mostly)

Pathogenesis

Mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 genes result in abnormalities in serine/threonine kinases that dysregulate the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal nephron (Option A). This leads to increased sodium and chloride reabsorption, causing extracellular volume expansion and subsequent hypertension.

Clinical Presentation

Non-specific symptoms like muscle weakness, fatigue, hypertension (not always)

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Low or low-normal plasma renin activity
  • Low serum aldosterone levels (relative to hyperkalemia)
  • Normal kidney function/normal glomerular filtration

Management
  • Correction of electrolyte abnormalities
  • Salt restriction
  • Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: During a disaster, a patient is suffering from a closed femur fracture with stable vital signs and another patient with a penetrating chest wound with respiratory distress. Which of the following are the colour coding given to the patients respectively based on triage principle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Yellow and Red
 

Explanation:
The first patient, with a closed femur fracture and stable vitals, is triaged as YELLOW, requiring assistance within 24 hours. The second patient, in respiratory distress, necessitates immediate resuscitation and is triaged as RED.

Triage:

During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.

During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

  1. Name
  2. Age
  3. Place of origin
  4. Triage category
  5. Diagnosis and
  6. Initial treatment.

Color coding in triage:

 

Types of triage:

Reverse triage:

  • Used in surge (bed scarcity) and during wars.
  • Priority: Green→Yellow→Red.

Simple triage and Rapid Treatment (START):

  • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.
  • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman presents with progressive muscle weakness and a distinctive rash on her eyelids and knuckles. She also exhibits a rash like in the given image. She reports difficulty swallowing and has experienced some joint pain. Which of the following statements about this patient's condition is FALSE?

choices.text: The rash may precede or accompany the muscle weakness.
Weakness is typically asymmetric, affecting distal muscles more than proximal.
Nail bed telangiectasias are a common finding.
Patients may present with only a rash and no muscle weakness.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Weakness is typically asymmetric, affecting distal muscles more than proximal.

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms, such as progressive muscle weakness and distinctive rashes, including the heliotrope rash on the eyelids and the V-sign on the anterior neck and chest, as shown in the image, are characteristic of dermatomyositis. The presence of dysphagia further supports this diagnosis.
  • Dermatomyositis typically presents with symmetric proximal weakness rather than asymmetric distal weakness.
  • Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory myopathy characterized by chronic muscle inflammation and weakness. A key feature is a skin rash that often precedes or accompanies the progressive muscle weakness.

Clinical Features of Dermatomyositis

  • Weakness: Symmetric, proximal greater than distal.
  • Rash: Characteristic rashes include:
    • Heliotrope rash: Erythematous eyelid discolouration with periorbital edema.
    • Gottron sign: Erythematous rash over extensor surfaces (knuckles, elbows, knees, ankles).
    • Gottron papules: Raised erythematous rash over knuckles.
    • V-sign: Rash on sun-exposed anterior neck and chest.
    • Shawl sign: Rash over the back of the neck and shoulders.
    • Nail bed telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries at nail beds. (Option C ruled out)
    • Subcutaneous calcium deposits.
  • Weakness and rash can appear together or be separated by months. (Option A ruled out)
  • Some patients may present with only a rash (amyopathic DM), while others may show mainly weakness. (Option D ruled out)
  • Additional Symptoms: Myalgias, arthralgias, dysphagia, and dysarthria.
  • Skin symptoms significantly affect overall life quality; pruritus can be debilitating.
  • Pulmonary Issues: Dyspnea from ventilatory muscle weakness or intrinsic lung problems (interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis).
  • Malignancy Risk: Higher risk (~15%) in adult-onset cases within the first 2–3 years.

Heliotrope rash
 

Gottron’s Papules

Shawl sign

V Sign

questions.text: Schematic diagram of sarcomere is given below. Red coloured structure is myosin with heads. Based on the length-tension relationship of muscle fibres, between which sarcomere length does the sarcomere allow optimal muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B to C

Explanation:

When the sarcomere is at perfect length—about 2.2 micrometres—the actin and myosin overlap perfectly, allowing the muscle to contract optimally.

The sarcomere maintains full tension as it shortens from 2.2 micrometres to 2 micrometres, i.e., from length B to C.

  • Sarcomeres are units in the muscles composed of actin and myosin filaments.
  • The amount of force or tension a muscle generates depends on the sarcomere's length.

  • Length A: Actin and myosin do not overlap; thus, muscle cannot generate tension. It occurs when the muscle is very stretched out.
  • Length B: Actin and myosin start to overlap, thus generating tension - maximum tension occurs when the overlap is just right - 2.2 micrometre
  • Length C: Sarcomere maintains full tension as it shortens from 2.2 micrometre to 2 micrometres
  • Length D: When the sarcomere length is shorter than 2 micrometres, the actin filaments overlap, thus reducing tension.
  • At about 1.65 micrometres, the sarcomere (Z disks) ends bump into the ends of the myosin filaments.
  • Further shortening crumples the myosin filaments, and tension drops to zero.
  • Thus,
    • Length A to B: Muscle cannot generate any tension (Option A ruled out)
    • Length B to C: Muscle starts generating tension, and the maximum is at 2.2 micrometres (Option B)
    • Length C to D: Muscle can maintain full tension, and it allows optimum muscle contraction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of feeling excessively tired. He gives a history of repeated blood transfusions. A skull radiograph revealed the following findings.



Which of the following is the most probable cause of this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased marrow hyperplasia

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above radiological image of the “hair on end" appearance, along with the history of multiple blood transfusions, indicates the diagnosis of Thalassemia.
  • The characteristic radiological appearance is due to increased marrow hyperplasia, a response to chronic anemia in thalassemia, which leads to diploic space widening in the skull.
  • Thalassemias are hemoglobinopathies that occur due to mutations in the globin chain.
  • Complications: “Hair on end" appearance of skull, maxillary bone overgrowth, compression fractures

 

Increased osteoclastic activity (Option A) leads to bone resorption rather than the formation of new bone.

 

Decreased bone remodeling (Option C) would result in reduced bone turnover, leading to brittle bones.

 

Increased osteoblastic activity (Option D): While increased osteoblastic activity could lead to increased bone formation, the "hair-on-end" appearance is specifically due to the hyperplasia of marrow, not just general osteoblastic activity.

questions.text: According to DAS guidelines, how will you manage a patient who is undergoing an elective cholecystectomy, if the below shown device fails to ventilate the patient?

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with 2-person technique

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bag and mask ventilation with 2-person technique

Explanation:

The image is a Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) - a supraglottic airway device (SAD).

Bag and mask ventilation with a 2-person technique is performed if SAD fails to ventilate

  • Continue the surgery with LMA practiced when normal intubation failed with a laryngoscope (Option B)
  • Invasive airway management is performed when the Bag and mask ventilation is unsuccessful (Option C)

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing technique used in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Interrupted sutures

 

Explanation:

  • Each stitch is a separate piece of suture material, allowing for individual control over each stitch.
  • Therefore, the suturing technique depicted in the given image is that of interrupted sutures.

Suturing Techniques:

 

Technique

Image

Description

Suture Placement

Interrupted Sutures

(Option A)

Needle inserted at 90-degree angle, passed through both sides of wound

Distance = tissue thickness, each suture twice as far from edge as previous

Continuous Sutures

(Option B ruled out)

Continuous placement after initial start, with suture appearing diagonal

Maintain proper tension, secure end with Aberdeen knot or final suture loop

Mattress Sutures

(Option C ruled out)

Vertical or horizontal, used to align wound edges

Passed through both sides, either vertically or horizontally

Subcuticular Sutures

(Option D ruled out)

Aesthetic closure with small bites of tissue, edges easily approximated

Absorbable or non-absorbable, secured with collar and bead or buried knot

questions.text: A 30 y/o contact lens wearer presents with very severe eye pain, blurred vision, and discomfort in his right eye. O/E, the following corneal finding is noted. Based on the image and the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acanthamoeba Keratitis

Explanations:

  • The above clinical features and examination findings are suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that is often out of proportion to the clinical findings, along with features such as perineural infiltrates and, in advanced cases, ring-shaped abscesses.

  • Symptoms:
    • Blurred Vision
    • Discomfort
    • Severe Pain
  • Ring lesion indicates advanced stage of the disease.

 

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A) typically presents with dendritic ulcers and less severe pain relative to Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis (Option B) usually presents with feathery-edged infiltrates and satellite lesions.

Bacterial Keratitis (Option D) typically presents with a more prominent purulent discharge and a dense, localized infiltrate.

questions.text: A 62 year old patient presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and facial droop. Neurological examination reveals upper motor neuron signs with weakness in both the arm and leg on the right side. MRI confirms an infarct in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory involving the genu of the internal capsule. Which of the following tracts passes through the genu?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Corticobulbar tract

 

Explanation:

  • The genu of the internal capsule contains the corticobulbar tract (corticonuclear tract), which is responsible for motor control of the cranial nerves, especially facial movements.
  • Damage here can result in facial weakness, as seen in the patient.

Blood Supply of the Internal Capsule:

Artery

Supplies

Tracts Affected in Lesions

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)
  • The ventral part of the anterior limb

Corticopontine tract affecting communication between cortex and cerebellum

Heubner's Artery
  • Ventral anterior limb

Corticopontine and frontopontine tracts: Impaired voluntary movements.

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • Parts of the anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb

Corticobulbar tract (genu): Facial muscle weakness and motor deficits in cranial nerves

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral limb weakness or paralysis (Option B)

Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

-

Varies depending on perforator origin, affecting similar tracts as MCA and AChA supplies

Anterior Choroidal Artery (AChA)
  • Ventral posterior limb
  • Retro-lenticular 
  • Sub-lenticular portions

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral motor deficits

Optic radiations (retro-lenticular part): Visual field defects

Auditory radiations (sub lenticular part): Auditory processing issues

 

Spinothalamic tract (Option C):

  • This tract is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the body to the brain.
  • It does not pass through the genu of the internal capsule.

Medial lemniscus (Option D):

  • This tract carries proprioception and vibration sense from the body to the brain, passing through the brainstem, not the genu of the internal capsule.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with severe renal artery stenosis is admitted for hypertension management. The physician decides to prescribe a medication to control the blood pressure but must avoid drugs that could adversely affect kidney function due to the existing renal impairment. Which drug is contraindicated in this patient due to the risk of worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor
 

Explanation

 

Renal artery stenosis reduces blood flow to the affected kidney, decreasing renal perfusion pressure. This decrease is perceived as threatening blood pressure homeostasis, triggering a cascade of events within the renin-angiotensin system.

Increased angiotensin II levels help maintain GFR by constricting the efferent arteriole, preserving glomerular pressure despite reduced renal blood flow.

ACE Inhibitors block the conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II, disrupting the compensatory mechanism and potentially causing a significant drop in GFR.

ACE inhibitors can lead to acute renal failure in renal artery stenosis by reducing protective efferent arteriole constriction and worsening GFR.

 

Beta-blockers (Option A) reduce blood pressure by decreasing heart rate and cardiac output. They do not directly affect renal perfusion or glomerular filtration rate.

 

Calcium channel blockers (Option C) reduce blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels, including the arterioles. They do not significantly impair renal perfusion and are generally safe in patients with renal artery stenosis.

 

Diuretics (Option D) help reduce blood pressure by increasing urine production and reducing fluid volume. While they must be used cautiously to avoid dehydration, they do not directly impair renal perfusion or GFR like ACE inhibitors.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old patient presents with painless redness of the eye. The ophthalmologist performed a diagnostic test using 2.5% phenylephrine, and no change was noticed. When 10% phenylephrine is used, the following change occurs. What is the most likely diagnosis?


	Before application of 10% phenylephrine:





	After application of 10% phenylephrine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Episcleritis

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has painless redness of the eye which blanches (as shown in the image) following the application of 10% phenylephrine, suggesting episcleritis.

Principle of Phenylephrine Test

  • Phenylephrine causes vasoconstriction of superficial conjunctival vessels.

  • Deeper episcleral or scleral vessels do not respond to phenylephrine.

Vascular plexuses

Locations of Vessels

Clinical correlation.

Conjunctival plexus

Most superficial
  • Congested in conjunctivitis.
  • Blanched with 2.5% phenylephrine

Superficial episcleral plexus
  • Lies at the level of Tenon's capsule.
  • Radial configuration.
  • Congested in episcleritis.
  • Blanching does not occur with 2.5%, but occurs with 10%

Deep vascular plexus
  • Lies deep to the Tenon's capsule and over the sclera.
  • Criss-cross pattern.
  • Congested in scleritis.
  • Does not blanch even with 10% phenylephrine.

 

Uveitis (Option D) is associated with pain, redness, photophobia, and excess lacrimation, with associated findings in slit lamp examination, which are not seen here.

questions.text:
The patient's blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Four different sphygmomanometers measure his BP, each with 3 readings. Match the sphygmomanometers with their respective accuracy and precision parameters.

 


	
		
			
			Sphygmomanometer readings
			
			
			Accuracy and Precision parameters
			
		
		
			
			1. 120/80, 120/80, 120/80
			
			
			a. Precise but inaccurate
			
		
		
			
			2. 140/96, 108/62, 96/82
			
			
			b. Imprecise but accurate
			
		
		
			
			3. 140/96, 140/96, 140/96
			
			
			c. Precise and accurate
			
		
		
			
			4. 122/82, 120/80, 118/78
			
			
			d. Imprecise and inaccurate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

Explanation:

 

A game of darts can help one understand precision and accuracy. Let the centre point be the true value or gold standard value.

  • Accuracy: Closeness to true value.
  • Precision: Findings are replicable.

 

Accurate & precise

Not accurate & precise

Accurate & not precise

Not accurate & not precise

Every line hits the central point exactly at the gold standard value.

The same finding is seen, but far from the true value; it is inaccurate.

It is accurate as the result is closer to the true value in the first circle; it is not precise.

It is not precise or accurate.

Correct Matching:

120/80, 120/80, 120/80 - c) Precise and accurate.
This set of readings consistently measures 120/80 mm Hg, indicating both precision (reproducibility of measurements) and accuracy (close to the true value).

140/96, 108/62, 96/82 - d) Imprecise and inaccurate.
These readings vary significantly (140/96, 108/62, 96/82), indicating both lack of precision (inconsistent measurements) and accuracy (not close to the true value).

140/96, 140/96, 140/96 - a) Precise but inaccurate.
Readings are consistent (140/96 each time), indicating precision (reproducibility) but they are consistently incorrect, hence inaccurate.

122/82, 120/80, 118/78 - b) Imprecise but accurate.
The readings vary slightly (122/82, 120/80, 118/78), indicating lack of precision (slightly inconsistent measurements), but they are close to the true value (accurate).

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the role of the Sexual Assault Forensic Examination (rape kit) concerning victim care?

choices.text: The examination focuses solely on collecting evidence and does not provide medical treatment.
The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their health needs.
The examination requires all victims to file a police report and then provides resources for their health needs.
The examination is primarily for legal purposes and does not address the psychological well-being of the victim.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their health needs.

 

Explanation:

The Sexual Assault Forensic Examination is designed not only to collect evidence but also to ensure that victims receive necessary medical treatment, addressing both physical health and immediate care needs.

Sexual Assault Forensic Examination Kit (also known as a rape kit)

  • Purpose: Preserves DNA evidence from the body, clothes, or personal items after a sexual assault and provides important medical care.
  • No Requirement to Report: Victims can undergo an exam without reporting the crime, allowing evidence to be stored in case of later reporting. (Option C ruled out)
  • Contents: The kit includes items like swabs, bags, documentation forms, and instructions for evidence collection (contents may vary by location).
  • Exam Procedure: Typically includes immediate medical care, health history review, head-to-toe examination, evidence collection (e.g., DNA, blood, hair samples), and documentation of injuries.
  • Follow-Up Care: Includes treatment for STIs, emergency contraception, and resources for further medical support.
  • Examiners: These are conducted by trained professionals like Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners (SANEs) or Sexual Assault Forensic Examiners (SAFEs).
  • Benefits: Helps in potential prosecution, connects DNA to databases for future investigations, and addresses physical health needs after an assault.

The examination focuses solely on collecting evidence and does not provide medical treatment (Option A): This option is incorrect. While evidence collection is a key component, the Sexual Assault Forensic Examination also includes important medical care, such as treating injuries and providing preventive measures for STIs and emergency contraception.

The examination is primarily for legal purposes and does not address the psychological well-being of the victim (Option D): Sexual Assault Forensic Examination does take into account the psychological well-being of the victim, often providing access to mental health resources and support during and after the examination.

questions.text: Under which initiative in India are children screened for common health conditions such as birth defects, deficiencies, developmental delays, and diseases up to the age of 18 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Explanation:

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health

  • Comprehensive health care for children aged from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays.
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost including surgeries.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with six months of dysphagia, regurgitation, and a feeling of food getting stuck, often coughing while eating. A barium swallow study shows specific findings on the radiograph. Which muscle pairs define the anatomical boundaries of the observed dehiscence?

choices.text: Inferior constrictor along with upper esophageal muscle fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario and barium swallow findings suggest Zenker’s diverticulum, an outpouching occurring at a site known as Killian’s Dehiscence (often referred to as the "gateway of tears").
  • This space is formed by the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle: the thyropharyngeus (oblique fibres) and the cricopharyngeus (transverse fibres). This arrangement creates a triangular gap known as Killian’s dehiscence.

 

Zenker’s Diverticulum (Hypopharyngeal Pouch/Pharyngeal Pouch):

Description

An acquired, false, and pulsion diverticulum formed by the protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's dehiscence.

Clinical manifestations
  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Food getting stuck (leading to coughing while eating)
  • Aspiration
  • Halitosis (bad breath)

Investigation

Barium swallow reveals an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa above the upper oesophagal sphincter, often with slow emptying of the diverticulum.

 

Management

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy: Surgical removal of the diverticulum and myotomy of the cricopharyngeal muscle.
  • Diverticular suspension: Dissection and inversion of the diverticulum with its apex pointing cranially.
  • Myotomy through stapler transection: Transoral insertion of a linear stapler to divide the septum between the diverticulum and the true oesophagal lumen.

Dohlman Procedure: Endoscopic technique involving division of the diverticulum wall and cricopharyngeal myotomy.

 

 

Cricopharyngeus and esophageal muscle fibres (Option A): Incorrect because Zenker’s diverticulum arises above the esophagus, not between these structures.

Thyropharyngeus and esophageal muscle fibres (Option B): Incorrect, as the esophagus lies inferior to the area of dehiscence.

Inferior constrictor along with upper esophageal muscle fibres (Option D): Incorrect because this does not specify the true anatomical gap (Killian’s dehiscence is between the two parts of the inferior constrictor, not between it and the esophagus).

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with cyanotic spells and a chest x-ray as shown below. Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for diagnosing and characterizing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Echocardiography

 

Explanation:

  • Echocardiography is the gold standard for diagnosing and characterizing Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • It provides detailed information about the aortic override, RVOT obstruction, and the sizes of related structures such as the pulmonary valve annulus and the pulmonary arteries.

Investigation of ToF

  • Physical Examination:
    • Cyanosis, clubbing, heart murmur, intensity/character of murmur, presence of thrill
  • Chest X-ray: (Option B ruled out)
    • Enlarged right ventricle, "boot-shaped" heart, decreased pulmonary vascular markings, right-sided aortic arch (20% of cases)
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG): (Option A ruled out)
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), dominant R wave in V1/V2, RSR' pattern, tall P waves indicating right atrial enlargement
  • Echocardiography: (Gold standard) (Option D)
    • Assessment of:
      • Aortic override
      • RVOT obstruction
      • Size of pulmonary valve annulus, main pulmonary artery, proximal branch pulmonary arteries
      • Presence of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Cardiac Catheterization: (Option C ruled out)
    • Indications:
      • Conclusive anatomy information needed
      • Suspicion of coronary artery anomalies
      • ToF with pulmonary atresia
      • Measure pressures and oxygen saturations
      • Perform interventions (e.g., Blalock-Taussig shunt)

Treatment of ToF:

  • Management of Tet Spells
    • Immediate interventions:
      • Knee-chest position
      • Oxygen administration
      • Morphine for sedation
      • Intravenous fluids
  • Surgical Repair
    • Complete Repair
      • Procedure: Close VSD, relieve RVOT obstruction
      • Approach: Transatrial-transpulmonary
      • Considerations: Minimizing pulmonary insufficiency with smaller patches
    • Palliative Shunts
      • Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Connects subclavian artery to pulmonary artery
      • Central Shunt: Connects ascending aorta to main pulmonary artery

questions.text:

questions.text: A 42-year-old man from a rural area in Africa presents to the clinic with a two-week history of fever, headaches, and general malaise. He reports experiencing night sweats and often feels excessively tired during the day. On examination, there is notable posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings?
questions.solution:
Sleeping sickness is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Trypanosoma, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected tsetse flies. It primarily affects rural populations in sub-Saharan Africa.

Causative agents: There are two forms of sleeping sickness, each caused by different subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei:

  1. Trypanosoma brucei gambiense: Causes West African sleeping sickness and is responsible for the more chronic form of the disease.
  2. Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense: Causes East African sleeping sickness and typically leads to a more acute and severe form of the disease.

Transmission

  • Vector: Both forms are transmitted by tsetse flies (Glossina species), which bite humans to feed on their blood. The flies are typically found in rural areas near rivers and lakes.
  • Reservoir Hosts: T. brucei rhodesiense is often associated with wild and domestic animals serving as reservoir hosts, while T. brucei gambiense is primarily human-centric.

  • Clinical features: Symptoms may appear weeks to months after infection and include:

    • Early stage: Fever, Headaches, fatigue and Joint pain
    • Winterbottom sign- Swelling of lymph nodes (particularly posterior cervical lymph nodes in T. brucei gambiense).
    • Late stage: As the disease progresses, especially in T. brucei gambiense, symptoms may include -
    • Neurological involvement leads to confusion, personality changes, and sleep disturbances (insomnia or excessive daytime sleepiness)
    • Ataxia (loss of coordination)
    • Coma

In T. brucei rhodesiense, the disease can progress more rapidly, with severe symptoms developing in weeks.

Diagnosis

  • Serological Tests: Detection of antibodies against the parasites (e.g., ELISA).
  • Microscopy: Examination of blood, lymphatic fluid, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for the presence of the parasites.
  • PCR

Treatment

  • Early Stage (no CNS involvement):
    • Pentamidine: Used for T. brucei gambiense.
    • Suramin: Used for T. brucei rhodesiense.
  • Late Stage (CNS involvement):
    • Eflornithine: Preferred for T. brucei gambiense, particularly if the patient cannot tolerate melarsoprol.
    • Melarsoprol: Used for late-stage T. brucei rhodesiense and can be toxic, leading to side effects like encephalopathy.

Leptospirosis (Option C): This can present with fever and systemic symptoms, but it usually does not cause significant cervical lymphadenopathy or distinctive sleep pattern changes.

 

Malaria (Option B): While malaria presents with fever and malaise, it typically involves symptoms such as chills and rigours, and does not usually lead to the sleep disturbances seen in sleeping sickness.

 

Dengue fever(Option D): This can cause fever and malaise but is less likely to produce the specific symptoms of sleep disturbances and lymphadenopathy described.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia and elevated lactate levels. The physician suspects a deficiency in a coenzyme essential for gluconeogenesis. Which coenzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Biotin

  • Biotin is a crucial coenzyme for pyruvate carboxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, the first regulatory step of gluconeogenesis.
  • This reaction occurs in mitochondria and is essential for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting.

  • Biotin also functions as a coenzyme for propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which is involved in odd-chain fatty acid metabolism.
  • Biotin deficiency leads to decreased gluconeogenesis, causing hypoglycemia and elevated lactate levels due to impaired conversion of pyruvate to glucose.
  • Causes of biotin deficiency include:
    • Severe malnutrition
    • Consumption of raw eggs (contain avidin, which binds biotin and prevents its absorption)
    • Inherited metabolic disorders (e.g., autosomal recessive biotinidase deficiency or holo-carboxylase synthetase deficiency)

Gluconeogenesis & Coenzymes

Step Enzyme Required Coenzyme Location
Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate Pyruvate carboxylase Biotin Mitochondria
Oxaloacetate → PEP PEPCK GTP Cytoplasm/Mitochondria
F-1,6-BP → F-6-P Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Mg²⁺ Cytoplasm
G-6-P → Glucose Glucose-6-phosphatase Mg²⁺ Endoplasmic Reticulum

Magnesium (Option A): Required for ATP-dependent reactions but does not function as a coenzyme for pyruvate carboxylase.

Thiamine Pyrophosphate (Option B): Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, not for gluconeogenesis.

Fluoride (Option D): Inhibits enolase in glycolysis but has no role in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of difficulty in vision in her left eye, along with persistent headaches and occasional eye pain. She also reports trouble with colour perception. Fundoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which type of optic neuritis is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neuroretinitis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario with a macular star in fundoscopy suggests Neuroretinitis, a subtype of optic neuritis.
  • Optic neuritis is an inflammatory condition of the optic nerve that can cause vision loss, with symptoms including decreased vision, pain in eye movement, and visual field defects.

 

Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

(Option A)

Retrobulbar Neuritis

(Option B)

Neuroretinitis

(Option C)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features

Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.

A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).

 

 

Clinical features,

It may be asymptomatic or associated with:

  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

 

Papilledema (Option D) is bilateral optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure.

  • Findings include elevated optic disc, blurred disc margins, retinal hemorrhages, and venous congestion.
  • It can be associated with optic neuritis.

questions.text: Leading cause of death in patients with Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: infection

  • The leading cause of death in patients with Crohn’s disease is infection, particularly sepsis related to complications such as postoperative infections, bowel perforation, and immunosuppression.
  • Approximately 25-40% of deaths are directly attributable to Crohn’s disease complications including infections.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a history of irregular menstrual cycles along with heavy bleeding for the past eight months. Pelvic examination reveals normal findings. Her coagulation profile is normal, and she has no other chronic conditions. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard for diagnosing the uterine cause of her AUB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy

Explanation: Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing the uterine cause of abnormal uterine bleeding

Investigations for Abnormal Uterine Bleeding:

 

  • There is no best single sequence of testing for the evaluation of AUB
  • Based on the patient's age and presentation, the testing approach may vary
    • Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVS):
      • It is well tolerated, cost-effective, and requires minimal technical skill.
      • Helps in the determination of endometrial thickness.
    • Endometrial Biopsy (EMB):
      • It is the gold standard for diagnosing the uterine cause of AUB
      • Preferred if endometrial hyperplasia or cancer is suspected.
    • Hysteroscopy and Saline Infusion Sonohysterography (SIS): Best for investigating possible focal lesions.

questions.text:
Match the following cytotoxic drugs with their primary uses:


	
		
			
			Cytotoxic Drugs
			
			
			Primary Use
			
		
		
			
			1. Temozolomide
			
			
			A. Treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma
			
		
		
			
			2. Dacarbazine
			
			
			B. DOC of glioma tumors
			
		
		
			
			3. Trabectedin
			
			
			C. Organophosphate used in myeloablative procedures
			
		
		
			
			4. Thiotepa
			
			
			D. Used in cisplatin-resistant ovarian cancer cases
			
		
		
			
			5. Altretamine
			
			
			E. Treatment of leiomyosarcoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-E, 4-C, 5-D

Explanation:

Miscellaneous Alkylating agents used as Cytotoxic drugs

Alkylating agents are chemotherapy drugs that attach alkyl groups to DNA, causing cross-linking, disrupting replication, and leading to cell death.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with monthly cyclic abdominal pain for the past year. She has not yet experienced menarche. The patient appears well-developed for her age, with normal secondary sexual characteristics. External genital examination reveals the following.



An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a distended vagina filled with blood, but the uterus and ovaries appear normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of cyclic abdominal pain, the absence of menarche, and the finding of a bulging, bluish hymen on physical examination are characteristics of an imperforate hymen causing cryptomenorrhea.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen, which explains the distended vagina observed on ultrasound.
Cryptomenorrhea

Definition

Obstruction of menstrual blood outflow due to congenital malformations

Common Causes

Imperforate hymen, transverse vaginal septum, vaginal agenesis, cervical stenosis

Symptoms/

Complications

Primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, abdominal mass, acute urinary retention, endometriosis, iatrogenic infections

Physical Examination

Bulging hymen, abdominal mass, possible tenderness on pelvic examination

Diagnostic Tests

Pelvic ultrasound (shows collection of blood), MRI (detailed anatomy), examination under anesthesia

Treatment

Surgical intervention to remove the obstruction (hymenectomy, resection of septum)

 

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) (Option A): Here an individual with a male karyotype (46, XY) cannot respond to androgens, resulting in female external genitalia despite the presence of testes and the absence of a uterus.
 

MRKH syndrome (Option C): A congenital disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina in females with normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics.


Asherman's syndrome (Option D) involves the formation of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. This condition can lead to secondary amenorrhea and infertility.

questions.text: A 38-year-old alcoholic patient presented to the OPD with atrophic scars and hyperpigmented lesions on the back of his hands, neck, face, and feet. Urine analysis revealed elevated uroporphyrin levels. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing atrophic scars and hyperpigmented patches along with the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme deficiency indicates that the likely diagnosis is Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).

  • It is the most common porphyria, has a complex inheritance pattern, and is of three types:

Type I (sporadic)

Type II (familial )

Type III

The enzyme deficiency is acquired and restricted to hepatocytes due to the inhibition of a normal UROD enzyme.

The enzyme deficiency is hereditary, present in all tissues, and associated with a UROD gene mutation.

Rare type and is characterized by a hereditary enzyme deficiency localized to the liver.
  • The major risk factors are subclinical genetic hemochromatosis, hepatitis C infection, alcohol, and estrogens.
  • Patients exhibit increased fragility of light-exposed skin, presenting with painful bullae formation, subsequent crusting, and resulting in atrophic scarring, milia, and alterations in pigmentation, either hyper- or hypopigmentation.
  • Histopathology reveals subepidermal bullae with a sparse inflammatory infiltrate and ‘festooning’ of dermal papillae into the bullae.
  • Management includes photoprotection and eliminating the risk factors.
  • Definitive treatment with venesection or low‐dose antimalarials is required in almost all cases.

Option A) Acute intermittent porphyria

  • Acute intermittent porphyria is a rare autosomal dominant disorder marked by hydroxymethylbilane synthase deficiency.
  • Clinical manifestations include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, peripheral neuropathy, and seizures.

Option B) Erythropoietic porphyria

  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) is a hereditary porphyria characterized by chronic photosensitivity and occasional liver disease.
  • It typically arises from deficient ferrochelatase activity, the final enzyme of heme biosynthesis.
  • It manifests most commonly in the first year of life, with excruciating pains on exposure to sunlight.

Option C) Variegate porphyria

  • It is an autosomal dominant inherited deficiency of protoporphyrinogen oxidase.
  • Clinical manifestations include cutaneous blistering lesions (subepidermal vesicles, bullae, and erosions that crust over and heal slowly) of sun-exposed skin, especially the hands and face.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with fever, cough, and foul-smelling sputum. A chest X-ray reveals a localized opacity in the apical lower lobe. Sputum culture shows the presence of anaerobic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)Aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a lung abscess. Aspiration is the most common cause of lung abscesses, particularly in the apical lower lobe, and is frequently associated with anaerobic bacteria from the oral cavity.

 

Lung Abscess Localized suppuration in the lung is characterized by tissue necrosis

 

Aetiology:

  • Infectious: Pneumonia due to Streptococcus, Pneumococcus, Haemophilus, Staphylococcus, anaerobic bacteria, etc.
  • Chronic upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis, tonsillitis, dental infections).
  • Mechanical: Bronchial obstruction due to tumours or foreign bodies.
  • Other Causes: Septicaemia and aspiration, commonly lead to lung abscess in the apical lower lobe.

Sites of Infection:

  • Apical Lower Lobe: Most frequently involved in aspiration-related lung abscesses.
  • Posterior Segments: Can be affected due to gravity when aspiration occurs.
  • Upper Lobes: May be involved in cases of tuberculosis or certain types of pneumonia.

 

Routes of Infection:

  • Aspiration: Inhalation of oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal secretions, often leading to anaerobic infections from the oral cavity.
  • Hematogenous Spread: From e.g., endocarditis or septicemia
  • Direct Extension: Localized infections in adjacent structures (e.g., pneumonia, empyema) can extend into lung tissue.

 

 

Hematogenous spread from endocarditis (Option B): While it can cause lung abscesses, it is less common than aspiration in the context of anaerobic infections and would typically present with multiple abscesses rather than a localized opacity.

Direct extension from pneumonia (Option C) can cause lung abscesses, but in this case, the specific presence of anaerobic bacteria and the apical location suggest aspiration as the more likely cause.

Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer (Option D) is a possible cause of infection and abscess formation, but the presence of anaerobic bacteria and the patient's age make aspiration a more plausible cause, especially in the context of a localized opacity in the lung.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a history of tubal ligation presents with sudden lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive serum hCG, and transvaginal ultrasound is shown below. What is the most definitive radiological feature confirming the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy in this case?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Ring of fire appearance

 

Explanation: The "ring of fire" appearance on Doppler ultrasound refers to the increased peripheral vascularity surrounding an extrauterine mass or gestational sac. The presence of this peripheral vascularity, along with the absence of an intrauterine pregnancy, is a definitive radiologic feature of an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Ectopic Pregnancy:

  • Empty extrauterine sac with a hyperechoic ring.

  • Extrauterine yolk sac and/or fetal pole with or without cardiac activity.
  • Inhomogeneous adnexal mass or extrauterine halo-like structure - a probable ectopic pregnancy.
  • Colour Doppler imaging: Placental blood flow within the periphery of an ectopic pregnancy - ring of fire appearance. (Option A)

  • In ruptured ectopic, blood is present in the pouch of Douglas, which shows echoes on USG because of the presence of hemoperitoneum.

Lambda sign (Option B): It is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies.

 

Trilaminar appearance (Option C): The trilaminar appearance of the endometrium is normally seen in the late proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Double decidual sac sign (Option D): This sign confirms the presence of an intrauterine pregnancy and is not seen in ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of progressively worsening temporal headaches, jaw pain, and visual disturbances. On examination, her right temporal artery appears swollen and tender to palpation. Which of the following statements regarding this condition are false?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of vasculitis in adults
It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response
It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response.

 

Explanation :

  • The clinical presentation of a 68-year-old woman with worsening temporal headaches (classical symptom), jaw pain (most specific symptom), visual disturbances (most dangerous complication), and tender and swollen right temporal artery points towards the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.

Temporal arteritis/Giant cell arteritis:

  • Giant cell (temporal) arteritis involves large- to medium-sized arteries. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epidemiology: Most common type of vasculitis in adults (usually >50 years old) (Option B ruled out)
  • It is frequently associated with polymyalgia rheumatica. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is a T-cell-mediated immune response (Option C)
  • Biopsy findings: 
    • Giant cells
    • Granulomas
    • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina
  • Special stain: Verhoeff-Van Gieson stain (to visualize elastic lamina)
  • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina: Elastic lamina is mostly present everywhere but fragmented in some places.

questions.text: What is one of the criteria used to define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) according to WHO standards?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presence of nutritional oedema

Explanation:

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) can be defined by:

  • Very low weight-for-height/length (Z-score below -3SD).
  • A mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm.
  • The presence of nutritional oedema.

SAM significantly increases the risk of death in children under five years of age.

It can indirectly cause child death by increasing the case fatality rate in children suffering from common illnesses such as diarrhoea and pneumonia.

Children who are severely wasted (SAM) are 9 times more likely to die than well-nourished children.

MUAC >115 mm (Option A): SAM is defined by MUAC <115 mm, not above.

Weight-for-age Z-score below -1 SD (Option B): This is not used for SAM diagnosis. Weight-for-age < -2 SD defines underweight, not SAM.

Height-for-age Z-score below -2 SD (Option D): This defines stunting, a sign of chronic malnutrition, not acute malnutrition.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the mentioned stages of fracture healing

choices.text: Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Hematoma formation, Modeling
Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Modeling
Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Modeling, Remodeling, Callus formation
Callus formation, Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Modeling, Remodeling

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Modeling

 

Explanation:

STAGES IN FRACTURE HEALING OF CORTICAL BONE:

 

Stage of hematoma
  • The initial stage lasts up to 7 days.
  • Blood leaks from torn vessels and forms a hematoma around the fracture.
  • The periosteum and soft tissues are stripped away from the fracture ends.
  • Fracture ends suffer from ischemic necrosis over a few millimeters.
  • Some osteocytes die, while others become active and help in healing.

Stage of granulation tissue
  • The granulation tissue stage lasts 2-3 weeks.
  • Precursor cells produce blood vessels, fibroblasts, and osteoblasts.
  • Soft granulation tissue forms between fracture fragments.
  • It provides support without structural rigidity.
  • A fibrous mesh from the blood clot supports fibroblast and capillary growth.
  • Macrophages and giant cells remove the blood clot.
  • In bone healing, granulation tissue differentiates into osteoblasts to form new bone.

Stage of callus
  • This stage lasts 4-12 weeks, during which granulation tissue differentiates into osteoblasts.
  • These cells create an intercellular matrix that becomes impregnated with calcium salts, forming the callus, or woven bone.
  • This callus, visible on X-rays about 3 weeks post-fracture, provides initial strength and indicates union.

Stage of remodeling

  • Formerly known as the consolidation stage.
  • Woven bone is replaced by mature lamellar bone.
  • This occurs in multicellular units, with callus replaced by lamellar bone.
  • The process is slow, taking 1 to 4 years.

Stage of modeling

  • Formerly known as the remodeling stage.
  • Bone is gradually strengthened.
  • Cortices sharpen at the endosteal and periosteal surfaces.
  • Local bone strains from weight-bearing stresses and muscle forces stimulate this process.
  • More noticeable in children with angulated fractures.
  • Limited remodeling occurs in adult fractures.
