fracture healing" data-author="" data-hash="8372" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/PXXQgntf1zwdA7EMjU7m1744216222.png" />

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

choices.text: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure
CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen
Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas- Fas ligand pathway.

Explanation:

The type of hypersensitivity involved in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is Type IV.

Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)

CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out).

Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)


 

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C)
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with persistent crying, refusal to eat, and multiple bruises. The parents report frequent falls. On exam, there are bruises on the abdomen and back, a healing burn on the thigh, and rib tenderness. X-ray done is shown below. The parents give vague explanations and claim the child "bruises easily." A CT scan reveals subdural hematoma without a clear trauma history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Caffey syndrome

Explanation:

  • Caffey syndrome or Battered Baby Syndrome is strongly suggested when a child presents with multiple injuries at different stages of healing, and the parents provide a vague or inconsistent explanation.
  • The rib fractures, bruises, and a healing burn- combined with intracranial hemorrhage without significant trauma- point to ongoing physical abuse.

Battered Baby Syndrome (Caffey-Kempe Syndrome):

  • A battered child is one who has sustained repeated physical harm due to intentional violence inflicted by a parent or guardian. Other names include Caffey-Kempe syndrome, maltreatment syndrome, or parent-infant traumatic stress syndrome.

 

Features Raising Suspicion of Abuse:

  • Inconsistent History: Parents may provide vague explanations for injuries, such as a fall, which do not match the type or timing of the injuries.
     
  • Delayed Medical Care: Parents often seek medical help only when the child’s condition worsens.
     
  • Injuries in Various Stages: Multiple injuries at different healing stages are often present.
     

Parental Admission: Parents may later confess to mild punishment but downplay the severity.

Injuries:

  • Surface Injuries: Bruises, abrasions, and lacerations, including characteristic labial frenulum tears.
     
  • CNS Injuries: Encephalopathy, retinal hemorrhages, and subdural hematoma (SDH), indicative of shaken baby syndrome.
     
  • Eye Injuries: Retinal hemorrhages and possible lens dislocation.
     
  • Visceral Injuries: Damage to the spleen, liver, or intestines.
     
  • Burns: Cigarette burns or scalds from hot liquids are often found.
     
  • Skeletal Injuries: Fractures (transverse, spiral, metaphyseal chip fractures), rib fractures, and the characteristic "string of beads" appearance on X-rays are common.
     
  • Cardiovascular Injuries: Rib fractures, lung and heart contusions.
     
  • Genitourinary Injuries: Consider sexual abuse.

 

 

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A): Causes frequent fractures but does not account for bruising, burns, or intracranial hemorrhage.
 

 

Munchausen syndrome by proxy (Option C): Involves a caregiver fabricating or inducing illness in a child, but the repeated physical injuries in this case make direct physical abuse more likely.
 

 

Hemophilia (Option D): Could explain bruising but not the presence of fractures and burn marks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of epilepsy has been prescribed Valproate. Look at the following diagram depicting the GABA metabolic pathway. Which enzymes inhibited by Valproate are responsible for increasing GABA levels?

choices.text: GABA transaminase and Succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase
Glutamate decarboxylase and Succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GABA transaminase and Succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase

Explanation:

Valproate increases GABA levels by inhibiting GABA transaminase, which breaks down GABA, and Succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase, which is involved in the GABA degradation pathway.


 

Mechanism of Action of Valproate

  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

GABA decarboxylase and Glutamate decarboxylase (Option B) : These enzymes are involved in the synthesis of GABA, not its degradation.

GABA transaminase and Glutamate dehydrogenase (Option C): Glutamate dehydrogenase is not directly involved in the GABA metabolic pathway.

Glutamate decarboxylase and Succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase (Option D): Glutamate decarboxylase is involved in GABA synthesis, not degradation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding Lynch syndrome?

choices.text: It is autosomal recessive in inheritance.
It is also known as hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
It is caused by mutations in genes involved in nonhomologous end-joining repair.
Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis.

Explanation:

Among the given options, the Amsterdam II criteria are used to diagnose Lynch syndrome (also called Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer or HNPCC).

  • An autosomal dominant disorder (Option A ruled out)

  • Caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, such as MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, and EPCAM. (Option c ruled out)

  • Amsterdam II criteria and Revised Bethesda guidelines are clinical tools used for screening and diagnosing Lynch syndrome. (Option D)

 

Feature Description
Inheritance Autosomal dominant
Also known as Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC)
Caused by Mutations in MMR genes (not NHEJ genes)
Diagnostic criteria Amsterdam II criteria, Bethesda criteria
Associated cancers Colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, gastric, small bowel, urinary tract

 

It is also known as hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome (Option B): Incorrect – that refers to BRCA1/2 mutations, not Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. On examination, he has significant posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The physician suspects a viral infection and decides to perform a specific agglutination test. Which of the following statements regarding this test is correct?

choices.text: The test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.
An agglutination titer of 50 or below is indicative of a positive result.
The test requires fresh serum samples without any prior heating.
Heterophile antibodies are produced only in response to one type of virus

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) The test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.

  • This scenario is indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM).
  • This statement accurately describes the principle behind the Paul-Bunnell test, which is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The test identifies heterophile antibodies present in the patient's serum that can agglutinate sheep red blood cells, which is a characteristic immune response associated with this viral infection.

 

Heterophile Antigens

  • Definition:
    • A type of hetero-antigen present in different species that share epitopes.
  • Cross-Reactivity:
    • Antibodies produced against an antigen from one species can react with the heterophile antigen from another species and vice versa (Option D)
  • Diagnostic Applications:
    • Heterophile antigens are used in various serological tests to detect antibodies in patient serum.
    • Examples of Tests:
      • Weil-Felix Reaction: Used to diagnose certain infections, such as rickettsial infections.
      • Paul-Bunnell Test: Primarily used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.
      • Cold Agglutination Test: This test is used to detect specific antibodies that cause agglutination at low temperatures.
        • This test is primarily used to identify mycoplasma pneumonia.
      • Streptococcus MG Test: Used to detect antibodies associated with streptococcal infections.

Paul-Bunnell Test

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Method:
    • Utilizes sheep red blood cells (RBCs) as antigens to detect heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum.
  • Principle:
    • In infectious mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.
    • These antibodies can also occur after serum injections and in some normal individuals.
  • Procedure:
    • The inactivated serum is prepared by heating at 56°C for 30 minutes (Option C)
    • The serum is mixed in doubling dilutions with an equal volume of a 1% sheep erythrocyte suspension.
    • Incubate at 37°C for 4 hours.
  • Interpretation:
    • Examine for agglutination.
    • An agglutination titer of 100 or above suggests infectious mononucleosis (Option B)

Note: The Paul-Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes; the Monospot test, horse red cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conductive Hearing Loss

 

Explanation:

  • Given that the audiometric findings show a significant A-B gap with normal BC thresholds and poorer AC thresholds, the most likely diagnosis is Conductive Hearing Loss, typically due to issues in the outer or middle ear.

 

 


 

Normal Ear:

 Conductive Hearing Loss (Option A): 

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

 

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) (Option B) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

 

Presbycusis (Option C) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease (Option D): 

  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the hospital for evaluation of recurrent abdominal discomfort over the past few months. She has a history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. An abdominal MRI reveals multiple irregularly delineated hyper-intense cystic nodules in the liver that do not communicate with the biliary tree. Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis suggested by the MRI findings?

choices.text: Very commonly associated with malignant transformation.
Typically asymptomatic and often found incidentally.
Characterized by enhancement on contrast CT.

questions.solution:
The MRI findings suggest Von Meyenberg complexes (VMCs), which are small, typically asymptomatic lesions in the liver resulting from ductal plate malformations. They are often discovered incidentally during imaging and can be associated with conditions like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

 

Von Meyenberg complex (Bile Duct Microhamartomas)

  • Small (<1.5 cm), usually multiple greyish nodular lesions in the liver due to ductal plate malformations.
  • Associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Caroli's disease, and congenital hepatic fibrosis. (Option D ruled out)
  • Histology: Cystically dilated bile ducts lined by a single layer of cuboidal epithelium in a collagenous stroma.
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Generally asymptomatic; Incidental findings during laparoscopic procedures or autopsies.
    • Can present with non-specific abdominal discomfort or episodes of cholangitis.
  • Imaging Modalities and Findings
    • Ultrasound: Multiple hyper- or hypoechoic areas with comet tail echoes.
    • CT Scan: Multiple irregular small low-attenuated areas, typically without enhancement on contrast injection. (Option C ruled out)
    • MRI/MRCP: Multiple irregularly delineated hyper-intense cystic nodules, not communicating with the biliary tree. Gadolinium contrast enhances differentiation from Caroli's disease.
  • Rare malignant transformation to cholangiocarcinoma. (Option A ruled out)
  • VMCs are rare liver findings with distinct MRI features. They typically cause no symptoms but can occasionally lead to abdominal discomfort or liver infections.

questions.text: The 45-year-old multiparous woman underwent a hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding after failed medical management. The uterus is firm and irregularly enlarged with multiple tumours in the myometrium with a characteristic whorled appearance on cut-section. HPE shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine Fibroid

 

Explanation:

  • Uterine Fibroid presents with heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, and a firm, irregularly enlarged uterus.
  • Histopathology reveals interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells with a characteristic whorled appearance.
  • Fibroids have an Eosinophilic cytoplasm and oval nuclei (cigar-shaped) with blunt ends.

Adenomyosis (Option A) is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, usually causing a uniformly enlarged and tender uterus. Histopathologically, adenomyosis shows endometrial glands and stroma interspersed within the myometrium.

 Endometrial Polyps (Option B) present with intermenstrual spotting rather than heavy bleeding. Histopathologically, endometrial polyps show irregularly shaped glands and a fibrous stroma, sometimes with blood vessels.

 Endometriosis (Option D) is endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, causing chronic pain and infertility, with histopathology showing ectopic endometrial glands and stroma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with schizophrenia, who has been stable on antipsychotics for years, was recently switched to a higher dose of a first-generation antipsychotic. He then becomes increasingly agitated, develops a high fever, and exhibits severe muscle stiffness, appearing less responsive and confused. The involved receptors and the drug of choice for managing this condition are:
questions.solution:
The scenario is indicative of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS), in which the blockage of D2 receptors leads to extrapyramidal side effects, and the drug of choice for treatment is Dantrolene sodium.

 

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

Description

A rare, potentially fatal consequence of neuroleptic administration.

Mechanism

D2 receptor blocking at:

  • Striatum (muscle rigidity)
  • Hypothalamus (hyperthermia)
  • Spinal nerves (autonomic disturbances)
 

Clinical manifestations

Motor and behavioural

Autonomic symptoms
  • Muscular rigidity (most common)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia,
  • Mutism
  • Obtundation
  • Agitation
  • Fever (most common)
  • Diaphoresis
  • Raised pulse and blood pressure
  • Sweating
  • Altered consciousness

Associated conditions

Renal failure and myoglobinuria

Laboratory findings
  • Raised levels of creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) (most common)
  • Leukocytosis (raised WBC)
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised plasma myoglobin

Management

  • Stop the drug (causing symptoms)
  • Supportive care (maintain hydration and other vitals)
  • Skeletal muscle relaxants: Dantrolene sodium (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Amantadine
  • Second-generation antipsychotics (for restarting the treatment for Schizophrenia).

questions.text: Given below is the image of a parasite. From the options pick a disease that is not transmitted by it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oriental sore

Explanation:

The parasite given in the image is a louse. Oriental sore is transmitted by sandflies, and lice transmit the rest.

 

Types of Lice
  • Head louse (Pediculus capitis)
  • Body louse (Pediculus corporis)
  • Pubic or crab louse (Phthirus pubis)

Transmission
  • Direct contact with infested persons.
  • Indirect contact through clothing, bedding, combs, or brushes.
  • Lice can be blown by wind from heavily infested individuals.

Diseases Transmitted
  • Epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii)
  • Epidemic relapsing fever (caused by Borrelia recurrentis)
  • Trench fever (caused by Rickettsia quintana)
  • Dermatitis due to scratching and secondary infection.

Control Measures
  • Malathion
  • Personal hygiene
  • Mass delousing

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive man suddenly develops facial asymetry and right arm weakness during a meeting. His BP on arrival  is 220/130 mmHg. CT shows putaminal hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Nicardipine to achieve target BP of 140/90 mm Hg or lesser
Sodium nitroprusside to achieve target BP of 140/90 mm Hg or lesser

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IV Nicardipine to achieve a target BP of 140/90 mm Hg 

Explanation:

Nicardipine is recommended as a first-line agent in the acute management of hemorrhagic stroke to reduce elevated blood pressure. According to the latest guidelines, blood pressure should be rapidly but safely lowered to a target of <140/90 mm Hg, as this has been shown to reduce the risk of rebleeding without increasing the risk of ischemia.

Earlier guidelines advocated a more gradual reduction in blood pressure, but recent evidence supports early intensive control for better outcomes.

Sodium nitroprusside is not preferred due to its tendency to cause a rapid and uncontrolled drop in blood pressure, which can lead to cerebral hypoperfusion and infarction, especially in patients with impaired cerebral autoregulation during hypertensive crises.

Mannitol is generally contraindicated in active CNS bleeding unless there is evidence of raised intracranial pressure with herniation risk, as it may worsen bleeding by altering intracranial hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent dental infection presents with persistent headaches, fever, and confusion. He exhibits focal neurological deficits and seizures. The radiological findings are provided. Given his clinical presentation and imaging, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage
Start oral antibiotics and monitor with CT every 48 hours
Administer high-dose corticosteroids and supportive care
Begin antiepileptic medications and refer for op follow-up.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage

 

Explanation:

  • Given the history of a recent dental infection, along with imaging showing a ring-enhancing lesion in the frontal lobe and symptoms of fever, confusion, and seizures, the most likely diagnosis is a Brain abscess.
  • The mainstay treatment includes both surgical intervention and antibiotic therapy.

Brain Abscess:

  • Pathology:
    • Direct Spread: From air sinus infections or following brain surgery.
    • Hematogenous Spread: Typically associated with respiratory infections, endocarditis, or dental infections.
  • Symptoms include fever, confusion, seizures, focal neurological deficits and raised ICT.
  • Most common in the frontal lobe, but are also frequently found in the parietal lobe, particularly in cases of hematogenous spread.
  • Imaging:
    • CT Scan (Initial Choice): Shows hypodense oedema initially, progressing to a ring-enhancing mass as the abscess matures.
    • MRI (IOC): Identifies restricted diffusion
  • Management: (Mainstay: Surgery + Antibiotics)
    • Early Surgical Drainage: Essential for effective treatment.
    • Antibiotics: IV antibiotics are administered for approximately 6 weeks.
    • Prophylactic Anticonvulsants: Considered due to a high risk of seizures.
    • Multiple smaller abscesses: IV Antibiotics.
    • Steroids: Reduce oedema and alleviate symptoms of mass effect.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with pain in the legs and swollen gums. The mother reports increased irritability and difficulty walking. Upon examination, there is subcutaneous bruising and tenderness in the lower limbs. You suspect a vitamin deficiency and order X-rays. What X-ray findings would you expect in this child?

choices.text: Dense lines between epiphysis and metaphysis, and a ground glass appearance
Widened epiphyseal plates and cupping of the metaphysis
Increased bone density with no fractures

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dense lines between epiphysis and metaphysis, and a ground glass appearance

 

Explanation:

The child's symptoms of leg pain, swollen gums, irritability, and subcutaneous bruising, combined with the suspicion of vitamin deficiency, suggest a diagnosis of scurvy.

In scurvy, you would see characteristic lines such as the White Line of Frankel (Dense lines between epiphysis and metaphysis) and a ground glass appearance in the bones, indicating abnormal mineralization.

 

X-ray Findings of Scurvy

  1. Characteristic Lines: Specific radiological lines indicative of scurvy are observed.
    • White Line of Frankel: Dense line between epiphysis and metaphysis. Due to calcification.
    • Scurvy Line: Dense line within the metaphysis.
    • Weinberger’s Ring Line: Dense line within the epiphysis.
  2. Trümmerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  3. Pelkan Spurs: Bone spurs from the lateral border of the metaphysis.
  4. Ground Glass Appearance of the bones.
  5. Subperiosteal Fractures: Fractures may occur beneath the periosteum.
  6. Epiphyseal Fracture Separation.

Normal bone structure (Option A): This is unlikely given the symptoms of pain, swelling, and bruising. Vitamin deficiencies typically lead to identifiable changes in bone structure on X-rays.

 

Widened epiphyseal plates and cupping of the metaphysis (Option C): This is associated with rickets but does not reflect the expected "dense lines" seen with vitamin D deficiency.

 

Increased bone density with no fractures (Option D): This is more typical of conditions like osteopetrosis or other metabolic bone disorders, not vitamin D deficiency, which typically leads to decreased bone mineralization and associated symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with acute onset pain, redness, and blurring of vision in the right eye. On examination, her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 48 mmHg, and there is a shallow anterior chamber with a hazy cornea. Slit-lamp examination reveals an intumescent, swollen lens with the iris pushed forward. Gonioscopy shows a closed angle. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for her glaucoma?

choices.text: Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory cells
Forward displacement of the lens due to an abnormal zonular attachment
Disruption of aqueous humor flow due to posterior synechiae
Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens

 

Explanation:

  • Lens-induced glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma associated with a disorder of the lens.
  • In this case, the enlarged lens prevents aqueous humor from flowing through the pupil into the anterior chamber, leading to a pupillary block.
  • The iris is pushed forward, resulting in angle closure and increased intraocular pressure.

 

Other options describe mechanisms for other forms of secondary glaucoma, such as uveitic glaucoma (Option A), phacodonesis (Option B), or chronic iritis ( Option C), but are not characteristic of lens-induced glaucoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with newly diagnosed pulmonary TB begins treatment with ATT. After several weeks of therapy, he complains of difficulty distinguishing colors and experiencing blurred vision. On examination, he exhibits decreased visual acuity and bilateral central scotomas. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ethambutol

 

Explanation:

  • Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness.

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green color blindness (Yellow vision- Digoxin; Blue vision- Sildenafil)
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with fever, purpura, and arthralgias. Biopsy shows small vessel vasculitis with immune deposits. Lab tests reveal C-ANCA antibodies. Which of the following is most consistent with this clinical picture?

choices.text: Microscopic polyangiitis with segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis

Explanation:
The case presents classic features of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which are C-ANCA/PR3 positivity and small vessel vasculitis.

The various types of small vessel vasculitis are listed below:

Microvascular vasculitis

Disease

Key Features

Antibodies/Labs

Pathology

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
  • Pauci-immune vasculitis
  • Upper/lower respiratory
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PR3-ANCA
  • c-ANCA pattern
  • Granulomatous inflammation
  • Small vessel vasculitis

Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Pulmonary-renal syndrome
  • No granulomas
  • Segmental necrotizing GN
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • (Option A ruled out)
  • Necrotizing vasculitis
  • No granulomas

Churg-Strauss (EGPA)
  • Asthma
  • Peripheral eosinophilia
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • (Option C ruled out)
  • Eosinophilic granulomas
  • Vasculitis

Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
  • Often HCV-associated
  • Purpura
  • Arthralgias
  • Cryoglobulins
  • HCV antibodies (Option D ruled out)
  • Immune complex deposits
  • Small vessel vasculitis

 

Vasculitis Type

Examples of Diseases

Granulomatous
  • Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
  • Churg-Strauss Syndrome
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Behcet's Disease (granulomatous form)

Non-Granulomatous
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Polyarteritis Nodosa
  • Henoch-Schonlein Purpura
  • Takayasu Arteritis
  • Giant Cell Arteritis
  • Kawasaki Disease

Necrotizing
  • Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
  • Churg-Strauss Syndrome
  • Henoch-Schönlein Purpura

Non-Necrotizing
  • Takayasu Arteritis
  • Giant Cell Arteritis
  • Kawasaki Disease
  • Sarcoidosis (rare vasculitis involvement)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found dead at home. On examination, his postmortem staining is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carbon monoxide poisoning

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Cherry-red discoloration
  • Cherry-red discoloration of the skin and tissues is characteristic of carbon monoxide poisoning due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin (COHb), particularly when levels exceed 30%.

Postmortem Staining in Poisoning Cases

  • Postmortem staining (Livor mortis) is the skin discoloration after death due to blood settling in dependent areas.
  • The color of the staining can indicate certain types of poisoning:

Poison

Postmortem Staining Characteristics

Opium (Option A ruled out)

Purple or blackish staining

Carbon monoxide (Option C)

Cherry red discoloration (COHb > 30%)

Hydrogen sulfide (Option B ruled out)

Greenish discoloration in tissues

Datura

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

Organochlorine/Kerosene (Option D ruled out)

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the activation mechanism of transmembrane guanylyl cyclases (pGCs)?

choices.text: Ligand binding induces a conformational change, activating cGMP synthesis.
The intracellular domain initiates gene transcription.
Intracellular proteins bind to activate cGMP synthesis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer A)Ligand binding induces a conformational change, activating cGMP synthesis.

Ligand binding to the extracellular domain causes a conformational change that activates the cyclase domains, leading to cGMP synthesis.

B) Phosphorylation within the kinase homology domain (KHD) is important but does not directly activate cGMP synthesis; ligand-induced conformational change is the primary mechanism.

C) The intracellular domains of pGCs do not bind to DNA or initiate gene transcription; they are involved in cGMP synthesis.

D) While some pGCs are regulated by intracellular proteins, the primary activation mechanism for most pGCs involves ligand binding to the extracellular domain.

Guanylyl Cyclase Receptor:

  • Transmembrane guanylyl cyclases (pGCs) are homodimers (~1,050 amino acids each).
  • Composed of a short transmembrane domain (21-25 hydrophobic amino acids) separating extracellular and intracellular regions.
  • Extracellular domain acts as a receptor for specific peptide hormones.

Domains:

  • Extracellular Domain: Binds specific ligands.
  • Juxtamembranous Protein Kinase-Homology Domain (KHD): ~250 residues, lacks kinase activity.
  • Cyclase Domain: Catalytic region for cGMP formation at the COOH-terminal end.

Activation Mechanism:

  • Ligand Binding: Specific ligands (e.g., ANP) bind, causing a conformational change.
  • Conformational Change: Rotation within the dimer activates cGMP synthesis by approximating cyclase domains.
  • Phosphorylation: Activation is modulated by phosphorylation in the KHD; ligand binding may expose phosphorylated sites to phosphatases for dephosphorylation and inactivation.
  • Desensitization: Prolonged ligand exposure can lead to dephosphorylation of the KHD, reducing pGC activity.

Intracellular Signalling:

  • cGMP Production: Activated cyclase domain produces cGMP from GTP, serving as a second messenger.
  • cGMP Targets:
    • cGMP-Dependent Protein Kinases (cGKs): Phosphorylate proteins to elicit cellular responses.
    • Phosphodiesterases (PDEs): Regulate cGMP levels by hydrolyzing it.
    • cGMP-Gated Channels: Involved in phototransduction and olfactory signaling

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn has not passed meconium since birth. The baby has a distended abdomen and frequent vomiting, which sometimes contains bile. Upon physical examination, there was a lack of stool in the rectal vault. An abdominal X-ray reveals a dilated colon with a narrowed segment near the rectum. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endothelial B receptor gene mutation

Explanation:

Hirschsprung’s disease (Aganglionic megacolon):

It is due to congenital absence of enteric ganglion cells in both myentric and meissner’s plexus in segment of distal colon due to failure of cranial to caudal migration of neural crest cells during development.

Causes:

  • Endothelial B receptor gene mutation.
  • Neural crest cell migration defect.
  • RET proto-oncogene mutation.

Symptoms:

  • Failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life.
  • Abdominal distention.
  • Bilious vomiting.
  • Constipation.
  • Failure to thrive.

Clinical Features:

  • Lack of stool in the rectal vault on digital rectal examination.
  • Explosive release of gas and stool upon withdrawal of the examining finger (squirt sign).
  • Chronic constipation in older children.

 

Meconium ileus (Option A ruled out): Associated with cystic fibrosis. Usually involves obstruction in the distal ileum (not colon). X-ray: "Soap-bubble" appearance. NOT typically associated with a narrowed distal colon

Increased enteric ganglion cells (Option B ruled out): This would enhance motility, not cause obstruction. In Hirschsprung, the issue is lack of ganglion cells.

Intestinal atresia (Option   C ruled out): Usually presents with double bubble or triple bubble sign on X-ray, depending on location (duodenal, jejunal, etc.). Often has polyhydramnios in utero. Not typically associated with transition zone in colon

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks of gestation presents with concerns about several skin changes. She describes a dark vertical line running down her abdomen, dark patches on her face, and pinkish lines on her thighs. She denies any itching, pain, or other systemic symptoms. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she is not on any medications apart from prenatal vitamins.

What is the most likely explanation for these skin changes?

choices.text: Linea Nigra, Chloasma (Melasma), and Striae Gravidarum
PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Linea Nigra, Chloasma (Melasma), and Striae Gravidarum

Explanation:

During pregnancy, various physiological skin changes can occur due to hormonal influences:

  • Linea Nigra: A dark vertical line running down the abdomen due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

  • Chloasma (Melasma): Hyperpigmented patches on the face, often called the "mask of pregnancy," due to hormonal changes and sometimes exacerbated by sun exposure.

  • Striae Gravidarum: Pinkish or purplish lines, commonly known as stretch marks, which appear on the abdomen, thighs, or breasts due to the stretching of the skin.

PUPPP (Option B) typically presents with intensely itchy, red, raised patches that often begin in the stretch marks of the abdomen and can spread to the thighs, buttocks, and arms, but not with pigmentation changes.
 

Pemphigoid gestationis (Option C) is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically begins with itchy urticarial papules and plaques around the umbilicus.


Atopic Eruption of Pregnancy (Option D) Presents with eczematous lesions or pruritic folliculitis, usually without the pigmentation changes described.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation syringe

Explanation:

The instrument shown above is a menstrual regulation syringe.    

Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

Uterine curette (Option A): Commonly used in D&C, a method for uterine evacuation, it is more invasive and typically used in later stages of pregnancy or for different indications.

Karman Cannula (Option C) is a component used in the MVA procedure but does not function independently as the evacuation instrument.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent respiratory infections and poor growth despite a normal diet. Genetic testing reveals Cystic fibrosis. What type of mutation causes cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Allelic heterogeneity

Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations within the same gene causing the same disease. In cystic fibrosis, many different mutations in the CFTR gene can cause the disease

 

Phenotypic heterogeneity

(Option A ruled out)

Pleiotropy

(Option B ruled out)

Allelic heterogeneity

(Option C)

Variability in the phenotype that is caused by mutations in the same gene
  • Disorders where multiple, seemingly unrelated organ systems are affected.
  • A single gene is responsible for several distinct and seemingly unrelated phenotypic effects

Different mutations (changes) in a single gene cause the same disease or condition

Example:

Loss-of-function mutations in the RET gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase, leads to inherited failure of development of colonic ganglia, leading to defective colonic motility and severe chronic constipation (Hirschsprung disease)

Example:

The allele causing neurofibromatosis type 1 can produce abnormalities of skin pigmentation, neurofibromas of the peripheral nerves, short stature, macrocephaly, skeletal abnormalities, and fits

Example:

Cystic fibrosis is caused by having one of many different mutations in the CFTR gene.

Heteroplasmy (Option D) refers to the presence of more than one type of mitochondrial DNA within a cell or individual. This is not relevant to cystic fibrosis, which is caused by mutations in the nuclear CFTR gene, not mitochondrial DNA

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of lower back pain radiating down his left leg, associated with numbness over the top of his foot and difficulty in dorsiflexing his big toe. On examination, he has weakness in the extension of the great toe and decreased sensation along the dorsum of the foot. Reflexes are normal. Based on the symptoms, which vertebral level is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4-L5

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient's symptoms suggest nerve root compression, commonly caused by a herniated disc.
  • The key findings in this case include lower back pain radiating down the left leg, numbness over the top of the foot, and weakness in dorsiflexion of the great toe (extensor hallucis longus), without reflex abnormalities.
  • These are classic signs of L5 nerve root involvement.

 

L5 nerve root compression, often due to L4-L5 disc herniation, results in:

  • Weakness in great toe dorsiflexion (extensor hallucis longus).
  • Sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot.
  • Radiating pain down the lateral aspect of leg.


 

Slipped disc:

 

  • A herniated disc, also known as a slipped disc, occurs when the soft center (nucleus pulposus) of a spinal disc pushes through a tear in the tougher exterior (annulus fibrosus) and presses on nearby nerves.
  • Herniated discs most commonly occur in the cervical (neck) and lumbar (lower back) spine. Here's an explanation of herniated discs affecting both the cervical and lumbar regions.

Cervical Slip Disc (Upper Limb Involvement):

  • In the cervical region, the nerves exit above their corresponding vertebrae (except for the C8 nerve).
  • The affected nerve root, in the case of a herniated disc, is typically the one corresponding to the lower vertebra in the pair.

 

Cervical Slip Discs and Affected Nerve Roots

 

Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Upper Limb)

C4 and C5

C5

Shoulder pain, weakness in deltoid muscle

C5 and C6

C6

Pain in biceps, weakness in wrist extension

C6 and C7

C7

Triceps weakness, difficulty extending the elbow

C7 and T1

C8

Hand weakness, difficulty with finger movements

Lumbar Slip Disc (Lower Limb Involvement)

  • In the lumbar region, the nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae.
  • Therefore, when a disc herniation occurs between two vertebrae, the nerve root corresponding to the lower vertebra is usually compressed.

 

Lumbar Slip Discs and Affected Nerve Roots

 

Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Lower Limb)

L3 and L4

L4

Weakness in knee extension, reduced patellar reflex

L4 and L5

L5

Weakness in foot dorsiflexion, difficulty walking

L5 and S1

S1

Pain down the back of the leg, reduced Achilles reflex, foot drop

 

Regional Prevalence:

  • Cervicothoracic (C6-T1): 10% of cases
  • Lumbosacral (L4-S1): 90% of cases
  • Thoracic: Rare

L3-L4 (Option A):

  • Compression at this level typically affects the L4 nerve root, causing weakness in knee extension (quadriceps) and decreased sensation over the medial side of the lower leg.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's symptoms.

 

L5-S1 (Option C):

  • Compression here would affect the S1 nerve root, causing weakness in plantarflexion (gastrocnemius), decreased ankle reflex, and sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the foot.
  • This does not match the patient's findings.

 

T12-L1 (Option D):

  • This is much higher in the vertebral column and would affect muscles and sensations around the lower abdomen and upper thighs, which are unrelated to the symptoms described in this case.

questions.text: A day-old preterm infant is admitted with severe respiratory distress. Physical examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and chest X-rays reveal bowel loops in the thorax and a mediastinal shift. Despite intensive care, the infant's condition deteriorates rapidly and leads to death. Which of the following accurately describes a characteristic feature of the most common type of this condition?

choices.text: Left-sided posteromedial defect with herniation of small intestine
Right-sided anterolateral defect associated with herniation of the liver
Defective central tendon of the diaphragm
Failure of development of the pleuroperitoneal canal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Failure of development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of a preterm with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and X-ray showing bowel loops in the thorax points towards Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)
  • CDH is a birth defect with an abnormal opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and severely impair lung development.
  • Most Common Side: Left (84%) > Right
  • It is of two types:
    • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of CDH and is due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal. (Option D)
    • Morgagni Hernia is due to the defective Central tendon (Option C)

 

Feature

Bochdalek Hernia

Morgagni Hernia

Side

Left-sided

Right-sided

Location

Posterolateral

Anteromedial

Herniated Organs

Small intestine, stomach

Transverse colon, sometimes liver

Common Symptoms

Scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, mediastinal shift

Mostly Asymptomatic and Incidental

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Less severe respiratory distress

Association

Polyhydramnios, abnormal LHR, and liver position

Rarely detected prenatally; usually diagnosed later

Management

Variable

Generally Better prognosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the clinic with a reddish patch on her tongue, as shown in the figure. She gives a history of chewing pan masala for more than 15 years. She has no difficulty in opening her mouth and has no other comorbidities. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Erythroplakia

 

Explanation:

  • The condition here is erythroplakia.
  • Erythroplakia is a bright red velvety plaque that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.
  • Has a higher malignant potential than leukoplakia.

 

Types:

  • Homogenous
  • Speckled
  • Granular
  • Erythroplakia interspersed with leukoplakia

 

Management:

  • Biopsy for diagnosis
  • Surgical excision
  • Strict follow-up

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent hoarseness and difficulty breathing. Laryngoscopy reveals findings, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely HPV serotype associated with these lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HPV 11
 

Explanation:

  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas are benign lesions primarily associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.
  • These serotypes are known to cause condyloma acuminatum and are commonly associated with laryngeal lesions, particularly in children and young adults

 

Types of HPV
 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma


 

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

 

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5 (Option A), 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts
 
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions
 
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11). (Option B)
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18) (Option C)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others. (Option D)
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with a condition where their haemoglobin has an unusually high affinity for oxygen. What is the physiological basis for the increased oxygen affinity of fetal haemoglobin compared to adult haemoglobin?

choices.text: HbF contains serine that reduces the positive charge of the globin side chain.
Higher histidine content, reducing oxygen affinity.
Binds oxygen more loosely than adult Hb

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) HbF contains serine that reduces the positive charge of the globin side chain.

  • Fetal haemoglobin (HbF) contains α₂ and γ₂ globin chains, where γ chains have serine instead of histidine. (Beta chains have more of histidine and lysine).
  • This reduces the positive charge in the heme’s central cavity, leading to decreased binding of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG).

Difference between Adult Hemoglobin and Fetal Hemoglobin”

Feature

Adult Hemoglobin (HbA)

Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF)

Globin Side Chains

α₂β₂

α₂γ₂

Oxygen Affinity

Lower

Higher

2,3-BPG Binding

Higher

Lower

Physiological Role

Tissue oxygen delivery

Oxygen extraction from maternal blood

Charge in Central Cavity

More positive

Less positive

pH Sensitivity

More sensitive

Less sensitive

 Binds more 2,3-BPG, increasing oxygen affinity (Option A): Incorrect- More 2,3-BPG binding decreases oxygen affinity, stabilizing the taut form. HbF binds less 2,3-BPG, increasing its affinity for oxygen.

Higher histidine content, reducing oxygen affinity (Option C): Incorrect- HbF has serine instead of histidine in its γ-chain, which actually increases oxygen affinity.

Binds oxygen more loosely than adult Hb (Option D): Incorrect- HbF binds oxygen more tightly than HbA to facilitate oxygen transfer from maternal blood.

questions.text: A 30 year old multipara at 40 + 5 weeks of gestation is scheduled for labour induction. The cervical exam reveals a Bishop score of 5. The device given below is considered for cervical ripening. Which of the following is the correct route of application of this device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intracervical

Explanation:

  • The image in the scenario depicts Laminaria tents, which are hygroscopic dilators inserted and placed intracervically as a part of mechanical induction.
  • Mechanical induction releases endogenous prostaglandins from the membrane and maternal decidua, resulting in the induction of labour and cervical ripening.

Laminaria Tents:

  • Made of dry seaweed with hygroscopic action.

  • Swells in 10–12 hours to dilate the cervix.

  • Rapidly improves Bishop score.

  • Uncomfortable and requires a speculum for insertion.

  • May not shorten induction-to-delivery time with oxytocin

Other Methods of Mechanical Induction of Labour:

  • Single Balloon Foley’s Catheter: inserted transcervically. (Option A)

  • Transcervical Double Balloon Catheter
  • Mechanical Dilator Insertion
  • Extraamniotic Saline Infusion

The transvaginal route (Option C) is used to deliver misoprostol tablets, which are used to chemically ripen the cervix for the induction of labour or medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding elimination characteristics of "hit and run" drugs are incorrect?


	These drugs are eliminated quickly and have short half-lives.
	These drugs produce a prolonged effect even after they are eliminated from the body.
	These drugs require continuous administration to maintain their therapeutic effect.
	Omeprazole and reserpine are classified under these drugs.
	Regular blood samples are needed to monitor plasma concentration.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1, 3 and 5
 

Explanation:

Hit-and-run drugs are not defined by their rate of elimination, do not require continuous administration, and monitoring of plasma concentration has no value.

Hit and Run drugs:

  • Create lasting effects by irreversibly binding to targets, initiating a cascade that persists even after the drug is eliminated (Statement 2).
  • The effect lasts much longer than the drug itself.
  • Do not require continuous administration due to prolonged effect.
  • Plasma concentration monitoring is of no value.
  • Examples include reserpine, guanethidine, MAO inhibitors, and omeprazole (Statement 4).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, progressive pallor and recurrent nasal bleeds. Bone marrow aspiration shows 10% myeloblasts with abnormal eosinophils. Cytogenetic analysis reveals inv(16) (p13;q22). Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Acute myeloid leukemia

  • Marrow blast count of ≥20% is required, except for AML with the recurrent genetic abnormalities
    • t (15;17)
    • t (8;21)
    • inv (16)
    • t (16;16)

questions.text:
Match the following research trials/programs with their respective objectives:


	
		
			
			i) MRFIT
			
			
			a. Surveillance and assessment of trends in cardiovascular events
			
		
		
			
			ii) Jai vigyan mission
			
			
			b. Decreasing serum cholesterol, diastolic BP, smoking cessation in lowering coronary heart disease mortality
			
		
		
			
			iii) MONICA
			
			
			c. Dietary approaches to stop HTN
			
		
		
			
			iv) MPOWER
			
			
			d. To control rheumatic heart disease
			
		
		
			
			v) DASH
			
			
			e. To control consumption of Tobacco
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e, v-c


Explanation:

Multiple risk factor intervention Trial (MRFIT)
  • It is a randomised, primary prevention trial
  • Its objective is to check whether decreasing high levels of serum cholesterol, DBP and smoking cessation would help in reducing coronary heart disease mortality.

MPOWER
  • Monitor tobacco use and prevention policies
  • Protect people from use of tobacco
  • Offer help for quitting tobacco use
  • Warn about the dangers with tobacco use
  • Enforce bans on tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship
  • Raise taxes on tobacco

MONICA
  • Monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease
  • Surveillance and assessment in trends of cardiovascular disease

Dietary approaches to stop hypertension

(DASH)
  • Consume a diet rich in vegetables, fruits and low fat dairy products with low content of saturated and total fats
  • Helps in decreasing around 8-14 mm hg of SBP

Jai Vigyan mission
  • Surveillance for finding out epidemiological determinants for Group A strep and sore throat.
  • Establishment of registry of RHD/RF all over the country
  • To promote vaccine development
  • To promote research and studies for investigations of RHD/RF

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after sustaining blunt chest trauma in a motor vehicle accident. Chest imaging reveals pulmonary contusions. After 48 hours, he develops severe hypoxemia with PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio of 110, bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, and no signs of left heart failure. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Insert a wide-bore needle in the fifth intercostal space
Start intravenous furosemide to reduce pulmonary edema
Begin low tidal volume mechanical ventilation
Initiate high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Low volume ventilation 

This patient has developed ARDS, likely secondary to pulmonary contusion, confirmed by bilateral infiltrates and low PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio. The cornerstone of ARDS management is lung-protective ventilation using low tidal volumes (4–6 mL/kg of predicted body weight) to prevent volutrauma and barotrauma. Option A (wide-bore needle) is used for tension pneumothorax, which would present with absent breath sounds and hemodynamic compromise, not diffuse infiltrates. Option B (Lasix) may be harmful here, as ARDS is due to inflammatory alveolar damage, not fluid overload. Option D (HFNC) is insufficient in moderate-to-severe ARDS, where invasive ventilation is required to maintain oxygenation and protect lungs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman’s transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 5 cm ectopic pregnancy located in the ampulla of the right fallopian tube. The initial serum beta hCG level was 3500 IU/L and has remained stable despite receiving three doses of methotrexate. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D) Laparoscopic salpingectomy


Explanation:
This patient has an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in the right fallopian tube that has failed to respond to medical management with methotrexate.

  • Laparoscopic salpingectomy involves the removal of the affected fallopian tube. It is indicated when medical therapy fails or is contraindicated, such as in cases of larger ectopic pregnancies (> 4 cm) or persistent beta hCG levels.

 

Expectant management (Option A) involves observation of the patient, hoping for spontaneous resolution. This is a viable option in cases where the beta hCG level is low or falling.

Hysterectomy (Option B) is not considered a management option for ectopic pregnancy.

Laparoscopic linear salpingostomy (Option C) is done only in H/O infertility or if the unaffected tube is also looking unhealthy.

questions.text:
A newborn baby presents with an inspirational stridor immediately after birth, which increases on crying. The stridor is alleviated when the baby is placed in the prone position, and the cry is normal. The flexible laryngoscopy is shown as follows.



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laryngomalacia

 

Explanation:

The scenario here points to the diagnosis of laryngomalacia, which presents with a stridor that increases on crying and an omega-shaped glottis on laryngoscopy.

 

Laryngomalacia or Congenital Laryngeal Stridor

  • Most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • During inspiration, an excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx gets sucked in and causes the symptoms.

Clinical Features
  • Presents at birth or immediately after
  • Stridor:
    • Increases on crying (increased negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the epiglottis inward, covering the laryngeal inlet)
    • Stridor present in supine position (as the epiglottis covers the laryngeal inlet)
    • Subsides in prone position (as the epiglottis falls away from the larynx)
  • Cyanosis seen sometimes
  • Normal cry
  • Usually disappears by 2 years of age

Investigations
  • Direct laryngoscopy:
    • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself giving an “omega-shaped” appearance.
    • Floppy aryepiglottic folds
    • Prominent aretynoids
  • Flexible laryngoscopy is the most preferred

Management
  • Conservative treatment in most cases
  • Tracheostomy: If severe respiratory obstruction
  • Supraglottoplasty: If severe laryngomalacia


 

Congenital subglottic stenosis (Option A) is a congenital condition where there is an abnormal thickening of the cricoid cartilage or fibrous tissue below the vocal cords. It may be asymptomatic until upper respiratory tract infections lead to dyspnoea and stridor. The cry is normal.

 

Subglottic hemangioma (Option B) is also a congenital condition but presents only by 3-6 months of age as hemangioma grows in size and causes stridor. Agitation and crying may increase the obstruction.

 

Laryngeal web (Option C) is caused due to incomplete recanalization of the larynx and presents with airway obstruction, weak cry, or aphonia from birth.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia. During the procedure, a tumor is discovered, which involves less than 5% of the resected tissue and is well-differentiated. The tumor was an incidental finding and was not palpable during a digital rectal examination. Based on the TNM staging system for prostate cancer, what is the most appropriate stage for this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) T1a

Explanation:

  • T1a stage indicates that the tumor was found incidentally during a procedure like TURP and involves less than 5% of the resected tissue. The tumor is usually well-differentiated.

 

TNM Staging System for Prostate Cancer

  • T1: Incidentally found tumors in a clinically benign gland.
    • T1a: Tumor involves <5% of the resected specimen. (Option A)
    • T1b: Tumor involves >5% of the resected specimen. (Option B ruled out)
    • T1c: Impalpable tumor found due to raised PSA.
  • T2: Tumor confined within the prostate capsule.
    • T2a: Involves one lobe. (Option C ruled out)
    • T2b: Involves more than half of one side but not both sides.
    • T2c: Involves both sides, confined within the capsule.
  • T3: Tumor extends through the capsule.
    • T3a: Unilateral or bilateral extension. (Option D ruled out)
    • T3b: Extension into seminal vesicles.
  • T4: Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum, pelvic sidewall).
  • N0: No regional lymph node involvement
  • N1: Regional lymph node involvement
  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis present

Match the following and choose the correct option:


	
		
			
			Name

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

 

Explanation:

 

Name

Microscopy

Features

a. Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large, rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

b.Vibrio Cholerae
  • Gram-negative
  • Short, curved cylindrical rod.
  • Distinctive comma shape.
  • Shows fish in stream appearance.

c. Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Gram-positive bacterium
  • Clubbed at one or both ends.
  • Often forming angles resembling the letters V or L, known as a Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement

d. McFadyean’s Reaction

The capsule of Bacillus Anthracis can be visualized using McFadyean's reaction, in which a smear is stained with polychrome methylene blue. The capsule stains purple, while the bacterial cells stain blue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. He has a history of ulcerative colitis. questions.text: During an eye camp, an elderly patient presented with a distinct ring around the cornea, as given below. The patient was referred to a higher centre for further evaluation. Several weeks later, the patient returned from the higher centre, reporting a progressive loss of vision. Upon examination, it was noted that a cataract had developed. Based on the initial observation and the current condition. Which of the following types of cataracts is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sunflower cataract

 

Explanation:

  • The initial observation of a distinct ring around the cornea in an elderly patient is suggestive of a Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is typically associated with Wilson's disease.
  • Upon the patient's return, the development of cataracts, particularly in the context of Wilson's disease, is most likely to present as a sunflower cataract.
  • This type of cataract is characterised by a specific pattern of opacification that resembles the appearance of a sunflower and is associated with copper deposition in the lens.

 

Type of Cataract

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2015?

choices.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all
Promote sustainable consumption and production patterns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Achieve world peace and disarmament

Explanation: 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030. There are 17 goals:

  1. End poverty everywhere in all its forms. (Option A ruled out)

  2. Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

  3. Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

  4. Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities. (Option B ruled out) 

  5. Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls. 

  6. Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

  7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

  8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

  9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

  10. Reduce inequality within and among countries.

  11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

  12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. (Option C ruled out) 

  13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 

  14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 

  15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 

  16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 

  17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a snake while working in his field in rural India. He presents with severe local pain, swelling, and gum bleeding. Within 2 hours, he develops diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive weakness in his limbs. Laboratory tests show prolonged prothrombin time and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Which of the following snakes is most likely responsible for this envenomation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- B) Russell's viper

The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a combination of hemotoxic and neurotoxic effects:

  1. Hemotoxic: Severe local pain and swelling, gum bleeding, prolonged prothrombin time, and decreased fibrinogen levels.
  2. Neurotoxic: Diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive limb weakness.

This combination of hemotoxic and neurotoxic effects is characteristic of Russell's viper envenomation.

 

Clinical features of various snake bites

questions.text: A 12-year-old child’s growth chart shows a distinctive pattern in the graph depicting their growth over time as shown in the image below. In this clinical scenario, what does the graph primarily indicate about the child’s growth patterns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic growth

 

Explanation:

In this clinical scenario, the sigmoid (S-shaped) curve primarily indicates the pattern of somatic growth, which refers to the child's height growth during childhood and adolescence.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic X-ray finding in patients with ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Squaring of vertebrae

 

Explanation:

Squaring of vertebrae (flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebra) is a key radiological feature of ankylosing spondylitis, caused by inflammation and erosion at the attachment points of ligaments, leading to a flattened appearance of the vertebral bodies.

X-ray Findings of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Squaring of vertebra and syndesmophytes

Bamboo spine appearance

 

Squaring of anterior vertebral margins due to osteitis of anterior corners.

 

 

Diffuse syndesmophytic ankylosis

Dagger spine

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Seen only in AP view
  • Linear ossification of the interspinous ligament in the central spine.

 

  • Bilateral sacroiliac joint erosions and sclerosis.
  • Joint is ill-defined bilaterally.
The "trolley-track sign" occurs due to the ossification of the ligaments along with the apophyseal joint capsules, resulting in three vertical radiodense lines visible on frontal imaging.

 

 

Clinical Features of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Onset and Age

Early Symptoms

Established Disease Symptoms

Postural Changes
  • Commonly begins in young adults, typically between ages 15-25.
  • More prevalent in males than females.
  • Insidious onset of chronic back pain and stiffness.
  • Morning stiffness lasting over an hour and stiffness after inactivity.
  • Possible referred pain in the buttocks and thighs, sometimes confused with sciatica.
  • Continuous pain and stiffness
  • General fatigue.
  • Joint pain and swelling.
  • Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion.
  • Intercostal pain and tenderness.
  • Decreased chest expansion
  • Enthesitis
  • Reduced lumbar lordosis (normal inward curve of the lower back).
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis (outward curve of the upper back).
  • Forward thrust of the neck, with compensatory hip and knee flexion.

Extraarticular

manifestations

Uveitis, aortic valve disease, carditis, pulmonary fibrosis, osteoporosis, inflammatory bowel disease, psoriasis, renal abnormalities

 

 

Joint effusion (Option A): Joint effusion is often seen in inflammatory arthritis but is not a primary feature of ankylosing spondylitis on X-ray. Instead, AS typically shows changes related to bone and joint structure rather than fluid accumulation.

 

Osteophyte formation (Option C): Osteophytes are bony growths typically associated with osteoarthritis and are not characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Cartilage loss (Option D): While cartilage loss occurs in various forms of arthritis, it is not specifically a hallmark finding in ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents with symptoms of lethargy, nausea, and muscle cramps. laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia and plasma hypoosmolality. He has a history of lung cancer and was recently started on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for depression. He is diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). Which of the following statements regarding the management of SIADH is incorrect?

choices.text: Fluid restriction to less than 800ml/day is the first-line treatment for Mild to Moderate SIADH.
Severe SIADH is corrected with administration of 100 ml iv bolus of 3% NaCl
Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH
Demeclocycline and lithium can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate SIADH.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C). Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH

Explanation:

Sodium correction should not increase 0.5-1mEq/L per hour, as it can cause severe consequences such as osmotic demyelination syndrome, which can even lead to quadriplegia.

Severity of SIADH

Symptoms

Management

Mild

Asymptomatic, Mild lethargy, nausea

Fluid Restriction

Moderate

Pronounced Lethargy, Confusion, Cramps, Nausea and Vomiting

Fluid Restriction, Loop Diuretics, Vasopressin Antagonists(VAPTANS), Demeclocycline, Lithium

Severe

Severe symptoms (e.g., severe confusion, seizures, coma)

Hypertonic saline as 100 ml IV bolus, fluid restriction, Vasopressin Antagonist

questions.text:
Match the following genes involved in the development of depression with their normal functions.

 


	
		
			
			Genes 
			
			
			Encoded for 
			
		
		
			
			A) SLC6A4
			
			
			i) Serotonin receptor
			
		
		
			
			B) DRD4
			
			
			ii) Dopamine transporter
			
		
		
			
			C) HTR1A
			
			
			iii) Serotonin transporter
			
		
		
			
			D) SLC6A3
			
			
			iv) Dopamine receptor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Genetic Influence
  • About one-third of major depression risk is attributed to genetic factors.
  • The gene encoding of serotonin receptor: HTR1A
  • The gene for serotonin transporter: 5HTTP/SLC6A4
  • The gene for dopamine receptor: DRD4
  • The gene for dopamine transporter: SLC6A3

Family History
  • Risk increases 2.5–3 times if a first-degree relative has depression.
  • Life events can raise risk from 5 to 16 times shortly after occurrence.

Neurobiological Mechanisms

Studies show that individuals with the short allele of 5-HTTLPR (serotonin transporter gene) exhibit amygdala hyperreactivity to emotional threats

questions.text: Earliest radiological finding in patients with beta thalassemia is

choices.text: Widening of diploic spaces of skull

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Squaring of metacarpals

Explanation:

The earliest skeletal deformities in thalassemia are observed in the metacarpals, metatarsals and phalanges of hands. The patient develops marrow hyperplasia causing cortical thinning and a “squared or sausage-shaped configuration” of these small tubular bones. Subsequently, widening of diploic spaces with prominent bone trabeculations, giving rise to a “hair on end” appearance, is observed.
