questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe fatigue, weakness, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. On examination, he is hypotensive (BP 75/45 mmHg), tachycardic (HR 115 bpm), and has noticeable diffuse skin hyperpigmentation, especially in sun-exposed areas and palmar creases. Laboratory results reveal:


	Sodium: 128 mEq/L
	Potassium: 5.8 mEq/L
	Glucose: 58 mg/dL


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Addison's disease

 

Explanation:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is characterized by the destruction of the adrenal cortex, leading to deficient production of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • In an acute crisis, patients present with severe hypotension, electrolyte imbalances (low sodium, high potassium), hypoglycemia, and dehydration, which are all seen in this patient.
  • Diffuse skin hyperpigmentation occurs due to increased ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes, which is a hallmark of Addison's disease.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option A) typically presents with hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

  • The electrolyte pattern and skin hyperpigmentation are not consistent with DKA.

 

Septic shock (Option B) can cause hypotension and tachycardia, but doesn't explain electrolyte abnormalities, or skin hyperpigmentation.

  • Septic shock typically causes hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

 

Panhypopituitarism (Option D) can cause secondary adrenal insufficiency, but it wouldn't result in skin hyperpigmentation (due to low ACTH levels).

  • Also, the electrolyte abnormalities are typically less severe in secondary adrenal insufficiency because aldosterone production is usually preserved.

Correct Answer: A) Felty's syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The unknown joint and bone condition the patient is suffering from is most likely Rheumatoid arthritis based on the presence of characteristic hand deformities (swan neck and boutonniere deformities).
  • Felty's syndrome is a severe extra-articular manifestation of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by the triad of RA, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.
  • This syndrome predisposes patients to infections due to neutropenia.

 

Clinical features of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Symmetrical polyarthritis, polysynovitis with soft-tissue swelling- Pain and morning stiffness in multiple joints usually lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • Generalized myopathy or neuropathy, tiredness, and loss of weight.
  • As the disease progresses, joint deformity, joint instability, and tendon rupture.

 

Joints affected

Common
  • MP joints of the hand
  • PIP joints of fingers
  • Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles

Less common
  • Hip joint
  • Temporo-mandibular joint
  • Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints.


 

Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis

Hand
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand
  • Swan neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity

Elbow

  • Flexion deformity

 

Knee
  • Valgus deformity

Ankle

  • Equinus deformity

Foot
  • Hallux valgus

 
  • Hammer toe

 

Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Vasculitis
  • Rheumatoid nodules- Subcutaneous, over bony prominences, in the synovium, on tendons, in the sclera, and the viscera. Size is increased by methotrexate.
  • Serositis
  • Felty's syndrome: Severe splenomegaly + neutropenia + RA. (Option A)


 

Psoriatic arthropathy (Option B):

  • It is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
  • It can cause joint pain, swelling, and deformities, but it is typically associated with nail changes like pitting, and dactylitis causing sausage-shaped fingers. 

 

Kashin-Beck disease (Option C):

  • It is a rare polyarticular form of osteoarthritis commonly seen in regions of China.
  • It primarily affects growing children and causes joint deformities, leading to dwarfism.
  • It is not associated with neutropenia, splenomegaly, and typical hand deformities as seen in this patient. 

 

Pseudogout (Option D):

  • It is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, leading to sudden and painful joint inflammation.
  • It does not cause swan neck and boutonniere deformities, neutropenia, and splenomegaly.

questions.text: You are counselling a newly diagnosed hypertensive patient on lifestyle modifications to promote better health and help manage her blood pressure. Which of the following recommendations would be inappropriate or misleading for this patient?

choices.text: Light aerobic activity of thirty minutes per day
Increase potassium intake to 4700 mg per day

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Restrict salt intake to > 5 g/day

 

Explanation:

Salt intake is to be restricted to < 5g per day. Salt has 40% sodium. So Sodium intake to be kept below 2g per day. Potassium intake to be increased by intake of fruits and vegetables to 4700 mg per day. These are DASH guidelines.

The general guideline also suggests at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic activity per week, which translates to about 30 minutes a day, five days a week. Keep BMI in normal range will reduce peripheral resistance.

 

Hypertension lifestyle modifications

Weight reduction

BMI < 25

Dietary salt reduction

< 5g Na Cl/day ( < 2 sodium per day)

DASH-type dietary plan (Option D ruled out)

A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content.

The diet is also rich in potassium, calcium, and magnesium.

Moderation of alcohol consumption

≤2 drinks/day in men and ≤1 drink/day in women

Physical activity

Regular aerobic activity, e.g., brisk walking for 30 min/day for 5 days a week.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements from the following:

 

a)BCG vaccine for TB- primary

b)BCG for Ca bladder- secondary

c)OCP for contraception- primary

d)OCP for PCOD- secondary
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a,b,c,d

 

Explanation:

  • Secondary prevention focuses on the early detection and prompt treatment of diseases to prevent their progression to more advanced or severe stages. This includes screening and early diagnosis.
  • Primary prevention focuses on interventions to prevent the onset of disease.




 

Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations (statement a)
  • Health education
  • Family planning (statement c)
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examination

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening
  • DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.
  • Treatment (statement b and d )

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a clear, watery nasal discharge that worsens when bending forward. He has a history of recent head trauma. Examination shows no signs of infection or sinusitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging modality for diagnosing the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High-Resolution CT (HRCT)

Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes a clear nasal discharge that worsens with bending forward which is a classic sign of CSF leak. HRCT is the investigation of choice for identifying skull base defects associated with CSF rhinorrhea, especially following trauma, as it provides excellent visualization of bone structures and defects.

Radiological Examination for CSF Rhinorrhea

 

High-Resolution CT(HRCT)
  • Investigation of choice for identifying skull base defects.
  • 3D reconstruction helps evaluate congenital or spontaneous defects.
  • Useful for detecting trauma, developmental abnormalities, or erosive lesions.

CT Cisternography
  • Involves intrathecal contrast injection to localize the CSF leak.
  • Improves diagnostic yield, especially in active leaks.
  • May miss cribriform or ethmoid sinus defects.
  • Invasive procedure with potential side effects like nausea and headaches.

MRI (Option B)
  • Not first-line unless encephalocele is suspected.
  • Less effective for identifying bony defects compared to CT.
  • More costly and time-consuming; and may require a contrast agent.









 

CT cisternography(Option C) involves intrathecal contrast and is more invasive, reserved for difficult cases when the leak site isn't found by HRCT.

X-ray of the skull(Option D) has limited value in detecting CSF leaks or skull base defects.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has a rapidly growing 3 cm mass in his right cheek. Biopsy shows small round blue cells, alveolar patterns, eosinophilic cytoplasm with cross-striations, and positive immunochemistry for desmin and myogenin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathology features suggest Rhabdomyosarcoma, a malignant tumour that arises from primitive mesenchymal cells committed to the skeletal muscle lineage.
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents.
  • It can occur anywhere in the body, but common sites include the head and neck, genitourinary tract, and extremities.
  • It typically presents as a painless, rapidly growing mass, often in the head and neck region.
  • Histopathology reveals small round blue cells with features of skeletal muscle differentiation.
  • Immunohistochemistry confirms the diagnosis with positive for muscle markers like desmin, myogenin, and MyoD1.
  • Treatment involves a multimodal approach, including surgery, chemotherapy, and often radiation therapy.
  • Prognosis varies widely depending on subtype, location, stage, and age at diagnosis.

Ewing Sarcoma (Option A) typically presents with small, round blue cells with scant cytoplasm lacking muscle differentiation.

  • It commonly affects bone or soft tissue in children and young adults and is often associated with the EWSR1-FLI1 fusion gene.

Neuroblastoma (Option B) usually originates from the adrenal gland or sympathetic ganglia in young children.

  • Histology reveals small, round blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes and neurite-like processes, positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin.

Lymphoma (Option D) typically shows monomorphic lymphoid cells and is identified by markers like CD20, CD3, or CD45.

  • The presence of alveolar patterns, cross-striations, and muscle markers (desmin, myogenin) points to rhabdomyosarcoma, not lymphoma.

questions.text: A young female with history of recurrent attacks of pain over medial canthus of eye and cheek presents with chills, rigor, diplopia on lateral gaze and restriction of eye movements. She was diagnosed with PCOS and is on OCPs for the same since 6 months. On examination, edema over eyelids and exophthalmos were noted. Choose the correct combination regarding communication of the most likely structure affected in this patient.

choices.text: Transverse sinus through Inferior petrosal sinus
Internal jugular vein through emissary veins
Pterygoid plexus through superior petrosal sinus
Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein

 

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario of restriction of eye movements (III, IV nerve involvement) pain over medial canthus (V1), pain over cheek (V2), diplopia of lateral gaze (VI) with exophthalmos and eyelid edema (venous congestion symptoms) and no history of blindness is suggestive of Cavernous sinus syndrome.

 

CT image showing cavernous sinus thrombosis:

Tributaries and communications of cavernous sinus:

 

 

Tributaries:

From the Orbit
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Central vein of the retina (drains into either the superior ophthalmic vein or directly into the cavernous sinus)

From the Brain
  • Superficial middle cerebral vein
  • Inferior cerebral veins

From the Meninges
  • Sphenoparietal sinus
  • Frontal trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Communications

Vein/sinus

Via

Transverse sinus

Superior petrosal sinus (Option A)

Internal jugular vein

Inferior petrosal sinus (Option B)

Pterygoid plexus

Emissary veins (Option C)

Facial vein

Superior ophthalmic vein (Option D)

Right and Left cavernous sinuses

Anterior and posterior intercavernous sinuses

questions.text: By which age the milestone given in the image below is achieved by the child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3 months

 

Explanation:

The image depicts ventral suspension of the child (this co relates with neck holding milestone which also develops by 3 months)

  • Method: The child is held in a prone position and then lifted from the couch, with the examiner supporting the chest and abdomen of the child with the palm of his hand.

 

  • Different stages:-
    • Till 4 weeks (1 month): Head flops down
    • 6 - 8 weeks: Child momentarily holds the head in the horizontal plane
    • 8 weeks: He can maintain the position well.
    • 12 weeks: Lift the head above the horizontal plane

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the given drug?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Blocks Na+ channels

 

Explanation:

Image shown is Bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. All local anesthetic acts by inhibiting Na+ channels.

Mechanism of action & absorption:

  • Site: acts on nodes of ranvier
  • Blocks transmission of pain impulse from nociceptor to spinal cord.
  • Acts on intracellular side of Na channels at inactivation gate blocking the channel.
  • LA doesn’t affect RMP of nerves.
  • Blocks inactivation gates of Na+ channels → Disrupts depolarisation → No action potential generated → No pain sensation.
  • Highest systemic absorption (routes of administration): IV route >Tracheal > Intercostal > Brachial plexus > Epidural.
  • Form for onset of LA action (to reach target nerve) - Unionized form.
  • Active form at site of block of Na channels- Ionized form.
  • Higher doses will act for longer duration and lower doses for a relatively shorter duration.

 

Duration of onset for different local anesthetics (infiltration anesthesia):

Short Duration
  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine

Moderate Duration
  • Lidocaine
  • Prilocaine

Long Duration
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine
  • Shortest acting- Chloroprocaine
  • Longest acting- Dibucaine
  • Fastest onset- Chloroprocaine (low potency so high concentration used) > Lignocaine (pka is near physiological pH)

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to developmental delay and vision problems. Physical examination reveals a tall, slender child with elongated limbs, pectus excavatum, and blue eyes. Ophthalmologic evaluation shows bilateral lens dislocation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of homocystine and methionine in the blood and urine. Which of the following is the most likely underlying enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystathionine β-synthase

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with homocystinuria, which is caused by a deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS).
  •  

Classical Homocystinuria:

Pathogenesis
  • Defective metabolism of methionine and homocysteine
  • Accumulation of homocysteine and methionine
  • Decreased cysteine levels
  • Impaired folate metabolism (in MTHFR deficiency)

Enzymes Involved
  • Cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) - Most common
  • Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR)
  • Defect in methylcobalamin metabolism

Clinical Features
  • Ectopia lentis (Inferonasal subluxation of lens) (Superotemporal seen in Marfan disease)
  • Marfanoid habitus (tall, slender, elongated limbs)
  • Developmental delay and intellectual disability
  • Psychiatric and behavioral disorders
  • Skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, pectus excavatum)
  • Thromboembolism (recurrent episodes of stroke) (due to oxidised homocysteine)
  • Fair complexion, blue eyes
  • Seizures (in ~20% of untreated patients)

Diagnosis
  • Elevated homocysteine and methionine in blood and urine
  • Low or absent cysteine in plasma

Management
  • Coenzyme supplementation
  • B9 and B12 supplementation
  • Methionine-restricted diet
  • Cysteine supplementation

 

Phenylalanine hydroxylase: This enzyme is deficient in phenylketonuria (PKU), not homocystinuria (Option A)

Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) (Option C): While a deficiency of this enzyme can cause a form of non-classical homocystinuria, it typically presents with low or low-normal methionine levels, unlike the elevated methionine seen in this case. This is because MTHFR deficiency leads to THF deficiency, causing less conversion of homocysteine to methionine.

Methionine synthase (Option D): Deficiency of this enzyme can cause homocystinuria, but it's typically associated with low methionine levels and methylmalonic aciduria if B12 deficiency is present.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a progressive painless swelling in the superolateral part of his left orbit over the past year. Examination reveals mild proptosis and downward and inward displacement of the eye. CT of the orbit shows a well-circumscribed, smooth, encapsulated mass in the lacrimal gland region. Excisional biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic Lacrimal Gland Adenoma: (Option C)

  • It is a benign mixed tumor
  • Most common benign lacrimal gland tumor
  • Incidence- young adult males

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Slow-growing painless swelling in the upper-outer quadrant of the orbit
  • Displaces the eyeball downwards and inwards

 

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging:
    • CT- well-defined mass in superotemporal quadrant
  • Histology:
    • The inner layer of cells forms glandular tissue associated with squamous differentiation and keratin production.
    • The outer cells undergo metaplastic change leading to the formation of myxoid tissue

      Treatment:

    • Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option A), Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B), and Lymphoma (Option D): All of them are lacrimal gland malignancies typically present as a painful, rapidly growing mass in the superotemporal quadrant of the orbit, causing displacement of the eye in an inferonasal direction. CT scans often reveal an infiltrative tumor.


      Complete excision with the capsule

questions.text:
At your community medicine posting, a farmer arrives complaining of multiple nodules over his right leg after being pricked by a thistle. Examination findings are given in the image below. What would you expect to find on a microscopic examination of tissue from one of his lesions?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asteroid Bodies

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation, along with the linear distribution of nodules, is suggestive of sporotrichosis/ Rose Gardner’s disease caused by Sporothrix schenckii.

  • It is a Subcutaneous fungal infection that typically occurs after the fungus is traumatically inoculated into the skin, often through thorn pricks, splinters, or scratches from contaminated plant materials.
  • Enzymes secreted by fungus, such as serine & aspartate proteinases help in local invasion.
  • Sporothrix schenckii has a tendency to spread along lymphatics.
  • Risk factors: Walking barefoot, farmers & gardeners.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Incubation period: 3 weeks
    • Types:

Lympho-cutaneous
  • M/C type (80%)
  • Painless modulo-ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics.
  • Lymph nodes can become enlarged, suppurative & indurated and have cord-like feeling on palpation.

Osteoarticular

  • Seen in alcoholics.

Pulmonary
  • Can be seen in underlying COPD.

Disseminated
  • Seen in immunocompromised patients.

Fixed cutaneous
  • Single nodule, less progressive & not spread by lymphatics.
  • Laboratory diagnosis:
    • KOH mount: Elongated yeast cells of 3-5 𝜇m in diameter (low sensitivity).
    • Histopathological staining with methenamine silver reveals cigar-shaped asteroid bodies comprising a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating eosinophilic extensions composed of antigen-antibody complexes. This eosinophilic halo is known as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.
    • ​​​​​​​Culture is the most definitive test for diagnosis.

The image below shows the culture of S. schenckii:

The image below shows the asteroid body and Splendour Hoeppli phenomenon:

Treatment of Sporotrichosis:

  • Itraconazole is the drug of choice for all forms except disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Amphotericin B is the preferred treatment for disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Potassium iodide can also be used.

 

Black Granules (Option B) are classically associated with mycetoma/ Madura foot, caused by the organism M. mycetomatis. It can also be caused by the Actinomycetes bacteria, where there is the formation of yellow/ sulphur granules and discharging sinuses.

Madura foot:

Histopathology of Actinomycotic mycetoma:

Muriform bodies (Option C) are seen in chromoblastomycosis, which also occurs in farmers with a history of thorn or thistle pricks. It shows slow-growing, polymorphic, verrucous (m/c type) lesions and sclerotic bodies (muriform cells/medlar bodies).

Spherules containing endospores (Option D) are characteristic of coccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. His sputum microscopy, shown in the image below, reveals the following finding. Which best describes this finding?

choices.text: Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa.
Polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within the bronchioles.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) They are composed of Galectin 10.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of bronchial asthma, with sputum culture showing Charcot-Leyden crystals

Charcot-Leyden crystals:

  • They are microscopic, needle-shaped crystals that are often found in the sputum of asthma patients, particularly during exacerbations.
  • They are primarily composed of galectin-10 (derived from the eosinophils) also known as Charcot-Leyden crystal protein (CLC).
  • Strong inducers of inflammation and mucus production.

 

  • Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles describes the Curschmann spirals. They are a characteristic finding in asthma. (Option A)

  • Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa describe the Creola bodies seen in bronchial asthma. (Option B)

  • Polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within the bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli describe Masson bodies, which are seen in cryptogenic organising pneumonia. (Option C)

questions.text: A 32 year old male involved in smuggling accidentally swallowed a foreign object, which became lodged in his piriform fossa. After its removal, he reports numbness and loss of sensation in his throat. Which nerve is most likely damaged during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

The internal laryngeal nerve is responsible for sensory innervation to the supraglottic region of the larynx, and damage during foreign body removal from the piriform fossa can cause anesthesia in this area.

 

  • The piriform fossa is a small depression found on each side of the laryngopharynx.
  • It is positioned on both sides of the laryngeal inlet.
  • The boundaries of the piriform fossa include:
    • Medial boundary: Aryepiglottic fold
    • Lateral boundary: Thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
  • The internal laryngeal nerve runs just beneath the mucosa of the piriform fossa.
    • Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve, such as during the removal of foreign bodies from the fossa, can result in loss of sensation (anesthesia) in the supraglottic region of the larynx.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option A): This nerve innervates the muscles of the larynx and is not the specific nerve affected during this procedure.

External laryngeal nerve (Option B): This nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle but does not affect sensory innervation to the supraglottic part of the larynx.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D): While it provides sensory innervation to the pharynx, it does not innervate the supraglottic part of the larynx.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She has a history of rheumatic fever during her childhood. Examination shows diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex with pronounced opening snap. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heaving apex beat

Explanation: 

  • Heaving apex beat is seen in Aortic stenosis. Mitral stenosis has a tapping apex beat
  • The clinical scenario of worsening exertional dyspnea, a history of rheumatic fever, and the presence of a diastolic murmur with an opening snap suggests Mitral stenosis & the primary issue is obstruction, leading to left atrial enlargement and a reduced mitral valve area
  • Long standing MS will cause Pulmonary artery hypertension. That explains development of right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A public health researcher is investigating the association between air pollution and asthma in children. The researcher collects data from a population over several years, documenting the levels of air pollution and the incidence of new asthma cases. Which of the following best describes the study design?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Analytical Study - Cohort 

Explanation:

The researcher compares the levels of air pollution and the incidence of new asthma cases through a cohort study, an analytical epidemiological study.

A cohort study is a study design that follows a group of individuals (cohort) to observe how different exposures affect the incidence of specific outcomes.

Interventional Study (Option A):

  • An interventional study, also known as an experimental study, involves the researcher actively intervening to modify one or more factors and observing the effects of these changes.

Descriptive Study (Option C):

  • A descriptive study primarily describes the characteristics of a population or phenomenon being studied.
  • It does not aim to test hypotheses or investigate causal relationships.

Analytical Study - Case Control (Option D):

  • A case-control study is retrospective, starting with individuals who already have the outcome (e.g., asthma) and comparing them to those without the outcome to determine past exposures.
  • In the scenario described, the researcher collects data prospectively which aligns with a cohort study.

Classification of study designs:

OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES

EXPERIMENTAL/INTERVENTIONAL STUDIES

Descriptive

Analytical

Case reports

Ecological studies

Randomised controlled trials

Case series

Case-control studies

Field trials

Cohort studies

Community trials

Cross-sectional studies

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to her primary care physician with complaints of intense vaginal itching, a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge, and irritation. Per vaginal examination reveals the following finding. The vaginal pH is found to be acidic (approximately 4.5). What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Topical nystatin

Explanation:

Given the patient’s symptoms, risk factors, and the acidic vaginal pH, the presentation is consistent with vaginal candidiasis and the treatment of choice is Topical nystatin

Vaginal candidiasis

Risk factors

  • Old age
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Corticosteroid use
  • Pregnancy
  • Immunocompromised states - HIV
  • Low neutrophil count

Presentation

Intense vaginal itching and irritation

Splash dysuria seen

Thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge

Treatment

Topical nystatin - DOC for uncomplicated cases

 

Oral fluconazole (Option B) used for more severe or recurrent infections that do not respond to standard treatment.

Topical metronidazole (Option C): Metronidazole is an antibiotic primarily used for bacterial infections or protozoal infections( Bacterial vaginosis, Trichomoniasis) and does not treat fungal infections like vaginal candidiasis.

Topical hydrocortisone (Option D): Although hydrocortisone can help reduce inflammation and itching, it does not treat the fungal infection itself.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents with a two-month history of persistent itching, redness, and scaling of the right nipple, unresponsive to moisturizing creams. Physical examination reveals erythema and crusting of the nipple and areola without palpable breast lumps. The image of her right breast is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget disease of the nipple

Explanation:

The given case scenario is that of Paget’s disease of the nipple

Finding

Description

Possible Cause

Nipple discharge

Discharge from a single duct orifice

Papilloma (Option C) or other underlying ductal disease

Paget disease of the nipple

Appears as a psoriatic rash starting on the nipple and spreading to the areola and breast skin.

Paget disease

Skin dimpling
  • Traction on Cooper ligaments by a scirrhous tumor
  • Best seen with angled indirect lighting during the abduction of the arms upward.

Scirrhous tumor (Option B)

Peau d’orange (skin of the orange)

Edema of the breast skin
  • Inflammatory carcinoma (Option D)
  • Lymphatic blockage
  • Mastitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with palpitations and dizziness presents with narrow complex tachycardia and a heart rate of 200 beats per minute. His ECG shows a short PR interval and a delta wave. Which of the following is the drug of choice for acute management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Procainamide

Explanation:

This patient has WPW syndrome, indicated by the ECG findings of a short PR interval and a delta wave, along with his symptoms of palpitations and dizziness.

  • Procainamide is the most appropriate drug for treating WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). It effectively slows conduction through both the accessory pathway and the atrioventricular (AV) node, aiding in the restoration of normal sinus rhythm.
    • For WPW syndrome: Used with propafenone for narrow QRS tachycardia
    • Used with propafenone, verapamil, or propranolol for wide QRS tachycardia

 

Lidocaine (Option A): Lidocaine is primarily used for ventricular arrhythmias and is not effective for atrial arrhythmias associated with WPW syndrome. 

Esmolol (Option B): Not recommended in WPW syndrome as it may enhance conduction through the accessory pathway, potentially worsening the arrhythmia.

Ajmaline (Option D): Ajmaline, a new Class 1a drug, is not used for treating arrhythmias but is employed in diagnosing Brugada syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with acute abdominal pain, and bilious vomiting. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, and he has not had a bowel movement for three days. An abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start IV fluids (RL)

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation of acute abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting, along with the abdominal X-ray findings showing dilated bowel loops and valvulae conniventes, confirms the diagnosis of small bowel obstruction (SBO). T
  • he best initial step is to start IV fluids (RL).

 

 

 

Management of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Steps:
    • NIL per oral
    • Insert 2 large-bore IV cannulas.
    • Start IV fluids. (Option B)
      • Fluid of choice: Ringer's lactate.
  • Proximal Decompression with nasogastric aspiration
  • Monitoring, including urine output, and supportive treatment

questions.text: A 28 year old female presents with concerns about hair loss and decreased hair volume, as shown below. Many members of her family also have a similar history of significant hair loss. All of the following are true about the given condition except?

choices.text: It follows a polygenic mode of inheritance.
Ludwig’s grading system is used to assess severity.
Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

 

Explanation:

Hair loss with increased central parting and decreased hair volume is considered to be female pattern hair loss (FPHL). It is different from female pattern baldness as there is no loss of front hairline (Option A).

  • It is seen in androgenetic alopecia which occurs due to the involvement of multiple hormonal and genetic factors. Multiple genes have been identified for the same and hence it is considered to be of polygenic inheritance (Option B).
  • It is commonly seen in middle-aged women with progressive loss of terminal hair over the vertex of the scalp.
  • It presents with diffuse thinning of hair, increased hair shedding, decreased hair volume, and widening of hair partition.
  • Grade 3 FPHL is also called the ‘Fir tree / Christmas tree’ pattern.
  • Ludwig’s grading for female androgenic alopecia. (Option C)

Treatment: Topical 2% minoxidil is the first line of treatment, with or without adjuncts like spironolactone in women and finasteride in men.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with acute Hepatitis B presents with the following lab results:

ALT 4100 IU/L

AST 3900 IU/L

Total bilirubin 60 μmol/L (3.5 mg/dL)

Despite the very high aminotransferase levels, his bilirubin remains moderately elevated. What does this suggest about the severity of liver cell damage?

choices.text: Severe liver cell damage causing acute liver failure
The severity of damage cannot be determined from ALT levels alone
Mild liver cell damage causing fulminant hepatitis
Transition to chronic Hepatitis B with moderate liver damage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The severity of damage cannot be determined from ALT levels alone

Explanation: ALT/AST levels do not correlate directly with the extent of liver cell damage in Hepatitis B. While ALT and AST levels are very high, bilirubin remains moderately elevated, indicating that although hepatocyte damage is ongoing, the liver is still functioning well enough to manage bilirubin clearance.

Liver Function Tests (LFT) in Hepatitis B

Liver damage and clinical course depend on the immune response to HBV, not the level of circulating HBsAg

Aminotransferase levels (AST/ALT)

Increase during the prodromal phase and before bilirubin rises.

Levels do not correlate with liver cell damage severity. (Option B)

Peak levels (~400–4000 IU or more) are seen during clinical jaundice.

Levels decrease during recovery.

Bilirubin levels

Total bilirubin is divided into conjugated and unconjugated forms.

Levels >340 μmol/L (20 mg/dL) suggest severe disease.

Jaundice in the sclera and skin is visible when serum bilirubin >43 μmol/L (2.5 mg/dL).

Bilirubin may continue to rise even as aminotransferase levels fall.

 

Alkaline phospahatse (ALP)

A fourfold rise in ALP levels is suggestive of obstructive jaundice.

Comorbid conditions

In patients with hemolytic anaemia (G6PD deficiency or sickle cell anaemia), high bilirubin (>513 μmol/L or 30 mg/dL) may result from hemolysis and is not always a poor prognostic sign.

 

Severe liver cell damage causing acute liver failure (Option A): In acute liver failure, there is significant impairment in liver function, leading to much higher bilirubin levels in serum. Therefore, this option is incorrect, as the patient's bilirubin levels do not indicate severe liver failure yet.

 

Mild liver cell damage causing fulminant hepatitis (Option C): Fulminant hepatitis is characterised by massive liver damage and severe impairment of liver function, which would lead to very high bilirubin levels and signs of liver failure (e.g., coagulopathy, encephalopathy). Mild liver cell damage would not cause fulminant hepatitis, making this option incorrect.

 

Transition to chronic Hepatitis B with moderate liver damage (Option D): It is often associated with fluctuating or mildly elevated ALT/AST levels rather than the acute, severe spike seen here. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Leading cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients?

choices.text: Non small cell cancer of lung

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Non small cell cancer of lung:

  • The leading cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is squamous cell cancer. It produces PTH-rp that leads to increased bone resorption and resultant hypercalcemia. Lung cancer will produce symptoms like cough, weight loss/ cachexia in a short period of time.
  • In asymptomatic patients with incidental lab detection of hypercalcemia the cause is usually parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: In a 65 y/o male with COPD showing signs of a bacterial respiratory infection, the sputum sample undergoes culture and sensitivity testing using the Epsilometer (E-test). Following incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition is observed around the antibiotic strip. What is the primary advantage of using the E-test in this clinical context?

choices.text: It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection.
It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics.
It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.
It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.

Explanation:

The primary advantage of the E-test is that it provides a clear, visual indication of the MIC, which is the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the bacterium. This helps clinicians choose the most effective antibiotic and dosage for treatment.

Image showing E-test

 

Step

Description

Setup

An absorbent strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentrations is placed on a culture plate inoculated with the bacterium.

Process

The strip releases the antibiotic, creating a gradient in the medium. An elliptical zone of inhibition forms around the strip after incubation.

Determination

The MIC is identified at the point where the edge of the ellipse intersects with the strip, representing the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth (MIC). (Option C)

Advantages

Allows for the simultaneous testing of multiple antibiotics on a single plate and provides a visual, precise measurement of the MIC, enhancing accuracy compared to traditional disk diffusion methods.

 

It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection (Option A): The E-test assesses bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics but does not identify the specific bacterium. Additional tests like culture characteristics, biochemical tests, or molecular methods are needed for bacterial identification.

It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics (Option B): The E-test measures the MIC for specific antibiotics tested, not for all known antibiotics. Multiple E-tests with different antibiotics can be performed to get a broader resistance profile, but each test is specific to one antibiotic.

It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing (Option D): While the E-test provides valuable information, it still requires incubation and interpretation time. Immediate administration of antibiotics is typically guided by clinical judgment and empirical therapy, not solely by the results of the E-test.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with intermittent abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, and occasional rectal bleeding is scheduled for a sigmoidoscopy. The cannula is inserted in the left lateral position to avoid injuring the rectal folds that are present against the concavities of the rectum. Which of the following statements regarding these folds is inaccurate?

choices.text: First fold is situated near the rectosigmoid junction.
Third fold is located at the upper end of the ampulla.
They are flattened in a distended rectum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) They are flattened in a distended rectum.

 

Explanation:

In this case, the cannula is inserted laterally during the sigmoidoscopy to prevent injury to the permanent, transverse folds referred to as Houston's valves, which are more prominent during distension.

 

Two Types of Folds in the Rectum:

Longitudinal

Houston’s valve  (Transverse or horizontal folds or plicae transversales)
  • Temporary folds
  • Situated in the lower part of an empty rectum.
  • Obliterated by distension
  • Permanent folds (Option B)
  • Situated against the concavities of the lateral curvatures of the rectum.
  • More prominent by distension (Option D)

Types of Houston’s Valves:

Types

First Transverse Fold

Second Transverse Fold

Third Transverse Fold

Fourth Transverse Fold

Site

Near the upper end, close to the rectosigmoid junction. (Option A)

Above the third fold (2.5cm)

At the level of the upper end of the ampulla. (Option C)

Below the third valve (2.5cm)

Wall of Projection

Right or left wall

Left wall

(upper lateral curvature)

Anterior and right wall

(middle lateral curvature)

Left wall

(lower lateral curvature)

questions.text: RBC casts are seen in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mismatched blood transfusion:

  • Mismatched blood transfusion causes haemoglobinuria that leads to pigmented casts / renal tubular epithelial casts
  • In renal tubules, hemoglobin precipitates with Tamm–Horsfall protein that forms pigmented (hemoglobin) casts.
  • Tubular epithelial cells also take up Hb and can slough off, appearing as renal tubular epithelial cell casts.

questions.text:
In a population, the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) are given for the following age groups:


	
		
			
			Age range
			
			
			Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) 
			
			
			Age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) per 1000 women
			
		
		
			
			15-19 years
			
			
			80
			
			
			45
			
		
		
			
			20-24 years
			
			
			280
			
			
			120
			
		
		
			
			25-29 years
			
			
			220
			
			
			110
			
		
		
			
			30-34 years
			
			
			170
			
			
			90
			
		
		
			
			35-39 years
			
			
			85
			
			
			45
			
		
		
			
			40-44 years
			
			
			21
			
			
			10
			
		
		
			
			45-49 years
			
			
			3
			
			
			2
			
		
	


Calculate the Gross Reproductive Rate (GRR) for the age group of 25 years.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 11.9

Explanation: Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she were to experience the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years).

  • To calculate the gross reproductive rate (GRR), we need to consider only female births. The GRR is calculated by summing up the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) per 1000 women.

Step 1: Sum the ASFR values of females.

Total ASFR per 1000 women = 50 + 150 + 130 + 100 + 40 + 5 + 1 = 476

Step 2: Calculate the GRR.

Formula: 

GRR for the age group 25 years

GRR for 25 age group= (25 X 476)/1000 = 11.9

GRR is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates of female live births across all age groups.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents developmental delay. MRI shows demyelination in the central nervous system. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what enzyme deficiency causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Krabbe disease, β-Galactosidase

 

Explanation:

Krabbe disease occurs due to defects in β-Galactosidase, causing demyelination and mental retardation.


 

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A,
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in macula

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash(angiokeratoma)
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males - X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease (Option B)

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease (Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease (Option A ruled out)

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen

Farber disease (Option C ruled out)

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation

questions.text: A group of 4 experts on cardiac health were invited to interact with an audience of about 100 members. However, they were not given any set agenda to speak upon nor did they have any set speeches. They are allowed to discuss among themselves during the event as well and there is no set order of speaking. What kind of event were they invited to?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Panel discussion

 

Explanation:

  • In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 persons who are qualified to talk/ discuss the topic sit and discuss a given problem or topic in front of a large group or audience, without a set agenda or order of speaking and with audience interaction at the end of the discussion.
  • Symposium: In contrast to a panel discussion, a symposium involves 4-8 experts talking on a given topic with set agendas, speeches, and an order of speaking. .(Option B)

Panel discussion

Symposium

4-8 experts

4-8 experts

Two-way or Socratic

Two-way or Socratic

No set agenda

Set agenda

Not set speeches

Set speeches

No set order of speaking

Set order of speaking

Audience is present

Audience is present

Experts can discuss among themselves (they can intervene in between)

Experts cannot intervene in between (they cannot discuss among themselves)

Feedback can be taken

Feedback can be taken

Workshop (Option C):

  • A workshop is a practical educational experience in which participants learn new skills or techniques over a series of four or more meetings.

Seminar (Option D):

  • A seminar is a lecture-style presentation where a speaker provides information on a particular subject and the audience is allowed to ask questions and participate in a discussion.
  • It has a set agenda and speech.

questions.text: A 35 year old man visits the clinic with a persistent cough and fever lasting for more than 2 weeks. He also reports experiencing night sweats and significant weight loss over the past month. Sputum smear tests or radiological tests are not yet done. According to the new terminologies in NTEP, how should this patient's case be categorized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Presumptive TB case

 

Explanation:

  • The patient should be categorized as a "Presumptive TB case" according to NTEP's new terminologies as the patient is showing cough, fever or night sweats & apparent loss in weight for more than 2 weeks.
  • The term Presumptive TB case is used in place of TB suspect (Option B) and refers to individuals who show symptoms suggestive of TB but have not yet been confirmed with a diagnosis.
  • This term is crucial for early identification and screening of TB cases to initiate timely diagnosis and treatment.
  • The new NTEP changes in terminologies are as follows:

Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case
  • Used in place of TB suspect.
  • Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.
  • Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

(Option A)
  • Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB.
  • Used in place of Sputum negative TB case. (Option C)
  • Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear
  • High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case
  • Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT.
  • Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.
  • Positive sputum smear for AFB
  • Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text: How many tests are available in Primary Health Centers under the Free Drugs and Diagnostic Service Initiative of the National Health Mission?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)19

Explanation:

Under the Free Drugs and Diagnostic Service Initiative of the National Health Mission:

  • Primary Health Centers: 19 free tests.
  • Community Health Centres: 39 free tests.
  • District hospitals: 6 free tests.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain and reports that he feels a "catching" sensation during movement after a recent sports injury. On examination, there is localized tenderness along the joint line, and he experiences difficulty fully extending the knee. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a meniscal tear?

choices.text: Pain on passive extension of the knee
Locking of the knee during movement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Locking of the knee during movement

 

Explanation:

  • The most characteristic clinical feature of a meniscal tear is locking of the knee during movement.
  • This symptom, along with the “catching” sensation and joint line tenderness, strongly suggests a meniscal injury

 

Meniscal Injuries:

Anatomy of the Menisci

  • Location: Fibrocartilaginous structures between femur and tibia in the knee joint.
  • Types:
    • Medial Meniscus: Inner side of the knee; less mobile and more prone to injury due to capsule attachments.
    • Lateral Meniscus: Outer side of the knee; more mobile than the medial meniscus.
  • Structure: Composed of circumferential collagen fibers with radial strands; prone to longitudinal tears.
  • Functions:
    • Aids proprioception through mechanoreceptors that detect joint motion and position.
    • Enhance joint stability and congruency.
    • Facilitate smooth knee motion.
    • Distribute load during weight-bearing (50% in extension; up to 90% in flexion).

Mechanism of Meniscal Tears

  • Common Causes:
    • Rotational and Shearing Forces: Twisting a flexed knee under weight (common in sports).
    • Age-Related Degeneration: Reduced mobility in older adults leads to tears with minimal force.
  • Tear Mechanism by Age:
    • Younger Individuals: Traumatic tears from specific sports incidents.
    • Older Individuals: Tears may occur with less force due to degenerative changes, often without a distinct injury.


 

Clinical Features of Meniscal Tears

Symptom/ Feature

Description

Pain

Localized to the joint line, particularly medial; worsens with activities stressing the meniscus.

Swelling

Delayed onset, usually hours after injury; presents as effusion. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanical Symptoms
  • Locking: Difficulty fully extending the knee; suggests "bucket-handle" tear. (Option C)
  • Catching: Sensation of knee getting stuck, indicating loose fragment.
  • Giving Way: Knee buckling during twisting movements, suggesting instability.

Examination Findings
  • Tenderness: Localized along the joint line, typically medial.
  • Limited Extension: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: Possible in chronic cases.
  • Special Tests: Clinical tests (McMurray's, Apley's, Thessaly) assist diagnosis; MRI is the gold standard.

 

Pain on passive extension (Option B) is more indicative of ligamentous injuries rather than meniscal tears.

 

Dislocation of the knee (Option D) joint is not a feature of meniscal tears; it suggests a more severe injury or instability.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. She reports foraging for wild mushrooms earlier in the day and consuming them in a meal. Upon further questioning, it is discovered that she is experiencing visual disturbances and confusion. Physical examination reveals jaundice and signs of dehydration. Which of the following toxins is the likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amatoxin

Explanation: 

The clinical scenario shows a patient with a history of consuming wild mushrooms, confusion, visual disturbance, and jaundice, which is a sign of hepatotoxicity. Amatoxin from Amanita phalloides mushroom can cause hepatotoxicity when ingested.

 

 

Early mushroom poisoning

Late mushroom poisoning

Hallucinogenic mushroom poisoning

Species

Inocybe

Amanita phalloides

Amanita muscaria

Toxin

Muscarine (Option C)

Amatoxin (Option A)

Muscimol

Symptoms

Cholinergic symptoms (DUMBBELLS)

Hepatotoxicity

Hallucinations, seizures

Treatment

Atropine

Thioctic acid

Silibinin

(hepatoprotective)

Supportive treatment

ATROPINE CONTRAINDICATED

 

 

Bungarotoxin (Option B) is a toxin produced by venomous snakes that can lead to bleeding and paralysis.

questions.text:
Match the following instruments with their respective images:


 


	
		
			
			1. Kocher’s forceps
			
			
			A) 
			
		
		
			
			2. Mosquito forceps
			
			 
			B) 
			
		
		
			
			3. Allis forceps
			
			
			C) 
			
		
		
			
			4. Babcock’s forceps
			
			
			D)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)1-A,2-B,3-C,4-D

 

Explanation:

Kocher’s Forceps:

  • Serrations in the distal blades with an opposing tooth at the tip.
  • Holds tissues or pedicles securely, preventing slippage and retraction of vessels or bleeders.

Mosquito Forceps:

  • Distal blades have transverse serrations for a firm grip.

Babcock’s Forceps:

 

  • Distal blades are curved with triangular fenestra, allowing soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Non-traumatic tip with transverse serrations and a ratchet mechanism.

Alli’s tissue-holding forceps:

  • Distal blades do not oppose each other; the tip has opposing teeth in each straight blade.
  • Not recommended for holding delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, and a painful swelling in his axillary region. He reports that he recently returned from a trip to Himachal Pradesh. On physical examination, a large, tender lymph node is noted in the axillary region. Aspirate when stained with methylene blue is shown in the image below.



Which of the following organisms does not show a similar typical appearance as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clostridium tetani

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture (high fever, chills, tender axillary lymph node) and morphological appearance on staining with new methylene blue (Waysons stain) points to the case of Bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • Yersinia pestis characteristically shows safety pin appearance.

Safety pin appearance is shown by the following organisms:

  • Yersinia pestis
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Option B)
  • Burkholderia mallei
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei (Option A)
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Klebsiella granulomatis (Option D)

Clostridium tetani is a Gram-positive, spore-forming anaerobic bacillus. It typically appears as a "drumstick" or "tennis racket" shape under the microscope due to the terminal spores.

 

Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions
  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production]
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Recombinant R1F1v Vaccine: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis
  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

questions.text: A 32 year old man gets into an argument and intentionally causes severe injuries to another person, resulting in a broken arm and significant physical pain. The police decided to charge him under the appropriate section of the BNS. Which section of the BNS is appropriate in this context?

choices.text: He is charged under the section BNS 115 (1)
He is charged under the section BNS 115 (2)
He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)
He is charged under the section BNS 124 (2)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)

Explanation:

  • BNS 117 (2):
    • Specifies the punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt, which can result in imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine. (Option C)
    • Old: Section 325 IPC
  • BNS 115 (1):
    • Defines voluntarily causing hurt. (Option A ruled out)
    • Old: Section 321 IPC
  • BNS 115 (2):
    • Deals with the punishment for voluntarily causing hurt, which carries a lesser penalty than grievous hurt, with imprisonment up to one year or a fine of up to ₹1,0000. (Option B ruled out)
    • Old: Section 323 IPC, where fine was up to ₹1000.
  • BNS 124 (2):
    • Covers voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid, with a minimum imprisonment of 5 years and a fine. (Option D ruled out)
    • Old: Section 326B IPC

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with noticeable cognitive decline. She is diagnosed with Dementia with Lewy Bodies. Which of the following is not a core feature of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systematized delusions

 

Explanation:

While delusions can occur in DLB, systematized delusions (fixed false beliefs that are well organized) are not considered a core feature of the condition, rather are considered a supporting feature.

  • DLB primarily features hallucinations, particularly visual ones, rather than structured delusions.

 

Dementia with Lewy Bodies

  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline sufficient to interfere with social or occupational functioning.
  • Early symptoms may include difficulties with attention, fronto-subcortical skills, and visuospatial ability, rather than prominent memory issues.

 

Clinical Features:

Probable DLB requires two or more core symptoms, while possible DLB requires at least one.

Core Features

Supporting Features
  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (Option B ruled out)
  • Parkinsonian features (e.g., cogwheeling, bradykinesia, resting tremor) (Option D ruled out)
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Repeated falls
  • Syncope
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics
  • Systematized delusions (Option C)
  • Hallucinations in other modalities (e.g., auditory, tactile)

 

Differences in features of LBD and PD:

Feature

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)

Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Onset of Symptoms

Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms appear early; motor symptoms develop later.

Primarily motor symptoms appear first (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors).

Visual Hallucinations

Common and can occur early.

Less common initially; may occur later, often due to treatment.

Fluctuations in Attention

Fluctuations in alertness and attention are characteristic.

Fluctuations are primarily related to medication cycles.

Response to Medications

Poor response to dopaminergic medications; risk of worsening psychiatric symptoms.

Generally improves with dopaminergic medications (e.g., levodopa).

Sleep Disturbances

REM sleep behavior disorder is common and can precede cognitive symptoms.

REM sleep behavior disorder may occur but is primarily linked to motor symptoms.

Progression

Rapid progression of cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Gradual progression of motor symptoms, with cognitive decline developing later.

 

Pathology:

  • Lewy body disease presents clinically similarly to Alzheimer’s disease but is marked by hallucinations, parkinsonian features, and extrapyramidal signs.
  • Lewy bodies, which are abnormal accumulations of α-synuclein aggregates, are found in the cerebral cortex and substantia nigra.
  • In cases where Lewy body pathology coexists with Alzheimer’s, the amygdala is often the only affected region.
  • Patients with Lewy body dementia may exhibit Capgras syndrome (reduplicative paramnesia), highlighting the complex nature of their symptoms.

Lewy bodies

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient is undergoing routine laparoscopic appendectomy under general anesthesia. During laryngoscopy, the anesthesiologist can visualize the entire laryngeal aperture. What is the Cormack-Lehane grading of this laryngoscopic view?
questions.solution:
