questions.text: Which of the following cell deaths is most likely to show pattern B?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Apoptosis

 

Explanation: 

Pattern B shows regular DNA bands (~180–200 bp), forming a “DNA ladder,” which is a hallmark of apoptosis.


 

Apoptosis vs Necrosis on Agarose Gel:

Feature

Apoptosis (Option A) (Option D ruled out)

Necrosis (Options B & C ruled out)

DNA Cleavage

Internucleosomal, specific

Random and nonspecific

Enzyme Involved

Activated endonucleases

Non-specific degradation by cellular enzymes

Electrophoresis Result

Ladder pattern (discrete bands)

Smear pattern (continuous degradation)

Fragment Size

Multiples of ~180–200 base pairs

Heterogeneous, unorganized fragments

Interpretation

Indicates controlled cell death

Indicates uncontrolled cell death

questions.text: In a pharmacology experiment, you observe that adding a competitive antagonist increases the EC50 without changing the maximum response. Adding a non-competitive antagonist decreases the maximum response without changing the EC50. Which of the following best describes the dose-response curve changes for these scenarios?

choices.text: Competitive antagonist shifts left, non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts down, and non-competitive antagonist shifts right.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, non-competitive antagonist shifts left.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.

Explanation:

 

Competitive Antagonism

Non-Competitive Antagonism

Description

Competes with agonists for the same receptor site

Binds to a different site on the receptor, alters receptor function

Effect on Dose-Response Curve

Shifts to the right, no change in maximal response

Flattens the curve, reduces the maximal response

Reversibility

Reversible

Irreversible

Maximal Response

Unaffected

Reduced

Effective Concentration for 50% of population/ EC50 (Km)

Decreased

Unchanged

questions.text:
Cimetidine can reduce the effectiveness of ketoconazole. Which of the following mechanisms explain this interaction?

 


	Cimetidine decreases gastric acid production, leading to reduced absorption of ketoconazole.
	Cimetidine delays gastric emptying, reducing the absorption rate of ketoconazole. 
	Cimetidine increases gastric pH, leading to reduced solubility and absorption of ketoconazole.
	Cimetidine induces liver enzymes, leading to increased clearance of ketoconazole.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1, 3

Explanation:

  • Cimetidine, a H2 receptor antagonist, reduces gastric acid secretion, leading to decreased absorption of ketoconazole when administered concurrently.
  • This interaction can result in decreased efficacy of ketoconazole.
  • Cimetidine is also a potent inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to decreased metabolism of several drugs and subsequent elevation of their serum levels.
  • Theophylline, phenytoin, and warfarin are primarily metabolised by cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, concurrent administration of cimetidine can lead to decreased metabolism and increased levels of these drugs, potentially causing toxicity due to elevated plasma concentrations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is hospitalised at 30 weeks with PPROM. To reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants, the obstetrician decides to administer corticosteroids. Which corticosteroid regimen is recommended to promote fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses
Dexamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses
Hydrocortisone 250 mg intravenous (IV) every 6 hours for 4 doses

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses

 

Explanation:

Antenatal corticosteroid administration has significantly reduced the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and neonatal mortality in preterm infants.

  • The optimal time for administration is between 24 hours and 7 days before delivery, allowing for sufficient time for the corticosteroids to stimulate surfactant production in the fetal lungs.
  • The recommended corticosteroid regimen for promoting surfactant maturation in preterm pregnancies is

 

  • Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for a total of 2 doses.

(OR)

  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses (Option B)

 

  • Betamethasone and Dexamethasone are the preferred corticosteroids due to their potency, minimal mineralocorticoid activity, and ability to cross the placenta effectively.
  • Hydrocortisone (Option C) and Methylprednisolone (Option D) single dose are not recommended regimens for promoting surfactant maturation in preterm pregnancies.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the hospital with lethargy and giddiness. He has a history of being bullied at school due to his physical appearance, which led him to become increasingly interested in various forms of exercise. Over the past three months, he has lost 24 kilograms due to exercise. An ECG performed upon admission is shown below. He appears cachectic and pale. He is assessed by a dietitian and started on nutritional supplements. Two days later, the patient exhibits involuntary muscle contractions, followed by periods of unresponsiveness and confusion. Which electrolyte abnormality would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypophosphatemia

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Anorexia nervosa, as evidenced by the 15-year-old boy's significant weight loss, cachectic appearance, and bradycardia observed on his ECG.
  • He began a nutritional rehabilitation program to address his malnutrition which led to refeeding syndrome as evidenced by the complication of seizure (involuntary muscle contractions, followed by periods of unresponsiveness and confusion)

 

Refeeding Syndrome

  • Refeeding syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur in significantly malnourished patients when they are reintroduced to calories, particularly carbohydrates, after a period of starvation or very low caloric intake.
  • The syndrome is characterized by a series of metabolic and electrolyte disturbances due to the sudden increase in insulin secretion in response to increased calorie intake.

 

Category

Details

Risk Factors
  • Severe malnutrition (e.g., anorexia nervosa, prolonged fasting)
  • Patients who have experienced significant weight loss or are undergoing aggressive refeeding

Metabolic Changes (Option B, C)

Increased insulin levels lead to shifts in electrolytes, particularly:

  • Decreased phosphate (PO4³⁻): Essential for energy production and cellular function. Most common electrolyte abnormality seen in this condition; it is accompanied by prolonged QT interval and bradycardia.
  • Decreased potassium (K⁺): Important for cardiac and muscular function.
  • Decreased magnesium (Mg²⁺): Critical for many biochemical reactions and muscle function.

Clinical Complications
  • Cardiac complications: Arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances.
  • Rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown caused by electrolyte disturbances and increased workload.
  • Seizures: Can occur due to severe electrolyte imbalances.

Management

To prevent refeeding syndrome, it is crucial to:

  • Start feeding at a reduced caloric rate and gradually increase.
  • Monitor electrolytes closely, particularly phosphate, potassium, and magnesium.
  • Provide thiamine supplementation before correcting glucose levels.


 

Hypernatremia (Option D): This does not align with the rapid weight loss and subsequent neurological disturbances observed in this case.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the eye condition shown in the image. The child reports severe eye pain, redness, and eyelid swelling. Examination reveals an inflamed conjunctiva with thick, adherent membranes that bleed when removed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Explanation:

  • Child symptoms like thick, adherent membranes that bleed upon removal, along with the image showing inflamed conjunctiva with adherent membrane, suggest the diagnosis of membranous conjunctivitis.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria is the most common cause of membranous conjunctivitis.

 

Aspect

Membranous Conjunctivitis

Pseudomembranous Conjunctivitis

Characteristics

  • True membranes grow into the conjunctival epithelium and are more adherent.
  • Removal of these membranes often results in significant bleeding.
  • More superficial, with no growth into conjunctival epithelium, and are less adherent than true membranes.
  • These can be removed with minimal bleeding.

Causes

  • Bacterial: Corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Drug Reactions: Hypersensitivity reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).
  • Chemical or thermal injury.
  • Infectious: Mild Corynebacterium diphtheria infection, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option B ruled out), Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out), Staphylococcus aureus, adenovirus (Option A ruled out), COVID-19.
  • Inflammatory: Hypersensitivity reactions, foreign body reactions.
  • Ligneous Conjunctivitis

Image

Symptoms

  • Eye redness
  • Eyelid swelling
  • Watery discharge
  • Visual disturbances
  • Foreign body sensation

Signs

  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Chemosis
  • Eyelid edema
  • Corneal edema
  • Mucopurulent discharge

Management

  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Lubricants improve comfort and rehydrate the eye.
  • Membranes can dissolve on their own.
  • Peeling of pseudomembrane.
  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Removal of foreign bodies if present.
  • Washing the ocular surface to remove chemical irritants.

questions.text:
A 20 year old male patient comes to your dermatology OPD complaining of non-itchy lesions on the back of his elbows, shins, and knees. On examination, you find scaly lesions that exhibit the Auspitz sign, as shown in the image below. Which of the following processes is responsible for this patient's lesions?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Th1-mediated disorder

 

Explanation: 

  • The Auspitz sign, characterized by pinpoint bleeding in the areas where the lesion is scraped with a glass slide, is commonly associated with psoriasis, as depicted in the image above.

 

  • Psoriasis occurs via Th1-mediated immune responses, which are also involved in the pathogenesis of lichen planus.


The inflammatory modulators involved in a Th1 response are:

  • INF-γ (Th1 cells)
  • TNF-α (Th1 cells)
  • Th-17 (IL-17) (Th17 cells)
  • Th-22 (IL-22) (Th22 cells)

 

A detailed depiction of the pathogenesis is given in the image below.

 

Immune cells

Immunomodulators

Examples

Th2 response (Option B)
  • T helper 2 (Th2) cells
  • Eosinophils
  • Mast cells
  • IL-4
  • IL-13

Atopic dermatitis (eczema)

IgE response (Option C)

 
  • B cells (producing IgE antibodies)
  • Mast cells
  • IL-10

Allergic contact dermatitis

Mast cell activation (Option D)
  • Mast cells
  • IL-10

Urticaria (hives)

questions.text: A woman presents at 33 weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate termination of pregnancy

 

Explanation:

  • The umbilical artery doppler depicts reversal of end diastolic flow as waves appearing below baseline which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks , the pregnancy can be terminated.
  • In case of absent end diastolic flow, the waves just touch the baseline but dont appear below it. This suggest fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C Section if >34 weeks.
  • Reverse end diastolic flow suggests impending fetal death , hence the pregnancy is terminated by C section if >32 weeks.

 

Patterns  of end diastolic flow in umbilical artery :

questions.text: In a lateral chest X-ray, which area should you focus on to identify pathology in the hilar region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

In a lateral chest X-ray, the hilar region is typically located posteriorly and laterally within the mediastinum.

Focusing on area B allows for optimal visualization of structures such as the pulmonary arteries, veins, and lymph nodes, which are critical in identifying potential pathologies like tumors, infections, or vascular changes.

Area B is best suited for assessing any abnormalities that may indicate underlying disease in the hilar region.

 

Normal anatomy, Chest radiograph (PA View and Lateral View)

 


 

 

Fissures of the Lung and Hemidiaphragm in Chest Radiography

 

Lung Fissures in Chest Radiography

 

Right Lung

Left Lung

Three lobes: Upper, Middle, Lower

Two lobes: Upper, Lower

Fissures:

Horizontal fissure: Separates the upper and middle lobes.

Oblique fissure: Separates the middle from the lower lobe, and also divides the upper from the lower lobe.

Fissures:

Oblique (major) fissure: Separates the upper from the lower lobe.


Clinical Relevance:

  • Right Middle Lobe (RML) Collapse: Seen as a wedge-shaped opacity overlying the heart on lateral X-ray.
  • Lobar Pneumonia: Fissures localize consolidation (e.g., obscured right heart border in RML pneumonia).
  • Pleural Effusion: Blunts fissures due to fluid accumulation.


 

Elevated Hemidiaphragm

Flat Hemidiaphragm

One side of the diaphragm appears higher than normal.

The normally dome-shaped diaphragm appears flattened and lower in position.

Causes:

 
  • Subphrenic Abscess: Pus beneath diaphragm.
  • Hepatomegaly/Splenomegaly: Enlarged organs push the diaphragm upward.
  • Diaphragmatic Palsy: Paralysis due to phrenic nerve injury.
  • Lung Collapse/Fibrosis: Loss of lung volume elevates the diaphragm.
  • Atelectasis: Collapsed lung leads to diaphragm elevation.

Causes:

 
  • COPD: Hyperinflated lungs cause a flat diaphragm and tubular heart appearance.
  • Tension Pneumothorax: Air pushes the diaphragm downward.
  • Emphysema: Destruction of lung tissue results in diaphragm flattening.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and poor weight gain. A peripheral blood smear revealed a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. Biochemical investigations reveal very low levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MTTP gene mutation

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings suggest Abetalipoproteinemia, caused by a mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP), which is required for the transfer of lipids to nascent apolipoprotein B polypeptide in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Abetalipoproteinemia:

Aetiology
  • Mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP)

Presentation
  • Extremely low cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • Intestine shows lipid vacuoles because of problem in lipid transfer.
Biochemical investigation
  • Low triglyceride cholesterol levels
  • Low fat soluble vitamin levels

Symptoms
  • Presents in infancy with failure to thrive, diarrhoea, and steatorrhea.

Peripheral smear
  • Presence of acanthocytes-RBCs with peripheral spikes

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding clinical features of Madelung deformity?

choices.text: Volar and ulnar angulation of distal radius

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mostly unilateral

 

Explanation:

Madelung deformity is mostly bilateral, not unilateral

 

Pathogenesis:

  • Distal end of the radius growth plate fuses early causing defect in growth of radius.
  • But ulna continues to grow normally and hence more prominent resulting in positive ulnar variance.

 

Clinical features:

  • Girls are more affected
  • Mostly bilateral (Option A)
  • Appears in late childhood or adolescence and worsens

 

Deformity:

  • Volar subluxation of hand (Option B)
  • Prominence of distal ulna (Option C)
  • Volar and ulnar angulation of distal radius - Management by Darrach’s procedure.(Option D)

questions.text: A 36 y/o woman, G3P2, delivered via C-section 4 hours ago and is now experiencing severe PPH unresponsive to uterine massage and uterotonics. Her vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension. The medical team opts for surgical intervention to avoid a hysterectomy. What is the principle behind performing bilateral internal iliac artery ligation to control her PPH?

choices.text: To apply direct pressure on the bleeding site
To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure
To increase uterine contractility and reduce bleeding
To promote rapid healing of uterine tissues

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure

 

Explanation:

  • The principle of bilateral internal iliac artery ligation is to reduce blood flow to the uterus and pelvis, significantly lowering pulse pressure (85% reduction) in arteries distal to the ligation.
  • This reduction in pressure makes the blood vessels more conducive to hemostasis through clot formation, similar to venous circulation.
  • Considerations:
    • Ligation of the internal iliac artery is to be done at 5cm distal to common iliac bifurcation - this avoids the posterior division branches of the internal iliac artery.
    • Should not perforate continuous large veins, esp. Internal iliac vein.
    • Non-absorbable sutures are used.

To apply direct pressure on the bleeding site (Option A) is not the goal of internal iliac artery ligation; this applies to uterine tamponade or manual compression.

 

To increase uterine contractility and reduce bleeding (Option C) is achieved with uterotonics, not artery ligation.

 

To promote rapid healing of uterine tissues (Option D): Internal iliac artery ligation controls bleeding by reducing blood flow, not by promoting tissue healing.

questions.text:
A 55 y/o male heart transplant patient comes for a follow-up visit. He reports that he has been engaging in moderate exercise for about 30 minutes daily. Despite lacking sympathetic innervation to his transplanted heart, he notices an increase in his stamina and ability to exercise over time.

Given the patient's condition, what physiological mechanism allows him to experience an increase in cardiac output during exercise?

choices.text: Increased heart rate through parasympathetic withdrawal.
An enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism.
Parasympathetic stimulation reduces heart rate variability.
Increased heart rate through sympathetic stimulation to heart.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism

Explanation:

The Frank-Starling mechanism allows the heart to increase stroke volume by enhancing the force of contraction in response to increased venous return during exercise, thereby increasing cardiac output.

While parasympathetic withdrawal can lead to a slight increase in heart rate, it is not the primary mechanism by which cardiac output is increased in a heart transplant patient during exercise(Option A).

 

Aspect

Details

Frank-Starling Mechanism

More heart muscle stretch during filling leads to stronger contractions and higher stroke volume.

Sympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot increase heart rate through the sympathetic nervous system. (Option D)

Parasympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot decrease heart rate through the parasympathetic nervous system. (Option C)

Stroke Volume Increase

Achieved by increased force of contraction in response to increased venous return during exercise.

Cardiac Output

Increased primarily due to higher stroke volume, not heart rate.

Comparison to Healthy Individuals

Less increase in cardiac output, relying on stroke volume rather than both stroke volume and heart rate.

So, in transplant patients,the increase in cardiac output during exercise is mainly due to an increase in stroke volume, not heart rate.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman under general anesthesia for an emergency cesarean section suddenly develops acute respiratory distress with cyanosis and decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field. Chest X-ray shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for this condition?

choices.text: Maternal anxiety and apprehension during labor.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased gastric motility.

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is consistent with the diagnosis of Mendelson’s syndrome. Increased gastric motility is not a predisposing factor for Mendelson’s syndrome.

 

Mendelson’s Syndrome- serious and life-threatening complication caused by aspiration of gastric contents (pH <2.5) under general anesthesia in young and healthy obstetrical patients (especially during cesarean section).
Predisposing Factors

Delayed gastric emptying (Option D) due to: High serum progesterone levels (Option A), decreased motilin (Option B, or maternal apprehension during labor (Option C)
Complications
  • Chemical pneumonitis
  • Lung damage
  • Atelectasis
  • Bronchopneumonia

Clinical features

Commonly Affected lobe: Right lower lobe (due to aspiration through the right bronchus).

  • Tachycardia
  • Tachypnea
  • Bronchospasm
  • Rhonchi
  • Rales
  • Cyanosis
  • Decreased PaO₂
  • Hypotension
Diagnosis Chest X-ray reveals right lower lobe involvement.
Management
  • Immediate suctioning of the oropharynx and nasopharynx to remove inhaled fluid.
  • Bronchoscopy if large particulate matter is present.
  • Continuous positive pressure ventilation (CPAP) to maintain arterial oxygen saturation at 95%.
  • Administration of antibiotics if infection is evident.
